item.title: Wes Humpston talks - Fireman Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_15074" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wes Humpston at Fireman 1975[/caption]

Wes Humpston

"John Palfreyman AKA "JP" and I became tired of pools getting busted. We were done with too many people being at the pools. Â We just wanted a pool for us to ride. JP was one of or the top BMX riders in the countryÂ at the time and skating was coming on strong. At the BMX races, JP would ask other racers if they knew of any pools and tell the kids what to look for, like pool equipment and that corrugated aqua fiberglass and privacy fencing. So, the kids would search during the week and come to the next race with their pool intelligence and info. We would go out to meet them and see the pool. Some guys had three or more to show us. We skated the Pink Motel and some other well known pools long before they became known about."

[caption id="attachment_15076" align="aligncenter" width="584"] JP[/caption][caption id="attachment_15077" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tom Lund[/caption]

"The Fireman Pool was on a three day, four day work schedule, which was figured out by the kids from watching his house. The owner was a fireman and had a pretty regular work schedule. So, we were skating in pool heaven a few days a week and then we'd put everything back the way we found it. He had no clue that anyone was ever there." - Wes Bulldog Humpston

All images: Humpston Archive

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think there were a lot of guys doing multiple disciplines back then ,just like myself, skateboards ,surf, motocross, bmx, mt. bikes, mid to late 1970s was the birth of action sports . I can remember a great / famous photo of Tom Lund flying on a ( first full suspension bicycle) jump the highest i ever seen. Thanks, lets go ride now!
Wes, I saw Thom and JP race at Chatsworth Park one time. I raced as well back then. Thets the first time I saw the orange monoshock bike Thom had. It weas so new, and heavy as well. Long time ago.

item.title: a long way down...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4236" align="aligncenter" width="450"] skreech-- at night..."rising above it"[/caption] I was watchingÂ  a video of the Xgames recently. It was early in the global prostitution of skateboarding. I'd say that the video was of the 97 Xgames. Tony Hawk was riding in the vert finals at night & the announcer (an ESPN goob) was blathering on about how Hawk was "grinding the piping, displaying courageous amplitude" and other inanities. I remember looking around and mumbling, " What the hell happened to skateboarding?!" Then, in the middle of Tony Hawks run, the announcer proceeded with the following 'vowel movement'. "Tony Hawk. He's rising above it! He's the 'Night Hawk'!" I fell out of my chair. The 'Night Hawk'?! You have to be kidding me? ESPN-- in their infinite wisdom--eventually hired skaters to announce the Xgames buffoonery. I am certainly happy about that fact. Leave skating in the hands of the people that do it 'for life'.Â  I was watching Skreech ride 'Ridiculous' pool recently. It made me happy to know that Skreech keeps it real. Not that Tony Hawk doesn't. I have known Tony for quite awhile...he's for real, but when you are Tony, things can get kicked sideways by the media. He can be portrayed in a peculiar manner. Talk with Skreech & you will quickly see that he has an interesting outlook on skating. He skates for himself. He is not the "Night Hawk". However--I must say--he can "rise above it." I likeÂ  Tony & Skreech. I don't particularly share the same feeling for ESPN. At least the pockets of the fat-bellied, corporate carpet-baggers, have emptied themselves & our people are now paid accordingly. Remember, don'tÂ  'Bite the head off a SlimJim & Do the Dew' That is just plain silliness. Thanks to Ray Zimmerman for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: inconsequential?
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4346" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Mike Hamerla- proving that 'everything' is of consequence.[/caption] "Nobody can go back & start a new beginning, but anyone can start today & make a new ending."-Maria Robinson You will have to excuse the 'therapy' posts of late. I am going through some inner conflicts & need to do what I need to do. 'Blue Tile' is my deal, so I'll write exactly what I feel, regardless. Inconsequential= unimportance. Sometimes I think about the larger scope of things. Deceitfulness, lies, greed, world hunger, AIDS, the ravaging of our earth, war & attrition, genocide continuing unabated...and I am struck by the triviality of skateboarding. However, all things have their place. Skateboarding keeps us physically & mentally strong in some respects, provides youth with an activity to keep them--hopefully--out of trouble, and gives kids out there some sort of hope. Maybe it gives them a hope that they will skate & momentarily be free of family strife & peer pressure. Maybe skating can provide this. I believe hope is a good thing. I have seen some old friends lately; friends that are no longer my friends because of my past transgressions. The day I saw them again, they carried themselves with far more grace than I deserved. These two men were true friends. I feel saddened to know I burned those bridges. I can scream "I'm sorry!" for the world to hear, but--at this point-- it matters little. Some things you can't take back. However, I hold 'hope' close to my chest like a faded family photograph. I think that by doing the right things, maybe I can get a different ending. I've started. I can only hope.Â  Thanks to Ray Zimmerman for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Jeff Phillips
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4509" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Jeff Phillips-Arlington[/caption] On Christmas day 1993, Jeff Phillips took his own life. Whatever problems were plaguing him, evidently were harrowing enough to force his hand. I only wish someone could have helped Jeff. At The Howard Johnson pool, in San Bernardino, there was a 'Jeff Phillips' sticker on the shallow tiles by the stairs. I have seen Salba, Reul, Belmar & countless others slap it with their hand before riding the pool....every time. Respect. Jeff Phillips is missed. R.I.P. bro.Â  Thanks to Geoff Graham for the image. Thank you also to Rob Mertz. For more on remembering 'Jeff Phillips', visit the Rob Mertz link below. Skate-Ozzie MERTZWORLD.net

item.title: Spitting out smoke
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5322" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Joe Marrara -FS Ollie[/caption] Dawn oozes pale sunlight across the windshield of my car. I squint & flip the sun visor down. Its cool at this time of the day, but I know that this will soon give way to the life-sucking blast furnace that is San Bernardino in the summertime. I watch the rolling metal cages--just like mine--blast past me in a hurry to get to whatever fate awaits them. I see theirÂ  tail lights fade into the dawn on the asphalt ribbon of road that I am hurtling down. I always wonder about people. What's their story? What is important to that person? Where have they been? Are they affected-- like I am-- by a haunting train whistle in the night? Do they see horror in everything, or goodness? Who lives in that dark, shadow-cluttered house over there in the distant trees?Â  I wonder. Always have. I but follow the threads of my own fate & some days am in awe at things I've seen & done. 'Coldplay' comes on the radio, I scoff & quickly turn that homogenized garbage off, lest it eat into my brain like a mediocre narcotic I don't want. The last thing I want to be doing is walking around humming 'Coldplay'....gods forbid! I put 'Entombed' 'Wolverine Blues' on the 'Ipod' & feel relief rush over me in an awesome way. I feel like I'm made of metal...a strange new form of titanium, impervious to lifes more difficult trials & tribulations. I grin in self-satisfaction because I know that this happens rarely to me. I'm actually a pretty sensitive person & periodically I feel too much. I am truly haunted. I am haunted by the things I've done & people I have hurt. At least this keeps me human. If I were to stop 'feeling', I couldn't go on. My demise. Sometimes however, I let things bother me, when in actuality I should say, "The hell with it!" Regardless, I will feel like metal today & laugh while life's problems slip & flow off of my skin like dirty pool water. Thanks to Brian Fick for the image of Joe Marrara.Â  Skate- Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: return
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: the walk up just a sunny day by the pool bottles and cans slatetop up the hip Lance-fastplant...the hard way! Ripperside Shawn Kevin Burke me Tough luck. I havenât forgotten it. It is nailed into my skin dailyâit seemsâand some days I find it hard to go on. Golgotha. Storm clouds. I am so uncertain. Life is crippling. I gave up everything & am left with littleâ¦ some books, threadbare clothing & a few faded photographs I cannot part with. My heart is sold. I seemingly wait for nothing. I neither smoke, drink nor do drugs. I havenât dated in an entire year. My last relationship was a debacle. At times, there is an ocean under my eyes. My soul is like dried, cracked leather. The older I become, the less I understand. Though, there is a certain odd freedom in giving up all responsibility & expectation. My toughest daily decision is deciding what I am eating for dinner. Rice & beans or rice & beans. I am becoming quieter; my mouth is out of words. Coldâ¦ is my endless road. My lifeâstuck in the âwaiting roomâ. I am sitting at a glass & chrome table. Its surface is dullâ¦like my senses. The sun is bleeding itself out into the ocean. I can see it growing red & darkness falls across me. I havenât been writing on âBlue Tileâ lately. It has been a tough few weeks. I looked at a few photographs recently. They were of a session in Palm Springs with Ripperside Shawn, Kevin Burke, Brandon Wong, Lance Mountain, Samwise & myself. I was reminded âall too clearlyâwhat is important. I must remember what I was & where I came from. I must stay grateful for what I have. So it is. I will be posting some new pool stories. Thanks for the emails & comments. Thank you to MRZ, Samwise & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate & be grateful- Ozzie first posted Â January 2010

item.title: Circling the Drain
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Skateboarders. We must be masochistic. Destroyed. I âlike others of myÂ kindâ learn through pain. I feel broken. When IÂ climb out of bed in the morning, my joints crack and Â I sound like someÂ strange anatomical popcorn popper. I have used up more ice taking careÂ of my injuries than I have ever used drinking glasses of whiskey. MyÂ liver tells me that Iâve consumed about half the whiskey in IrelandÂ soâ¦ Â I only heal so I can hurt again. Itâs the game we play. WhileÂ the world has their noses buried in TV, computer and cell phone screens,Â living their lives visually through others, skaters live our livesÂ viscerally. We participate. Often such participation is at our ownÂ peril. In the eyes of the world, we always play the wrong card.Â  TheÂ idea of sitting on a couch in front of a TV idly thumbing the remote,Â fills me with a self-loathing not easily transferred into language.Â People watch and believe the lies the TV continues telling us. âOnlyÂ money will make you happy.â â Only money will make you happy.âÂ Reprehensible. PeopleÂ  buy the same tired things in the same boringÂ fashion. Toe the line. Appear important. Go broke, appearing rich. Skateboarders reject such nonsense out of hand. Krishnamurti wrote,Â âThe greater the outward show, the greater the inward poverty.âÂ  IÂ would have to agree. We walk our own path. Skaters have found theÂ anti-authoritarian ideal that pervades skateboarding and the lawlessnessÂ of it, a warm embrace in a cold distant society. Â  We continually battleÂ with fear and ourselves. Society shuns us unless they are prostitutingÂ us for monetary gain or âcoreâ credentialsâ¦ Itâs enough to make oneÂ sick. I battle with advancing age and physical decline. Injuries and societal norms have forced me deeper underground. I no longer try and explain myself. I am persona non grata in polite circles. I ride thatÂ useless wooden toy. I canât imagine my life without a skateboard. IÂ wouldnât know how to live. No drug, booze, sex or respectableÂ endeavor has ever fulfilled me the way skateboarding has. It is lawless and unconventional. Anarchist.Â  I went into the military and served my country with honor, went to college, earned a degree,Â received a few letters after my name and gained the coveted 'respectabilityâ, yet remained emptyâ¦Â  unless I skated. It is the oneÂ true gift of my existence and â in the eyes of the worldâÂ  has sent myÂ life straight down the drain. Until the distant shuddering stars burnÂ out and all of the buildings crumble into the earthâ¦ I wonât change aÂ thing.- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: love this Ohzee.

You already know how I feel about this my friend! We've talked about it so many times. Without skateboarding we would be nothing, we'd have nothing. It's who we are, not what we do! We're proud 100% skateboarders for life and we wouldn't have it any other way! I Love this post Ozzie, it gets right to the point!

I can do nothing but agree with you... To skate is to live. No matter how much getting hurt can be a slow process (and I've been put back together) I will keep on getting up, healing up, and skating.
As usual I enjoy your posts. Thanks!

But if you say "This is what I really want to do and I am going to pursue it," then you will find that something miraculous takes place. You may have to go hungry, struggle to get through, but you will be a worthwile human being, not a mere copy, and THAT is the miracle of it. -Krishnamurti

When I read this in Defect, I showed it to my wife and tried to explain why I am who I am. She got it of course and agrees there is something inherently different about me. I blame it on skateboarding, punk rock and good pals. Thanks for the validation OZ!

I skate at this age regardless of what people say or think. Jealously manifest in undetected ways. I've returned to skating after a long absence and laugh at the insults and other devices people use to declare me crazy. I've had people yell at me on the streets to get some pedals and I even had one ingrate tell me I hope I enjoy taking food through a tube. The intense joy I receive through skating cannot be conveyed to the uninitiated. You're so right....I could loose every material possession and not miss any of it as long as I can keep skating.
Well said Ozzie. Thanks for the Skate Journal of Insight.
Skateboarding is my first love. I won't let her down.
Great photograph the accompanying words that went with it, Oz.

item.title: Motivation
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_15092" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva at Paul Revere[/caption] Tony Alva was an inspiration to me when I was a young outcast in central Pennsylvania. I would obtain a copy ofÂ  Skateboard World magazine and read EVERY single letter, cover- to- cover. The magazine was my bible and skateboarding my religion. I would be forced to go to church every Sunday morning and night. The bible of the church had interesting stories. I liked that people lived to be nine hundred years old, had tons of wives, water was turned into wine, prostitutes and lepers flourished and people fought during massive bloody wars. There were even sacrifices and fires...Â  I love fire! All-in-all, the bible was killer reading when you are forced to be there on a Sunday. I would sit there on the mahogany wooden pews, thumbing the cabbage-colored pages of the bible. I would stare at the stained glass windows and think of skating. At Woodward, I heard a kid say, "I would rather be riding bike in the woods, looking at the beauty of nature that God created, than sitting in church thinking about my bicycle."Â  It was that way for me. We shared the same sentiment. I liked church. I loved the pageantry and hated its punishment. Sitting there, watching the candles cast wavering shadows on the walls, I wondered--even then--if God actually hated us. Like it dawned on him--one day--what a colossal mistake he made in creating us. Rage, war, inadequacies, pure destructiveness. Maybe he would have enough and send in the Calvary. Then angels would come, carrying savage weapons. Angels- One, Humanity- Zero. God hates us? I thought he must have. I mean, Jesus sounded pretty rad to me. You have to like a guy that teaches and feeds people. You have to love a guy that goes into a room full of money-lenders and starts breaking things up with a stick or a whip....Â  I have often thought of going into Bank of America myself and laying into a few people with a stick! I understand. Human beings are greedy, cruel and self-absorbed. I try not to be those things, but I am sure I have hit the mark from time to time. Regardless, I would pull out my well-thumbed copy of Skateboard World and stare at images of Tony Alva and others. I would place the magazine inside an opened copy of the bible and peer urgently at the world I wanted to be a part of.... a world so foreign to my surroundings. Pennsylvania. California. The math doesn't even add up! I taped photographs of Tony Alva, Wally Inouye and Jerry Valdez on my wall. I constantly reminded myself what I loved. Skateboarding. It was just it and me. There was no bullying. My skateboard never struck me in anger. My skateboard never mocked or ridiculed. It was ALWAYS there. It provided an endless escape from the dusty country life that ran away in every direction I looked. The roads were buckled and cracked asphalt. The streets and people were old and they followed even older ideals. I could cruise my ramp and pretend. In my mind, IÂ  was with Tony Alva and Wally Inouye, skating Fruit Bowl. I was hanging with Tony Alva at the Long Beach arena when he kicked ass!Â  These thoughts pulled me through the rough times. In a strange twist, I have met Tony Alva and most of my childhood heroes. IÂ  hang out with Tony Alva pretty frequently now. We are friends. He just celebrated another year of sobriety and once again....he is an inspiration and motivation for me. I love skateboarding. Thanks to Arto Saari for the images. Skate-Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you, go ride a skateboard now. Arto Saari inspires me!
I can relate 100%.

item.title: The Return
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: the walk up just a sunny day by the pool bottles and cans slatetop up the hip Lance-fastplant...the hard way! Ripperside Shawn Kevin Burke me Tough luck. I havenât forgotten it. It is nailed into my skin daily and some days I find it hard to go on. Golgotha. Storm clouds. I am so uncertain. Life can be crippling. I gave up everything and am left with littleâ¦ some books, threadbare clothing and a few faded photographs I cannot part with. My heart is sold. I seemingly wait for nothing. I neither smoke, drink nor do drugs. Â My soul is like dried, cracked leather. The older I become, the less I understand. There is a certain odd freedom in giving up all responsibility and expectation. My toughest daily decision is deciding what I am eating for dinner. Rice and beans or rice and beans. I am becoming quieter. My mouth is out of words. I am sitting at a glass and chrome table. Its surface is dullâ¦ like my senses. The sun is bleeding itself out into the ocean. I can see the night looming. I looked at a few photographs recently. They were of a session in Palm Springs with Ripperside Shawn, Kevin Burke, Brandon Wong, Lance Mountain, Samwise and myself. I was reminded âall too clearlyâwhat is important. I must remember what I was and where I came from. I must stay grateful for what I have. Â Thank you to MRZ, Samwise & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate and be grateful- Ozzie Posted- January 2010

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Keep on keepin' on my man!

item.title: suffering
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
California Department of Corrections.
The man woke in the dark like he always did. He had been dreaming. This time he had been a bird. Freedom. Â Corrections officers were loud out on the pod. He turned on his side and listened for a moment. He knew that it was probably close to morning but it was hard to tell in here. There was a small gash of plexiglass close to the ceiling which let in light. The walls outside were massive and blocked virtually all sunlight from reaching them anyway. He didn't know. He didn't care. His cell mate snored away above him. Reaching over beside the thin mattress, he pulled out his penlight and the skateboard magazine that he had traded contraband for. He glanced at the glossy cover. Â He thumbed through it and was pretty stoked. Â "Whoa!" He had turned the page to a pool article. "This Jimmy Wilkins is ripping!" He paged through and saw other photographs that made him feel like he was back in a better time.
Jimmy Wilkins
He had finally got his hands on a different skateboard magazine about five years earlier. Thrasher. TransWorld. He didn't recall the name. It was lame. All he saw were a bunch of kooks falling down stairs. The magazines seemed to be bending over for the advertisers. Whatever. It wasn't skating to him. He had rode almost every day before he was placed in here. He remembered the golden times. The money. Endless boxes of product. Autographs. Women... He remembered a girl pulling him by his hand underneath a contest ramp to an isolated spot. She just smiled and knelt down. She said his name as she unzipped his shorts. "Gator" He recalled those times in his life often and let his mind soar outside of the confining walls he lived in. He heard his cell mate still snoring and jerked off into his pillow. He was a freak then and he was a freak now. Back then, no one knew. He wore his mask well. Â Leaning on one arm, Â he paged through the magazine again. It was full of awesome stories and great pool and pipe photographs. It was soulful and real. He chuckled as he came upon a photograph of someone he recognized. Owen Neider. They had rode at Del Mar together all those long years ago. It briefly made him happy that some of the old crew were still ripping.
Owen Neider
Paul Wisniewski
He soon heard the Corrections staff opening the pod and getting the inmates ready for breakfast. The prison was dangerous. It was full of every race and culture. It was no melting pot though. He smirked to himself. It was more of a garden salad. The cucumbers stayed with the cucumbers. The black olives stayed with the black olives. The iceberg lettuce remained with its own kind and although they may lay on top each other from time to time exchanging juices, their flavors never mingled. It was an odd and joyless world. Persistent pain.
Al Brunelle
Kevin Caan
He looked away from the magazine. Jessica. He thought of her from time to time. She was the one white-hot incandescent spot that burned in his brain and made his nights sweat-soaked and sleepless. Jessica. His association with her had put him in here. This was what he told himself when he thought of the horror of a human being that he became. The moment he choked her, the line blurred. He wiped a small tear that threatened to spill from the corner of his eye. It wasn't for her. He didn't operate like that. He was wallowing. He only thought of himself. People were objects and she was the one smudge of his pathetic past that he couldn't wipe away. It reappeared every day. Cursed. Failure. If he could be honest for one second in his life, he would know how he deserved his suffering. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate Â - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: the guy is in prison for like what?20 yrs? and you guys still have a need to talk about all of these things, you gotta give Mark rogowski a break. He is pretty much dead for the skateboard world for years and i bet he is a totally different person nowadays after a 20 year jail experience, so there's no need in bringing back the whole story over and over.

Ozzie have you been talking to Gator recently? how do you know all these things about his life in jail? Or is this a piece wrote by you kinda using Gator as a character? Dude's on where he belongs till 2018. Great reading by the way!

item.title: Steve Caballero - Guest Post
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I have been asking people to participate in doing 'Guest Posts' on the Blue Tile Obsession. It allows for me to have a break & also gives everyone a differing perspective on things from others. I supplied Steve Caballero with five photographs and asked him to choose one & talk about it. He chose an older image from the Big-O. Steve is hovering a frontside ollie mid -channel. It's an epic photograph. Here is what he recollects from that time. Steve Caballero "The Big-O contest was the second Gold Cup. It went like this: Gold Cup - Â Oasis, then Big-O, then Colton, then Marina & finally Upland. All had channels & doing a trick over the channel was --pretty much--a requirement. People were doing airs over them. Oasis & Marina were gnarly because the channel walls were not straight across. You had to pull hard to make it. Big-O was directly across so you could frontside ollie it. I don't recall anyone making a backside ollie over it. I think Alan Gelfand and Steve Olson frontside ollied it as well. I actually came down for practice before the contest. I made airs over the channel & then started trying the ollie. Back then we had compulsory runs. If I remember correctly, it went like this: FS carve, FS air, invert, BS carve, BS air, slide to fakie on the wall, fakie ollie, rock walk, rock-n-roll then out. This kept all the riders on the same level. I remember that Alan Gelfand had to come and learn inverts before the contest. He made them in practice. I think I ended up 3rd in the Big-O contest. The next contest was Colton which I won. I went home to Winchester and practiced. I tried to learn new tricks. I was skating and saw Robert 'The Fly' Schlaefli doing a fakie 360 kickturn in the bowl. He went too fast & flailed it around. The board spun around with him. It made me wonder- "Maybe that could be done as a 360 ollie." Between the Colton and Marina contests, I learned the Caballerial. I explained it to Stacy on the phone but he didn't understand. Word got out to Lance Mountain & Neil Blender. When Stacy & I pulled up at Marina for contest practice, they were waiting. They wanted to see this 360 ollie. I got out & pulled one in the upper keyhole for Neil, Lance and Stacy. Unfortunately, I didn't make the Caballerial at the Marina Gold Cup, but I did at the next contest in Upland. I Â won at Pipeline. Neil & Lance went back to Whittier and worked on the Caballerial but couldn't make it without grabbing. They started doing it and they thought it was gay that they had to grab, so they named it the 'Gay Twist'. That is where it all came from. Eddie Elguera was a huge inspiration. He always had something new at a contest & I tried to do the same. The fakie ollie and frontside ollie all progressed into other tricks. It was a long progression." Thanks to Steve Caballero for the words & memories. Thanks to Tim Lunt and Paul Horning for the stellar images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Good history lesson
Thanks for making history Cab, fun to witness & fun to get the back story straight from the gentleman. I was there as a little kid but did not know any of that. Gr8 read.
Great article as usual Ozzie! Where is Cab's frontside grind photo from?

item.title: Sprawl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
"The essentials of happiness are: something to do, something to love, and something to hope for."-Â Â Allan K. Chalmers Dirty concrete. Billboards. Ribbons of oil-stained road. People fly by in their cars, oblivious to the disintegrating world that litters the overpasses and dead end streets nearby. Â The homeless clutter and huddle there, sharing needles and poisoned blood. Glass bottles become the only sound that brings any comfort in a world gone horribly wrong. A fairly young man stands and peers into the twilight. His sparse beard is dirty and his skin yellowing from jaundice. Hepatitis... Â or maybe something worse. He had rolled around in a dirty car with a twisted guy on a filthy night. He needed the money, and the drugs his body craved had removed caution and self-esteem a long, long time ago. San Jose had once been kind to him. He rode bicycles and skateboards. He loved his family. He once dreamed of a new age dawning. It didn't last. Teenage years disappeared. Drugs. Low places.Â He gave up his skateboarding Â friends. They had phoned him and gave him hell. "Put the pipe away dude! Come skate." But, his new friends ridiculed skateboarding. "When are they going to grow up?" Â He looked away and followed their lead. He didn't need to skate. He became hard. Part of the crew. Streetwise and in the gritty loop. A year flew by in a minute. He found himself in a shadowed doorway. The quest for job opportunities and a better life paled in comparison to seeking the soothing rush of opiate armor that he now clothed himself in. Blurry blood. Disease. Inside the sickness. He watched as the cars burned past on the freeway. He looked down and saw blackened pieces of chewing gum on the concrete sidewalk. He felt like one of them. Scuffed. Forgotten. Boot heels. Moving over to an abandoned, piss-stained couch, he sat down and wondered where to go. "How in the hell...?" Regret was a word that stuck close to his tongue. He wouldn't admit this even to himself. Â He had made some pretty poor decisions. Trucks hurtled past him. He sat. Numb. He soon drifted off. His dreams were no longer of life, happiness and youth.
Lake Cunningham Skate Park. San Jose
A few miles away, Lake Cunningham Skate ParkÂ glitters under the afternoon sun. Riders fly through its perfect corners and round bowls in every direction. Smiles are everywhere. Skaters work on tricks. Fear is conquered. Self-esteem is gained. The long road up to the light.
Mike Griffin- blasting
Eddie Elguera 5-0 fakie
Jeff Hedges- sadplant
The skate park serves as a place where people can gather and progress. They need to stay wary. Vice. Thug life. A dark mentality. It is around every corner. One must be ever vigilant. The family of skateboarding. It can save a life.
Daniel Cuervo
Michael Parente- frontside ollie
Thank you to Steve Potwin and Dan Sparagna for the images. Skate... and never stop - Ozzie
Dan Sparagna- frontside air

item.title: Where happiness lives.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Origins Riverside. 1966.Â Her thin voice. She could barely hear it herself... It was always this way. She was mild. Meek. She kept close to her children and the home. They were growing up so fast. As soon as she bought them new clothing and shoes, another set was soon needed by all. There were holes in the knees, socks, toes and her husbands wallet. He jokingly referred to the kids as " The money pit." He flicked the edges of the newspaper, peering over the top of the Riverside Bulletin and she could see his eyes smiling. She knew that everything would be alright. With him around, it always would be. Nearly fifteen years had gone by since they had met during a hot summer in the valley. Long nights were spent in silence. The desert seeped into them. They'd sit under a zillion stars. A black blanket of diamonds drizzled above them. He had just come back from the war in Europe. She never knew what he had seen because he never thought it worth relating to her. Deep pain. Scars reopened and he was not allowed to understand. He would toss in his sleep, sweating and calling out. She brushed the matted hair away from his eyes and kissed him. Life "Lois? The kids are in. They're ready to eat." His voice rumbling through the kitchen, pulled her from her reverie. The youngsters soon filled the kitchen with laughter and noise. Dinner. Family. Happiness was in residence. She set the crock pot of beef stew on the table and they quickly served themselves. The kitchen was the very center of their lives. A huge oak table spread out across the room. The kids would sit in a cluster at her feet as she read to them. Fairy tales. Persian poems. Grabbing a towel from the sink, she caught a glimmer from the water in the swimming pool outside. It was huge. When he had the rambling house built with government loans, he insisted on a pool because of the hot summers in Riverside. She protested the size of the pool. It was modeled after the Roman baths but only much larger. He took her chiding quietly. He gently put a hand on her shoulder, "We'll just have to have more children." Smiling. That was some years ago. Seating herself at the table, they all held hands and asked for God's blessings. Demarcation The children were gone now. The last had married and moved out. The house creaked in the dry desert air. He had started coughing in April. "It's nothing... just the dust." He'd grumble and putter about the small building out behind the pool. His place. Tires and metal. A memory shed where he fingered old tools and machinery. It reminded him of when he was more useful. Chores and building. She knew that he was feeling old. His health wilted. She watched him falter. Things no longer were being attended to. They didn't ask for help. It wasn't their way. Pride. The pool water turned black and primitive once the pumps failed. Paint blistered and boards broke. His illness crawled from one long painful month into the next. By the following May, he was gone. She broke shortly after. Her children gathered. Concern. "We need to move her closer to us..." Primitive The old house sat empty. It was rented in rapid succesion. Seasons rumbled past. Years.Â The pool became a dumpster. An old automobile salvage company employee began towing cars to the property. They accumulated. Oil and grease. Sun-faded metal soon took the place of green grass. Everywhere one looked, junk sprouted from the ground. Deterioration. The house quickly became uninhabitable. Neighbors whispered furtively. "Something has to be done." The city moved. The house was dozed and most of the property stripped of its junk. Memories and happiness were long gone. Riverside Ed pulled his car into the dusty driveway and shut the ignition off. He removed his sunglasses. Astonished. The house was completely gone. He had kept his eyes on the property for years. He knew that there was a huge pool at the back of the property but he never could get a look it it. It sat far from the road. He walked along quietly. Insects hummed. A dog barked a few houses away. He saw pool tiles through a broken wall. Standing at the edge of the pool, he could not believe what he was looking at. He raised his camera. Discovery Ed quickly shared his find with a few friends. He pointed out the sheer mass of refuse, stinking black water and heavy junk clearly visible. It hadn't been filled for its intended purpose in decades. There were some signs that it might be pretty good. We decided to drive over together. The deep end was virtually filled with garbage. One could readily see that the face wall appeared to be good. The rest of the pool was anyone's guess. I took my toe and moved the trash and muck aside on the top shallow step. Paddock Pools. We both knew from past experience that Paddock Pools were notoriously good. They had great surfaces that held up. Though it seemed like a gamble, we agreed to give it a try. We could work hard for an entire day and find the bottom cancered, pitted or kinked. To my way of thinking, this was inconsequential. I knew I was going to clean it out as soon as I saw the photograph. It isn't the end result that dictates my happiness, it's the fact that we try. This is what matters most. [caption id="attachment_15155" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Riverside Ed[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15156" align="aligncenter" width="584"] One of the more recognizable things we found. Most defied description.[/caption] Laborous We decided to get into it quickly. Anna, Greg, Ed and I bought gloves and tools and stepped into the pool. Something monstrous was looming. Foul water, garbage and putrid things were everywhere. We cleared away the shallow area first. We wanted to see how the shallow end wall looked. If the deep end was as good as it seemed and the shallow was rideable, we'd be able to flow through the pool pretty well. As we removed debris, I saw intricate hand-painted tiles on the pools shallow floor. "Look at this!" Everyone gathered. We were looking at several porcelain tile fish and a bare-breasted mermaid. They were beautiful and we all were in wonder at how well-preserved they appeared to be. We pondered what other secrets the pool might hold. Once we cleared the shallow end, the sun was waning. Anna, Ed and Greg took a side to side shallow run. Happiness. It boded well. The walls seemed good. [caption id="attachment_15158" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ed and I starting on the deep end.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15161" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ed and Greg taking in the cleared shallow end.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15164" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Anna, Greg and Ed- test turns[/caption] Similar The next day was the same as the last. Filth, sweat and grueling work. Ripperside Shawn came out. He is an old hand at finding, draining and putting in pool work. He drained his first pool as a kid in Riverside. No one showed him anything. He grabbed buckets with his friends, pedaled bikes to a nearby pool and drained it. Â Kevin came out too. He's been in the pool game for many years as well. We pulled possums, spiders, rats, garbage and reeking refuse out until we thought we'd choke. We pumped out black water, oil and broken glass. Eventually, we won. The pool sat empty under the hot sunshine. The crew bought jugs of water for a final rinse. We rolled briefly that waning afternoon. Weary, we carved and smiled. It wasn't easy. The side walls were steep, like life. One had to dig in and push to get to the top. The surface was grippy, like problems. They stuck. It made us work. We made plans for a proper initiation session. [caption id="attachment_15172" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Anna, Kevin and Shawn[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15173" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Life can be draining...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15174" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Finished. Kevin, Shawn and Ed[/caption] Happiness A few days later, MRZ and the entire cleanup crew met up at what we were referring to as the Wagon Wheel pool. John Torchia joined us. We padded up and started trying to figure it out. It was tough work. There were kinks and bellies in the walls and everyone attempted different lines and approaches. It was awesome. [caption id="attachment_15178" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wagon Wheel[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15182" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ripperside Shawn[/caption] Shawn pulled frontside grinds, airs and ruled it. Greg did airs, Anna went over her first backyard pool light, Kevin grinded, Ed pulled wheelers in the deathbox, I fell pretty often and John Torchia pulled airs and grinds. Everyone struggled and everyone was happy. There was no question of it being worth the labor. We were just a couple of friends in love with pool skating. We needed to do what we did in order to be what we are. [caption id="attachment_15185" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kevin[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15186" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Greg Johnson[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15187" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ed- deathbox play[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15188" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Anna- first backyard light[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15189" align="aligncenter" width="584"] John Torchia[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15191" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Where happiness lives[/caption] Thank you to MRZ, AVB and the crew for everything. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Just gnar. That's some hepatitis action right there.
Super good!! Thanks for taking us there.
Great story Ozzie! I remember my first over the light like it was yesterday! Good times! Thanks for keeping me stoked!
Always my favorite read - awesome Ozzie!!
This one pulled me in....I didn't want it to end.
A true labor of love with an appetizing result! Well done boys & girls.
Another awesome tale brother !

You always write what I've wanted to express after many backyard excursions. The wonder of what the place must've been like in its hay day, Was there more joy with a family all swimming with food & family or was there family drama? Turmoil? Maybe a pools hay day really lives in the unencumbered smiles of skateboarders. Maybe both?

item.title: The Sun
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: "The phoenix must burn to emerge." - Â Fitch Once we wandered far. Trudged away from light and life. In the dark, I knew you were there alone and lonely... so darkness I embraced. Stars, heaven and goodness turned their sad faces away. Inky and cold was our road. Life in a holding pattern. You pulled the curtains back on a shadow world and I soon followed. No longer left in the dark. Dawn crept across our broken horizon. Future life. We are startled to have one. Thank you to Lucia Griggi for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_15198" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15199" align="aligncenter" width="584"] me[/caption]

item.title: Bert Lamar
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_15204" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bert Lamar[/caption] Bert Lamar. His name was everywhere in the skateboard magazines of the late 1970's. He was a heavy threat in skateboarding contests of the time. In the words of some, he was, "...a spoiled little brat! A trouble maker." Whatever the case may be, Bert Lamar ripped and did it well. He was a prodigy on the Sims team and he threw it down when he needed to do so. Truth be told.Â History. Bert walked away from skateboarding, made a successful snowboarding company, and now spends his time as a golfing pro. We are pushing forward with the William Sharp Book Project. I have spoken with Brad Bowman, Dennis Martinez, TA, Arthur Viecco, Steve Alba and Shreddi Repas lately. I'm looking forward to speaking with Kevin Worm Anderson, Greg Ayers, Marc Smith and Scott Dunlap. Pineapple, Gunnar, Jay Adams and Micke loom on my horizon. Respect. - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Look a little closer on bottom of deck; clear stick-on rails by the look of it, pretty cool..

Good job!!Team Sims was Cutting edge,But don't forget Frank Blood!!!! Frank ruled upland, Did the biggest air at Hester 2 next Scott Dunlap.The Dave Dominy films clearly show this and so much more. Who needs memory when you have film?......Film does not lie or get fuzzy,The truth is out there!!!!!!!!!!!!Thanks Ozzie for your passion in this sport!!...

Minki ! Bert definitely walked with his head up, but he earned it. Complete shredder with style. If you got to know him as I did you found he was a seriously cool guy. Had a lot of fun together back in the day.

item.title: Arthur Viecco / The Northridge Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Arthur Viecco In the photograph, I am riding the Dupont D Beam trucks and its the first photograph I've seen where I am riding them. They were strange and different. They turned unlike any truck at the time. They were responsive and odd. They grinded really well too. This pool was in Northridge and it was at this pool where Brad Bowman broke his ankle. I think it was dozed shortly after this. The pool was pretty open and the deep end was great. I recall it had a strange transition to the facewall though... not perfectly rounded. Strange feeling.

item.title: Lucia Griggi Weekend Workshop / Europe
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Weekend Photo Workshop/ Destination Europe / Cornwall England Workshop Details Surf Photography Workshop in Newquay, with professional surf photographer Lucia Griggi. Have you ever dreamt of seeing your photography in the pages of one of the worldâs top surf magazines? How about reading your own article in an award-winning travel publication? Well, the time is now. You can get started on your own dream by receiving hands-on surfÂ photography instruction by Lucia. She has the experience and has been published inÂ dozens of magazines and books world-wide. The weekend workshop will take place in south England. Picturesque. Old traditions. Cobblestone streets. Hedgerows. Taverns and farms dating back a hundred years. Cornwall. It is considered the surf capitol of England. Rolling hills wander off into the distance. Cliff faces of granite and stone jut from the green ocean's deep waters. Birds soar above, oblivious to the coming and going of people below. You will capture surfing images in and out of the water.Â You can capture the spirit of southern England and document this ancient land.Â  Requirements Students must bring their own DSLR camera, a laptop with photoÂ software installed, storage media and other equipment (cord, thumbÂ drive, card reader, etc.) for transferring images from camera toÂ computer.Â Overall, these courses are designed for students that can expect toÂ learn what they need to really take their photography to the nextÂ level. They are for beginner to intermediate levels alike.Â If you are an aspiring photographer with a passion for documentingÂ surf, travel and action sports, then this is the course for you. Topics under discussion. -How do I go about submitting photographs to magazines? -How do I know which magazines to submit to and should I submit to multiple titles? -How much do I charge? In this course you will: -Benefit from Luciaâs professional technical guidance. -Focus on surf photography both in and out of the water. -Understand how to edit, image enhance, manage files and presentÂ work to your clients. -Learn about file formats, digital standards, rating your images, manipulatingÂ your files, sharpening, customÂ presets, Photoshop, FTP file transmission, web galleries, retouching, and the business of digital work. -Gain insider tips on selling your work and obtaining commissions. -Develop your own portfolio. -Your investment in equipment, which lenses and camera bodies to buy that are specific to the surf industry. -Rates for the surf industry. -Developing story ideas and interviewing for photojournalism. Requirements for the course Participant must bring up to eight images (jpg, raw or Tiff) of recentÂ work with you on the day of the course for a portfolio review. If you'd like assistance with processing images, bring the raw file and Lucia can help you with it.Â Processed imagery is fine but bring the unedited version along as well.Â We are reviewing applicant work to help you understand your ownÂ photos and how to enhance them for publishing quality. Students must bring their own DSLR camera, a laptop with photo software installed, storage media and other equipment (cord, thumb drive, card reader, etc.) for transferring images from camera to computer. * Students not required to have their own water-housing. A message from Lucia Griggi. âWhen you are shooting in the ocean, your open water knowledgeÂ is as essential as your photographic skills. You quickly realize how insignificant you are with that amount of water movingÂ around you, and the biggest breakthrough comes when you learn to become part of the ocean and work with it, rather than against it.Â I have been lucky enough to shoot in some of the most testing waves in the world, and to be taught by some of the most experiencedÂ watermen." âRunning these courses is my opportunity to pass on this experience and show my students how to be safe in the water, to understand how a wave breaks in different environments both above and below the water, and of course how to be in the right place at the right time for that perfect shot!â Itinerary - Four Days. The following is our planned itinerary. However, our schedule is flexible to allow for spontaneous photographic opportunities. One must always be ready for the unexpected.Â  Day 1 â Thursday / Newquay Settle into our waterfront hotel or stay in accommodations of your choice. Gather on first evening at a restaurant in town for a welcome dinner and orientation. Day 2 â Friday / Fistral Beach / Newquay We will start the day in the classroom with an instructive talk. LuciaÂ will present a presentation aboutÂ work ethic and where the industry is going. Also discussed will be the pros and cons, how theÂ industry is going and the steps to becoming a full time working pro.Â Our first assignment on day one will take us to Fistral Beach where we will begin shooting photographs of professional surfers. Fistral Beach is world famous for its scenic beauty and recognizable surf line, good waves and spectacular sunsets. Students will become aware of the environment they are in. It will be made clear that a photographer must not only get the tight action shots, but the pulled back images and lifestyle surrounding the scene. Â We will end the day with an edit-and-critique session. Day 3 â Saturday / Fistral Beach / Newquay We will start the day with scones, coffee and tea because that is what will be required as we all head out for a guest lecture on water safety. Water safety is important as the tides and currents change dramatically and a surf photographer must understand these things so that they remain safe. We then head out on a morning photography shoot in the waterÂ with a pro surfer. We will cover the techniques of water housing use and their application to surf photography. We will return to the classroom for editingÂ and critique. Afterwards, there will be a guest lecture from one of England's largest surf magazine editors. With this, there will be a Q&A as well. Â A unique opportunity. We then present our best images to the group and enjoy dinner at a local restaurant. (Water surf photography shoot location will depend on current conditions) Day 4 â Sunday / Newquay / Home We will have a leisurely start to our last day together and any final topics or editing can be addressed at this time. This will be the time that we will doÂ Individual portfolio reviews.Â Final classroom session and workshop wrap-up. Costs With Hotel- $2500.00 Without Hotel- $2000.00 Workshop prices are per person. Price with hotel is based on doubleÂ occupancy. For a single room, add $650.00. Â Meals noted in the itineraryÂ are included for both options (with and without hotel)Â Â Attendees are responsible for their own International airfare, travel visas (ifÂ required), insurance, tips and personal spending.Â  DATES Next workshop scheduled: To be confirmed.
Tips.
Parking on site at Fistral Beach is between seven to eight pounds daily. There is free parking at the hotel adjacent to Fistral Beach.Â 
Airports- Newquay is closest and most convenient. Exeter and Bristol are alternates. Taxi and shuttle services available on request.
Cabs##
Shuttle ##
Daytime snacks and lunch is up to the attendees choices. There is a place nearby for quick bites, and the more adventurous could spear fish and provide lunch for the lot of us! The less adventurous can bring a lunch along. There is a bar nearby for sunset libations and cheer.
Clothing. Well, herein is the problem. England is a temperamental lady and one never really knows exactly what one will be getting. Â England has difficult weather at times but this is a plus, as it can provide amazing contrast, clouds and color for surf photography. Bring warm clothing and dry things to change into.
Water attire. Full wetsuit. 4Mil wetsuit suggested. Booties, hood and gloves optional. Swim fins are a must. Snorkel googles are advised. Water housings will be on hand but bring yours if you have one. A towel and swim suit are necessary and bring sunblock.
Activity Rating
Easy
Moderate
Hard
Reservation Form
Map
Download PDF/ Itinerary/ Booking Form
Link tours with University credits
England
-London College Communications
-Falmouth University
-Arts University Bournemouth
-University of Brighton
Photographic Gallery
-Workshop Location
-Past Students Works
Bio
Lucia Griggi has walked the worldÂ as a photographer for over a decade. She has taken photographs in Africa, Asia, Australia, England and the United States. A weary traveler. The sun sinks on her day and lends itself to the other side of the world. Yet, the more she see's, the more she needs. She greets the morning sun like an old friend. Driven. Impassioned. There is always another corner to turn, another moment to capture, another way to view our beautiful world. She always anticipates her next photographic subject and attempts to view it differently, whether its a wave or a portrait. "I have visited a great deal of the world but I havenât seen it all. Â I share these photographs, hoping they will inspire in others what I have found in myself: The desire to travel, have adventures and learn and experience different cultures. All I want to do is see the world and capture it in a way that will encourage others to follow their passions and make their dreams become a reality. Why not join me on my next adventure?"
Testimonials.
Learning about the industry, what state it's in, how you begin to involve yourself in it and much more is simply not knowledge which is usually taught, but (I guess) gained from years of experience. To get someone who is in the industry to tell us how it is in real terms before we start learning ourselves is so valuable, I don't think I would ever take such knowledge for granted.- Robbie Dark Â 13 April 2013
Thanks again for running the course yesterday - I found the whole day really fun and inspiringÂ - from the technical advice to the philosophy behind your photography. It was great to get out and have a go at using the water housing ourselves.Â The variation and pace was spot on - and hearing Louise Searle speak from an editorial perspective was very useful. Just need to save up for some water housing now!- Nina Zietman Â 13 April 2013
I found the whole day with Lucia to be very informative, but above all inspirational. I drove away that evening, chasing my shadow back east to Plymouth, feeling uplifted and more driven than ever to keep pursuing my passion, my photography.- Tom Money Â 13 April 2013

item.title: Lucia Griggi Photographic Expedition / Asia
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Photographic Expedition / Asia / Sri Lanka Workshop Details Wildlife photography expedition with professional photographer Lucia Griggi. Have you ever dreamt of seeing your photographyÂ in the pages of one of the worldâs top Â magazines? How about readingÂ your own article in an award-winning travel publication? Well, the time is now. You can get started on your own dream by receiving hands-on wildlife photography instruction by Lucia. She has the experience and has been published inÂ dozens of magazines and books world-wide. The expedition will take place Â in Sri Lanka. Leopards, crocodiles, monkeys and a thousand other things. Everywhere one looks, there is amazement. "We search for the elusive leopard. We spot a frequented water hole.Â The water is glassy and still and occasionally ruffled by the peeking andÂ peering of crocodiles, below the surface. There is a colorful necklace ofÂ birds around the water hole, fringing the subtle dance of the crocodiles âÂ nervous as ballerinas about to go on stage.Â Nervous and serene is the scene around the waterhole. There seems toÂ be a common agreement among all the animals â a truce in the ladder ofÂ predation â that all are welcome as long as you donât try to eat anotherÂ animal. It is fascinating to watch, but can they all just get along?Â The truce applies to the larger animals, but apparently not the fish in theÂ pond. A bird dives low to snatch a fish and as it wings away, a crocodileÂ snaps and splashes to get its share. This inspires schools of fish to leapÂ in an escape frenzy, and that activates the birds and the crocodile and forÂ a few minutes the water hole is as splashy as a summer camp swimmingÂ pool. A crocodile snaps up a few fish, some leap out of the water awayÂ from the croc into the mouth of a bird.Â The ring of peace is broken by the circle of life." - From Lucia's upcoming article on her Sri Lanka Safari. Yala National Park is a gorgeous, lush and hothouse world of exotic creatures, foliage and experiences. A visit to Sri Lanka is never complete without a tour to a wildlife sanctuary. OfÂ the many wildlife parks in the country, Yala National Park, situated in the deepÂ south of the island, is a must visit. Abundant with wildlife, where the majestic SriÂ Lankan elephant still reigns supreme and the ever elusive leopard, in its gracefulÂ elegance, tip toes its way to a hunt or to quench its taste at its favorite waterÂ hole. Attendees will be led into the wild of Yala National Park with experienced local guides who are familiar with the best locations to find the solitary and elusive animals. Requirements Students must bring their own DSLR camera, a laptop with photoÂ software installed, storage media and other equipment (cord, thumbÂ drive, card reader, etc.) for transferring images from camera toÂ computer.Â Overall, these courses are designed for students that can expect toÂ learn what they need to really take their photography to the nextÂ level. They are for beginner to intermediate levels alike.Â If you are an aspiring photographer with a passion for documenting wildlife and travel, then this is the course for you. Students must bring their own DSLR camera, a laptop with photo software installed, storage media and other equipment (cord, thumb drive, card reader, etc.) for transferring images from camera to computer. * Students not required to have their own water-housing. A message from Lucia Griggi. âWhen you are shooting in the ocean, your open water knowledgeÂ is as essential as your photographic skills. You quickly realize how insignificant you are with that amount of water movingÂ around you, and the biggest breakthrough comes when you learn to become part of the ocean and work with it, rather than against it.Â I have been lucky enough to shoot in some of the most testing waves in the world, and to be taught by some of the most experiencedÂ watermen." âRunning these courses is my opportunity to pass on this experience and show my students how to be safe in the water, to understand how a wave breaks in different environments both above and below the water, and of course how to be in the right place at the right time for that perfect shot!â Itinerary - Nine Days. The following is our planned itinerary. However, our schedule isÂ flexible to allow for spontaneous photographic opportunities. One must always be ready for the unexpected. Day 1 â Day One Arrive on flight to Colombo, Sri Lanka and stay over night in a waterfront hotel there. Meet together and get to know each other. Expedition attendees dinner. Day 2 âDay Two Depart from Colombo, Sri Lanka. Destination- Kandi, a hillside temple retreat located in the cool mountainside. Lunch will be taken there among the trees. Day 3 â Saturday / Fistral Beach / Newquay We will start the day with scones, coffee and tea because that is what will be required as we all head out for a guest lecture on water safety. Water safety is important as the tides and currents change dramatically and a surf photographer must understand these things so that they remain safe. We then head out on a morning photography shoot in the waterÂ with a pro surfer. We will cover the techniques of water housing use and their application to surf photography. We will return to the classroom for editingÂ and critique. Afterwards, there will be a guest lecture from one of England's largest surf magazine editors. With this, there will be a Q&A as well. Â A unique opportunity. We then present our best images to the group and enjoy dinner at a local restaurant. (Water surf photography shoot location will depend on current conditions) Day 4 â Sunday / Newquay / Home We will have a leisurely start to our last day together and any final topics or editing can be addressed at this time. This will be the time that we will doÂ Individual portfolio reviews.Â Final classroom session and workshop wrap-up. Costs With Hotel- $2500.00 Without Hotel- $2000.00 Workshop prices are per person. Price with hotel is based on doubleÂ occupancy. For a single room, add $650.00. Â Meals noted in the itineraryÂ are included for both options (with and without hotel)Â Â Attendees are responsible for their own International airfare, travel visas (ifÂ required), insurance, tips and personal spending. DATES Next workshop scheduled: To be confirmed.
Tips.
Parking on site at Fistral Beach is between seven to eight pounds daily. There is free parking at the hotel adjacent to Fistral Beach.Â 
Airports- Newquay is closest and most convenient. Exeter and Bristol are alternates. Taxi and shuttle services available on request.
Cabs##
Shuttle ##
Daytime snacks and lunch is up to the attendees choices. There is a place nearby for quick bites, and the more adventurous could spear fish and provide lunch for the lot of us! The less adventurous can bring a lunch along. There is a bar nearby for sunset libations and cheer.
Clothing. Well, herein is the problem. England is a temperamental lady and one never really knows exactly what one will be getting. Â England has difficult weather at times but this is a plus, as it can provide amazing contrast, clouds and color for surf photography. Bring warm clothing and dry things to change into.
