item.title: Alessandro
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I climbed as icy wind bit at my lungs. My boots were worn and the wool clothing threadbare. I had been walking from India for five weeks. The ice fields of Nepal were inhuman and uninhabitable. I was the only living thing moving slowly up the snow and frozen ground. Granite outcroppings sprouted from the peak above me. I craned my neck and took in the spectacle. Dizzying. Ancient. The sun glittered through the clouds and reflected like a billion diamonds around me. My eyes ached and my chest heaved. I dug in my ice axe and pulled up over another stone bluff. I was enroute to the ancient forbidden city of Lhasa. I was going to sneak in to the Potala palace, once home of the Dalai Lama. I was going in at night. I wanted to remain stealth and secrecy. My wish is to climb the colossal towers and ramparts of the ancient stone citadel and photograph the residents of the old city moving through their morning.

item.title: Scorpion Bay
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Baja California Sur. The tiny villages spill over the hillsides in dirty clumps. Brightly colored walls starkly shadow the poverty seen in every direction. People have less than nothing. I see a man defecating in the grass of a vacant lot. A small brown dirty-faced boy smiles and waves from a blue cloud of bus exhaust fumes. I can't hear his call for a peso in the confines of our air-conditioned, comfortably appointed American automobile. I don't feel too good at the moment. I think of the leftover dinner I threw into the trash last night and the thirty dollars I wasted at a skateboard shop. That could've gone far on this day... in this town. I wince at the naked reality of the destitution and lawlessness spread out in front of us. Every town. Every night. Crime seems to ooze through the villages like a leprous thing. Hard-eyed men watch us hungrily. We push south in a caravan. Tony Alva and Brian Logan lead on point, as Lucia Griggi and I follow. We pass broken homes, tiny hamlets and Catholicism. Churches seem ubiquitous yet to my thinking, God has left his post. I hope he is paying attention. Dry hillsides, bristling cactus and dirt clouds were a constant reminder that we were pushing further and further from our homes. Scorpion Bay waited for us. On arrival, Tony Alva quickly led the fray into the lineup. Perfect rights peeled open like glass zippers. He stabbed deep into a pocket and blew through for a long, four minute ride halfway down the bay. Lucia stepped in and stepped up. Style and grace. We've been in the water several times already today and last night was cool and quiet. I woke just before sunup. The sea hissed a few feet from the tents. The ocean was purple and malevolent. An uncaring master. I stood on the cliff above it and closed my eyes... Â I felt like the last human on earth. Dawn slowly bled all over me... light and peace. Thanks to Lucia Griggi for the images. Skate... Â and surf. - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Get back safe. Wish I was there. Its not so bad.

item.title: looking for sunlight
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Sometimes, we are like the blind, looking for sunlight. We wouldn't know it if we stumbled upon it. The search for meaning. Scorpion Bay. The days start overcast and damp. Not much moves faster than a stand still. Time doesn't exist. In the moment. We live for one reason. To get in and become one with the ocean. The surf rolls in and spreads across the bay in long undulating lines... crystal perfection. Lucia, Brian and Tony spent a fair amount of yesterday in the water. I think we were all in at least three times. Today, everything was bright and the sun hurt my eyes. This morning, I was first in the water followed shortly after by TA. For awhile, we had the point to ourselves.

item.title: looking for sunlight
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Sometimes, we are like the blind, looking for sunlight. We wouldn't know it if we stumbled upon it. The search for meaning. Scorpion Bay. The days start overcast and damp. Not much moves faster than a stand still. Time doesn't exist. In the moment. We live for one reason. To get in and become one with the ocean. The surf rolls in and spreads across the bay in long undulating lines... crystal perfection. [caption id="attachment_15445" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brian[/caption] Lucia, Brian and Tony spent a fair amount of yesterday in the water. I think we were all in at least three times. Lucia rode some super long waves across the bay as did Brian. TA held third point most of the morning virtually alone and blasted some quick rides down the line. [caption id="attachment_15444" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brian[/caption] This morning, I was first in the water followed shortly after by TA. For awhile, we had the point to ourselves. I paddled hard and caught a few, stood up and fell. I moved further outside. I saw TA way out... paddling. One big wave grew dark and rolled toward me. It spilled across nearby and broke. I turned and paddled, was picked up and stood on it. I officially rode my first wave. [caption id="attachment_15449" align="aligncenter" width="584"] TA[/caption] TA blew past me, trimming down the line. We came into camp afterwards and spent a quiet breakfast in camp as the sunlight slowly warmed our backs. Thank you to Lucia for the images. Skate... and surf. Â Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It's said in the surf world " you shoulda been here" appears to be true
Stoked! Your writing applied to another substrate is just as poetically appropriate & appealing. Surprised PK hadn't forced the ocean & element of water on you before.

hahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha I can't tell you how MUCH i'd like to be there with you, for now I'll just read and look and not try and hold it against you! hahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha
Stoked for you, Ozzie. I will hit the road and head for the Basque Country in just a couple of hours. Waves and pools....can`t wait. Markus

item.title: Easy Jet
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
1-Who else do you shoot for?

LG- I shoot commercial advertising & editorial for mainstream travel & tourism clients specializing in surf & water-based imagery. I love shooting portraits and lifestyle near the water and high end action of surfers performing. Some of my clients include: National Geographic, GQ, Time, Sri Lanka Airlines, Air Pacific, Rip Curl and Quiksilver.

2- How did you get into your occupation?

LG- I developed my passion for surf and photography by doing both things myself. I started documenting my travels from New Zealand to Morocco. People began to notice my images and I started selling from there.

3- How did you develop teaching the photography clinics?

LG- I'm self taught and learned on my own and by my mistakes. I just developed my eye as I went. I'm a woman in a male-dominated industry so as I became more adept, I saw that I could give back to the community and help others with my experiences. I just think that there is room and a need to come in and do these type of clinics.

4- Favorite thing about the work?

LG- I travel to some of the most obscure, remote and gorgeous places on the planet for my work and assignments. I probably wouldn't have ever visited half of them where it not for my profession. I get to meet beautiful people and visit different cultures which keeps me very open minded.

5- Favorite cocktail?

LG- When I travel, I take granola and yogurt when I can. That is my cocktail of choice... Â though sometimes a Mojito can take the edge off.

item.title: Lensbaby
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
1- When & how did you first discover your passion for photography?
LG-Â Â I developed my passion for surf and photography by doing both things myself. I started documenting my travels from New Zealand to Morocco. People began to notice my images and I started selling from there.
2- Where did you first learn about Lensbaby? What was your first Lensbaby lens, and what lens or optic is currently your favorite?
What is your favorite Lensbaby image (or, top 2-3 if you can't pick just one!)
LG- I'd always see people shooting with them and I was intrigued. On a road trip for a book publishing company, from the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State to San Diego recently, I met up with Keith in Portland. I was fascinated by the lenses. He lent me some and I fell in love immediately with Â them. My current favorites are the soft focus and the Edge 80. I took one up to the Smith river in Oregon. It was pouring rain. Overcast. Storm clouds and bleakness was all around. I shot down the river and between the mist, rain and the soft focus lens, the shot came out very moody and surreal.
3- How often do you use Lensbaby in your professional client work? How do your clients tend to feel about the Lensbaby images vs the straight lens images?
LG- I use the Lens Baby lenses in my editorial work and in Â my travel, surf and skate pieces. I use the Edge 80 most often in those environments. Clients are really impressed with the results of the lenses. The images are very different and fascinating. They always say. "Keep shooting and providing these images."
4- You recently served as an expedition photographer on a winter adventure to photograph famous surfers â can you tell us a bit about that experience?
LG- From January 15-February 4th, I traveled from virtually the Canadian border and all the way down to San Diego to shoot some incredible surfing portraits. Gerry Lopez, Bruce Brown and Greg Knoll are some of the surfers. We accumulated over 7000 images and spent 3000$ on gas, food and lodging. I was so impressed with the lenses that I shot virtually all my portraits with the soft focus and Edge 80. Between the phenomenal landscape, national parks, the lenses and shooting, it was a trip to remember.
5- You just returned from a trip to Mexico where you photographed more surfers and some skateboarders. What was that trip like? Did you shoot many Lensbaby images?
LG- Well, I enjoy shooting skateboarding with the Edge 80 lens as skaters usually hit one part of the lip so I can set my focal point and obtain a quality image. There is a manmade concrete bowl in a surfers backyard down in Baja Mexico. Tony Alva and Ozzie went over a rode it. It is a very private place and no photographers have been allowed to shoot there. The owners gave me permission and the images are awesome. Â We also went to the school of a talented female surfer who is a schoolteacher by trade. We were in her third grade class and I took portraits and lifestyle images. Â I used the soft focus lens. It is great for inside with ambient light and no direct sunlight. It gives a nice skin tone especially when shooting portraits or lifestyle.
6-Any tips for photographers new to Lensbaby, manual focus, etc?
LG- When using soft focus lens, it is good to use in flat light where there is no contrast or direct sunlight. It is great for giving atmosphere. This lens gives a film like look to the images. With the Edge 80, Its really beautiful and gives great results as well. Set focus on the subject, know where you want the focal point to be as its a small margin.

item.title: Seven Points
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: San Diego, California. 1992. Roberta looked up into the rearview mirror just in time to see the car behind her approaching far too fast. Momentary panic. A crunch of metal and a shudder ripped through the automobile as she was struck hard from behind and pushed into a guardrail. Shock... Â she moved her legs and hands. Inventory. Intact. People drifted off the sidewalks and approached, calling out. She was helped from the car. Her neck hurt. She glanced back and couldn't believe how the cars appeared. Buckled. A woman was being helped from hers and she was sobbing. There was a man in hospital scrubs nearby and was walking quickly towards them. He said that he was a doctor. Once the ambulance came and checked them over, he gave Roberta a business card. Dr. William Hollis. Doctor of Chiropractic Medicine. The next day, Roberta woke up and felt like a misused toy. She couldn't believe how terrible her neck hurt. A visit to Doctor Hollis' office was set up. X-rays. Roberta noticed a small shadow on the XR and asked the doctor. He dismissed her concerns and set her up to manipulate and adjust her spine. She felt him push on either side of her neck... she tried to relax. It burned. Then she felt a stabbing pain as he squeezed. Burning moved down her arm. In the end, the doctor had overlooked a hairline fracture and ended up fully fracturing her C2- C3 vertebrae. Roberta suffered. Loss of feeling. Vision problems. A bleak medical outlook. Surgical intervention was planned and she was told that it would be a long recovery. Minimal physical activities. Rehabilitation. Pain. Roberta would wear a Halo around her head for four months. It would help the bone fuse in her spine. She would suffer and be told by the medical profession that she wouldn't be able to do any aggressive activities at all. About five years later, Roberta decided to try surfing. She watched surfers nearby and it looked fun. Her doctors told her it was inadvisable. She ignored the advice and began her journey. It continues to this day. Baja, California Roberta and Glen drove down the dusty rode into San Juanico. The wind pushed hard against the old truck. He turned the wheel hard and eased the truck slowly over a sandy ridge. The truck growled and pulled them forward. She smiled. Roberta had met Glen in Baja after she had learned to surf. He was a long time Baja surfing legend and was known everywhere. They met and became inseparable. As a couple, they traveled frequently and he always encouraged her surfing. He felt that it helped her overcome her physical accident and it kept her strong and soulful. They crested a ridge and stopped. Scorpion Bay spread out in front of them like a treasured thing. White waves peeled back in perfect undulating waves. A blue sky beckoned. The sun glittered wetly. Priceless. Driving closer to the third point, cars and trucks dotted the edges. Surfboards sprouted from truck beds and people smiled and waved. Glen stopped the truck as a familiar face approached. "Myra. Hello there..." Myra was a local school teacher who learned to surf about five years ago. A resident of Scorpion Bay, she had become quite talented. They were happy to see each other. Myra smiled in greeting and told both of them how the point was looking. "The tide is coming up high, so I'm going to wait for an hour or so until the waves become more punchy." Glen nodded and peered toward the sea. "We'll see you out there, Myra." Setting up nearby, Glen and Roberta spotted other friends. Roberta commented to Glen how many female surfers were around lately. Sophie - an antique dealer - from Santa Barbara, was waxing her board nearby. Roberta knew that she came down frequently and was a great longboarder. Sophie could walk the board better than most. Watching the sets come in, Glen pointed out Jamie. Her husband David was nearby on the beach with their little daughter. Jamie and David spent a good bit of time at Scorpion Bay. They were frequent fliers. They both remarked how it was so good to see so many of the ladies together. They didn't see this very often. The next day, Roberta paddled out to the point. Lucia Griggi was there, Jamie and local female surfer Brittney were out as well. They were all bobbing in the sea waiting on the set waves. They spoke about the swell, board choices and how cool it was to be out in the sea. Sophie paddled up a bit later. Lucia made the comment that

item.title: Monotony
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: One would think that I'd feel monotony here. Day in, day out. No clocks. No time. The deep ocean ruling all things. We follow the sea and its mandate. It tells us how we will spend our day. In this place and time, it is not difficult to feel puny. [caption id="attachment_15475" align="aligncenter" width="584"] the hard way[/caption] I feel so small and think of the problems of life. They cannot be escaped. Trying to escape from our problems really is no escape at all. It's only window shopping. In this place, there is no monotony. I am forced to look at myself. I learn the hard way. My fears, longing and the wretched, petty creature that I sometimes am. I learn to live with the sea... and with me. Thank you to Lucia Griggi for the images. Skate... and surf. Â Ozzie [caption id="attachment_15476" align="aligncenter" width="584"] TA[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: the ocean teaches
Mono Tony #1

Ozzie, I've been reading your blog for about a year! Well Done! Skater since 76' happy joyous & free since 96', just trudging that happy road. You keep me inspired to skate. Hit a ditch yesterday . Also very jealous of the surf camping trip your on with tony! Been surfing for about 5 years Peace John Jacob

item.title: Seven Points and Seven Sisters
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The road south had been a treacherous one. Dust and dirt. Heat. The long way. I drove down from San Diego into Baja California. I was on an assignment to shoot skateboarding legend Tony Alva, as he was making a surf trip to Scorpion Bay. The place was situated perfectly. Seven points jutted from the rugged Baja coast at varying intervals in fairly close proximity. This created a perfect situation for waves to line up with the different points given the particular swell. It is rumored that during larger swells, people come down to, "...connect." On arrival, the bay spread out before me like a treasured thing.Â White waves peeled back in perfect undulating waves. A blue sky beckoned. The sun glittered wetly. Priceless. Driving closer to the third point, cars and trucks dotted the edges. Surfboards sprouted from truck beds and people smiled and waved. I felt at home and at peace immediately. These were my kind of people. I spotted several female surfers clad in black neoprene and carrying boards. These weren't the usual surfers girlfriends. These women could ride. Setting up camp on the bluff overlooking the second point, I watched the first evening session. The waves were perfectly formed rights that lazily rolled across the bay in the same manner virtually each and every set. It was hypnotic. I watched as three girl surfers paddled into the waves and rode all the way in. One rode a long board and another rode a strange looking board I'd never seen before. It appeared homeade.
The next day, I had the opportunity to meet several of the girls. I paddled out to the point and rode a few waves in. On my return to the outside, I was struck by something. When I looked around, it was only women in the water. We started laughing. There were seven of us. No men. We were sitting there bobbing in the water talking about board choices, shapers, the swell and our morning so far. I commented on the fact that I'd surfed all around the world and I couldn't recall there ever being a time when I surfed with seven women at once. I would come to know the girls and the story of how they all came to Scorpion Bay. Night. The wind pushed hard against the uncommon dark. Here, there are only stars and blackness. Inky. We wandered to a nearby camp. There were several of the girls nearby. Sitting. Together. I heard laughter rising up like smoke. Sophie was introduced to me. I had seen her in the water earlier. She smiled. Perfect teeth. "Hi. Today was pretty cool..." I nodded. It was. Sophie continued. "It was pretty neat being out there with only women. The waves were coming in so good..." Some of the girls nodded. I saw Jamie from Redondo Beach, Myra, a local school teacher and resident of Scorpion Bay and Baja regular, Roberta. I was in good company. We laughed and had some food. Myra was talking about her start in surfing five years past. "I started on a six foot, four inch board and rode that as a beginner for five months, then a friend gave me an eight foot long board. I was scared at first but I kept at it. I started surfing with my cousin and another girl from here. This is our home" Myra pushed her hair with a long index finger and quietly added, "This is a perfect wave."
I was surprised at first by the ability of these particular women. All were very good and all seemed so peaceful. Their ages varied as did their occupations. Sophie was an antique dealer from Santa Barbara. She walked her board better than most. I asked her about how she started surfing and what brought her to Scorpion Bay. "I started eight years ago in Santa Barbara. I come to Scorpion Bay about twice a year. I'd heard about it from the Thomas Campbell movies and first visited on a trip with my friend Joel and his son Tony. It was about four years ago. Surfing with the others today was cool. Everyone is mellow and respectful. Scorpion Bay is really good.Â .. Â this wave cannot be beat." We talked into the night. The ocean waves muttered down below on the rocks. It soon lulled us into a sleepy mode and we dreamt of tomorrow. Morning dawned. Fog wrapped itself around the bay like an old wool blanket. The suns warmth was needed. Cold waves pushed toward land in a peculiar rhythm all their own. I took out a nine foot Takayama long board and headed toward the point. Dolphins arched out of the water nearby and I lay still on my board, watching.
Outside, I saw Roberta, a Baja regular. We surfed together for over an hour. She spoke of her trips down here to Scorpion Bay over the years with her husband Glen. They were Baja mainstays. Roberta invited me over for a light lunch after surfing. I graciously accepted. Roberta and Glen made an interesting pair. They met in Baja and were married. They travel between Baja and San Diego throughout the year. They run, surf and complete each other's puzzles. Union. Perfection and fit. Their home is a dream house built for two. Three hundred palm trees circle the property like a tropical bastion. They screen the sun and wind in a rustling, tropical green canopy. It makes an entirely idyllic sound. Whale bones, shells, cactus and other native plants are everywhere. Glen is quite the innovative craftsman. He is building the home. It resembles the tree house in the Disney film Swiss Family Robinson. Outdoor showers of bamboo, fabricated walls and stairs resembling tree branches, inlaid woods and veneers... Â its a work of art. I am led about the place and stand in awe.
On the gravel enclosure is a huge four wheel drive old panel truck from the 1950's. Glen has turned it into a surf commando vehicle complete with surf racks, cupboards and tables, queen sized bed in the loft and huge sand gripping suspension and tires. It is known throughout the entire region of Baja. We completed the walkthrough as Roberta continued with the story of her surfing journey. "In 1993, I was injured in an automobile accident. I fractured my neck. I had the surgery and the physicians said I wouldn't be able to do anything strenuous again without risks. After my surgery, I was watching surfers one day. It had been five years since my injury. I wanted to learn to surf and I did. It was the best thing I ever did for myself. I now run daily and surf as much as possible. It keeps me strong and healthy." I nodded in agreement with Roberta. Surfing sure worked that way for me. Sometimes, I shoot photographs so much that I don't have the opportunity to surf as often as I'd like. I definitely notice its absence in my life. We headed back over to Scorpion Bay. The sun was waning. On the bluff we sat and watched some of the ladies surfing.
Jamie is a stylish surfer from Redondo Beach, California. She's been surfing fourteen years. She joined us on the bluff after her session and toweling off, she told me about her initiation into this life we lead. "I traveled often when I worked in the music industry. I caught the surf bug and a friend and I traveled around the world for four months. Baja. Australia. Fiji. Then in 2005, I went to the east coast of Australia for two months. All I did was surf. I got laughed at by the locals and stayed in the water six hours a day. It helped. I really learned. Around 2007, I was in Redondo Beach and my friend Â Baja Mark mentioned Scorpion Bay. I managed to tag along on the next trip down. It was the best wave ever. Once I met my husband David, I found out that he'd been coming here for years, we started making regular visits. We both prefer long, peeling right soft bottom waves..." I had to agree. If this was what they both wanted, Scorpion Bay wouldn't disappoint. It truly was an epic wave. Sitting on some beach chairs, the sun was dropping quickly as evening fell. The wind picked up and licked at our clothing. We saw a long blonde haired local girl on a homeade board. She had a low slung retro style that couldn't be missed. We stood and watched her rip a set wave all the way across the bay and in the moment, we were all one.

item.title: swell
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I now understand. I listen and learn. The ocean chuckles away on the rocks below our campsite at the trivialities of mankind. It spreads out and whispers in a dark green wavering voice. It knows - in some strange way - that it is humanity that has lost touch with itself. Fewer farms. Less time. More money and greed. People no longer feel the cycle of the earth and become one with it. Removed. Isolation and defensive barricades. Our minds are burdened by a billion damaging distractions. The line must be kept very thin... The swell arrived. The ocean humbles us, whether we like it or not. We leave for the U.S. on Thursday morning. I feel like throwing my laptop and cell phone in the ocean and not returning... Thanks to Lucia for the images. - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: mahalo for sharing your trip Ozzie. Aloha, Michael
father ocean teaches
Rad, check out the dogs / watching the action
Good photos!! and sammy was here!!

item.title: revealed
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_15502" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Evandro Mancha Menezes[/caption] Two days of driving. Desolation. Decay. Old stones and older beliefs. We drove north. All the things that I thought were true, were not. Discovery and revelation. Friendship doesn't really exist sometimes. It is only use and misuse. Dirty town. I've been in this place before. A lonely parade cavorts at the border. They try and sell the same useless things.Â The fences fell behind us as we crossed into the United States. Arriving in San Marcos at Jonathan's, he asked about my trip. Words were like stones in my throat. I held my tongue. There is a long shadow on the sun. [caption id="attachment_15503" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jonathan Spooner[/caption] We drove to Mancha's vert ramp. Leo, Mancha and Jonathan rode. I sat on the deck and took photographs. Content. Relief washed over me in an awesome way. Real people. Revealed. Dusk poured over us. The shadows were a welcome sight. It's enough that I am waiting in the dark... Â Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_15504" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Leo Ruiz[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Glad you all made it back safe. And right back into the swing of sk8.
Long drive huh? That was a while. Nice lip slide Spooner!
Hi Oz, We half way to Scorps!
Have a rad time. Big love to You and TA - Ozzie

item.title: The Nude Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_15509" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Andy Macdonald[/caption]
I visited Andy Macdonald in San Diego, back in 1993. I flew in for an ASR tradeshow from Woodward skate camp in Pennsylvania. Andy happily informed me that we would be driving out by Joshua Tree that very night. It seems that it was Dave Reuls birthday and there was going to be a party. I nodded my assent and off we went. The dirt road up to the slab, was rutted and broken. Cactus and sage brush covered everything. Trash billowed out beside the car and discarded beer cans were ubiquitous. We crawled up the dirt track, careful not to bottom out.
[caption id="attachment_15510" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Doug Kinkade[/caption]

We arrived at the concrete slab. It was right below the hotel remains and it was overflowing with trucks, cars and people. Everywhere that I looked, there were people sitting on sleeping bags, smoking, drinking & laughing. It was unreal. We got our gear out and headed up a short path to where we could see lights. A generator growled somewhere in the distance close by. We stepped up onto the deck. A huge kidney pool was spread out before us with at least thirty skaters milling about the decks and shallow end.

[caption id="attachment_15511" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Duane Peters[/caption]

Graffiti was splashed and scrawled upon-virtually-every surface, in every color. Â Most of it was unintelligible, but one that caught my eye and has remained with me over the years, was located on the hip just inside the coping. It said, "Friendships never die at the nude." The old nudist hotel building was a pale shadow if its former self. It rose gaunt and skeletal above the pool and squatted obscenely in the waning light. I could smell weed burning and happy faces greeted my roving eyes.

This was Â Mecca! I watched Dave Reul- hair dyed blue-push into the pool and frontside 50-50 the entire face wall. I watched Andy frontside blunt, then follow it up with a front rock near the hip. I saw people I can barely remember doing insane things I will never forget. I hadn't seen anything like it... anywhere. A cute girl walked up to me and offered me a beer. I waved her away and started skating.

[caption id="attachment_15512" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Nude Bowl dig out of 1999[/caption]

Twister pulled a sick frontside grind, Rhino crailed the side wall, and Jonathan 'Bacon' Hobbs made a sick frontside air, which was greeted by howls from those watching. It was sick! We skated for hours and hours. People came and went, moves were pulled, girls were discovered, friendships and love were made. The deep night faded into half light. Dawn glowed in the distance. I watched the sun come up over the Nude bowl that morning and I will remember it my whole life.

The Nude is gone now. Someone was stabbed at a party out there in the late 1990s. It wasn't a skater that performed such a heinous act. It was a scumbag wanna-be punk. His stupidity lost us one of the great gathering places for skateboarders everywhere. Remember the Nude bowl. Thanks Andy Mac, JGrant Brittain & Doug Kinkade for the images. Skate-Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Nice pics. I also feel that place was epic. Many great memories. I was so amped to skate those late night parties. How did I do front side airs with that much beer in my system?!
RIP nude, you had a good run. Nice memorial to a troop of many tours of duty. Thanks Ozzie.

item.title: nothing is enough
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
She walked through Macy's department store. She carried several bags to her expensive automobile. Trunk. Filled. Walking back inside the cool confines of the Macy's, she admired her reflection in a passing window. She never tired of her own adoration. Loveliness. Only on the outside. Shop windows. Mannequins looking bent and depressed. Tired clothing and wrapping paper. Tinsel. Lace. Lies. She was still browsing. It wasn't her money she was spending. He didn't care. He'd climb on top of her once a week and rut feverishly. Sleep took him quickly after. The new romantic American man. Leaving at the end of the day, she thought that she might need to plan a Spa day. She had far too much stress to deal with... A huge hole festered in her heart. Absence. Feelings. She once felt that gorgeous sickness called "Love". Â Life then called. Reality wasn't what the poets said it would be... Â he cheated and she never felt anything again. Nothing was ever enough.
Scott Ward
He had lost everything. The great divide. A chasm of misery had opened up and devoured. It chewed through his past and then it swallowed all he'd ever be. Alcohol became his panacea. Nights. No dawn. No day. A long blurry run of faces and flesh. It was his turn to be the misery... Â devouring. He was teeth and talons. His soul became sick. What he had left to give anyone was soon gone. He now stood in the shallow end of the pool. His old friends welcomed him back. It had been a long time. He smiled and pushed down into the waterfall. He had nothing... and it was enough. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: amen!
EPIC..

I am that guy. Alcohol took over my life for nearly a decade. I stopped surfing and skating. When I got into the program; I realized the program lacked something. Something was missing. I bought a sufboard, a wetsuit and a skateboard. I began to take back what I had let myself bury beneath layers of misery, anxiety and fear. I still go to meetings every now and then, but there is not much of an open skate culture where I live. I am glad to see posts like this. It makes me feel good to know that even though I am alone where I live, I am not alone in this life.
Health before money.

item.title: we know that you lost your way
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Disillusioned. Oh, sorry humanity. Their voices. AÂ blaring trumpet that shrilly shrieks. Empty and hollow. "Look at me. Look at me." They join panels and committee's just to stand on any stage.

item.title: the thing we are looking for
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_15525" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me at Ridiculous[/caption]
We start out unknowing. Our eyes are wide open and sparkling. Filled with all that is new and unexplainable. A slave to each new taste and sensation. We revel in life... The dark of the world is held at bay by the light of our youth. Neon night and sun-splashed afternoons. The curl of a glassy wave, white pool plaster spangled with shadows, the smell of the good smoke rising up, young girls with copper skin, night fires with pretty faces, pleasure that never seems to end. Years prowl by, friends are gone and we shake our heads in wonder. "Where the hell did they get to? What happened to me...?!" Most of what we had in store for ourselves didn't come to fruition. The lonely parade. The nights are still golden but tinged with tiredness and regret. The pretty faces are older and haggard. We look at ourselves in the mirror -- only briefly-- and say, "I'm getting too old for this." We find justification. We reinvent the language of our youth. Excuses. Platitudes. This thing we are looking for... It is a ghost. Absence. One day we awaken. We see a trampled path. The sun is a cold orb that cannot bring us happiness. The beaches and surf are dull, crowded and flat. The pretty faces of our youth became wrinkled and repellent. We find that we have the emotions of a reptile. "How did it become so damned dark?" The thing we are looking for... Gratitude is the answer. Thanks to Brian Fick for the image.Â Skate and be grateful.- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Youth is happy because it has the capacity to see beauty. Anyone who keeps the ability to see beauty never grows old. Franz Kafka
truth... :)

item.title: Canvas
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: ABOUT At Canvas, we saw that there was something missing in current skateboard deck choices. The same graphics, colors and ideas were being reintroduced over and over again. We decided to do something about it. Every skateboarder is an individual with personal likes, goals and abilities. Everyone is great at something. Why be clones of each other? At Canvas, we want to see skateboarders ride what they choose to ride. Embrace your individuality. Differences are good. Be yourself. With the Canvas Skateboard site, you can design your own graphic, color choices, upload a favorite image and create a skateboard and a look that is perfectly your own. Give it a try. Fool around and design a few decks. It's free. If you like the design, buy the deck from Canvas. We make our decks with American maple in San Diego, California. Our boards are super durable and will punch the crap out of that Chinese and Mexican junk everyone else is pawning off on you. We'll even throw in the grip tape... can't beat that, can you? Get on board. Get busy. Show that you are unique. Canvas Skateboards.

item.title: the promise
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Her hair was piled up silky and dark. It spilled over her shoulders. Her red lips curled like flame and her mouth hinted at the promise of more than words. I glanced at her eyes. They were like wet jewels. Her walk was a mockery itself... I looked away lest I succumb to her charms. I pushed hard with my foot and my skateboard moved me past her on the sidewalk and rapidly away from my weakness. Further down the street, a boarded-up house greeted my roving eyes. The sun-baked, curling edge of a pool slide jutted above the concrete edge of the property. It was a beacon. Salvation found within. I hopped the wall. It was perfection. It glittered like a thieves dreams. It was a Blue Haven. It offered up endless possibilities and promise. The Blue Haven lady would take only what I could give and never concerned herself with trivialities and always needing more. Â Decision? I hesitated not one moment. I plunged right in. A perfect marriage. Thanks to Brandon Wong for everything. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Leo Ruiz
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_15559" align="aligncenter" width="576"] Leo Ruiz- Method air[/caption] I was skating at my friend Evandro Mancha Menezes' vert ramp in San Diego awhile back. Mancha is one of those rare souls. Happy. Open and honest. He listens when you converse with him. He had a friend of his from Brazil there with us that day. His name is Leo Ruiz. Like Mancha, Leo is a rare soul as well. Good people. We all laughed and skated away through the afternoon. Leo skated extremely well. Huge airs, flip tricks and 540's poured from him like water... it was inspiring. Leo rarely stops smiling. I find this to be a good human quality. We talked afterwards and have skated together on numerous occasions since that day. Leo is a complete ripper and I've started flowing him Blue Tile Obsession boards to help him and keep quality decks under his capable feet. I thank him here and now for riding Â them and most of all, I thank him for being a super cool person. Thank you to Brian Fick for the image. Skate - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you for the article brotha!!
Thank you for all bro!
That's a good looking board under his feet.

item.title: Hester Series / Spring Valley / Dennis Martinez
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_15563" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Dennis Martinez- stoop so low, to reach so high.[/caption]
Dennis Martinez
"Like all hometown parks, certain people get aquatinted with their parks and terrain.
Spring Valley, San Diego, Â was the first park to have a real swimming pool. It was designed after the famous SDSU Soul Bowl. We rode that park and that pool, day and night. We knew every line, kink and flaw.Â When the Hester pro bowl came up, the San Diego boys had the advantage. Well, Â that's what we thought. Great skaters can skate anything and many great skaters came down and ripped. Most of my friends thought that I stood a good chance at winning or placing really well. Â As the competition started, the skating got gnarly. I was doing very well, Â but I smoked and got too high. I lost it on a big frontside speed carve into a high frontside air. I hooked up in the deep end and I totally thought I had it. I fell straight to the bottom on my head.Â I was taken to the hospital with aÂ bad concussion and was unable to finish. Even though I couldn't finish, I still made top ten, so that lets you know I was doing pretty good. After losing and seeing Steve Alba as the winner I yelled out - Â "I want a rematch".Â For the record - EVERYONE RIPPED and Salba deserved to win. Needless to say,Â I was disappointed." - Dennis Martinez
Thank you Dennis and thanks to Glen E. Friedman for the image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The T in the upper right hand corner is still there. Freeway where the park used to be.
Dennis Martinez really is an awesome skater but he's MORE awesome now helping others that are less fortunate than we all are. You rock, Dennis!

item.title: Lasekland
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_15573" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bucky Lasek[/caption] A gleaming sun. Palm trees. Crowded decks. Bucky Lasek's home sits out in the middle of the countryside. The neighborhood is affluent. Rolling hills and fenced estates. MRZ, Christian and I drive the meandering road that leads to his house. I look around in the midday sun. Horse stables sit in the middle distance before a long row of trees. A white fence wraps around the nearby property. Enclosed. Privacy. Colorful bougainvillea obscure the horse corral at the edge of the field. Contentment resides among the well-manicured lawns and shading trees. We drive past... [caption id="attachment_15574" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lasekland[/caption] Bucky graciously has a BBQ and bowl session after the Clash at Claremont. He does this for the athletes and friends that give so much to Grind for Life. Bucky gives back. Sponsors provide delicious food and drinks. There are plenty of beverages, as skating the huge bowl is thirsty work. The crew gathers. It is a crowded, milling deck of lawn chairs, comfortable over-stuffed deck furniture, umbrellas and families. Pro skaters, friends and children all spill out across the property. Skateboarding takes center stage. It isn't the skateboarding of the XGames. It isn't the skateboarding of the professional. It isn't a powerful display of vertical prowess. The skateboarding on this day centers around one thing only. Fun. [caption id="attachment_15578" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mike Rogers[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15579" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Scott Foss[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15590" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mixmaster Mike and Bucky[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15580" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kiko[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15591" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bucky & Dave Tuck[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15582" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Daniel Cuervo[/caption] The bowl at Bucky's is a canyon. There are some that ride and some that watch. I watched and took notes. Mike Owen, Paul Wisniewski, Mike Rogers, Owen Neider, Bucky, Daniel Cuervo, Scott Foss, Dan Sparagna, Adam Taylor, Kiko, Cam Dowse, Darren Jenkins, Tony Mag and a heavy crew of others, were putting it all on the line. Mixmaster Mike was spinning hard, music pulsed, happiness prevailed and another dream was fulfilled. Thanks to Bucky, BULL TACO, ROCKSTAR, GRIND FOR LIFE, MOVIE TICKETS,Â PUMAÂ and thank you to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_15584" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mike Owen[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15585" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Owen Neider[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15587" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Paul Wisniewski[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That was without a doubt one of the best times I've ever had, skating or otherwise, a dream come true really. Thanks Bucky, Chris Conway and everyone else involved . . . skaters rule !!
I like Mike Rogers fs grind and Kiko kills it. Kiko is my new favorite skater.

item.title: Cindy Whitehead
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Cindy Whitehead. Southern California born and bred. She took the skateboarding world by storm in the late 1970's with her brash style and technicality. Cindy was one of the only women ever to be featured riding vertical in the centerfold of a skateboarding magazine. In the male-dominated, testosterone-fueled world of vertical skateboarding, Cindy stood out. Impact. She began skateboarding in Hermosa Beach by riding freestyle at the pier. She quickly switched over to vertical and progressed rapidly, becoming a mainstay in the women's vertical skateboarding scene. At sixteen years of age, Cindy became one of the first female professional skateboarders and was sponsored byÂ Tracker Trucks, Sims Skateboards, Puma Tennis Shoes, Rector and Fly-a-Way Helmets. Cindy went on to become one of the top female vertical professional skateboarders in the world. She has the distinction of being the only woman featured in a skateboarding centerfold and is the only female skateboarder to ever be sponsored by Puma.
Since then, Cindy has gone on to coin the term "Sports Stylist," working with companies like Gatorade, Nike, the NBA, and athletes like Tiger Woods, Kobe Bryant and Mia Hamm. Last year she made headlines by skateboarding down the closed 405 freeway in Los Angeles and now she has her own skateboard collaboration "GIRL is NOT a 4 Letter Word" with the biggest company in skateboarding - Dwindle Inc. She's chosen to use this collaboration to give back, by donating a portion of the proceeds to GRO 'Girl Riders Organization'.
Dusters California, which originated from the heart and soul of skateboarding and embraces the heritage of the California skate and surf lifestyle, agrees.Â Cindy and Duster's creative director Nano Nobrego collaborated to design the board 'Girl Is Not A Four Letter Word'Â in conjunction with Longboarding for Peace. The board not only acknowledges, but encourages ALL female skaters.Â With Cindy's original artwork and lettering done in neon and metallic ink, and a skull embedded in the custom grip tape, the board will launch at this summers Vans Warp Tour and will also be in stores this month.Â Cindy will be speakingÂ June 21, 2013Â at the INNOSKATE event at the Smithsonian Museum in Washington DC, along with Tony Hawk and Rodney Mullen.

item.title: Chris Strople - Upland
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Chris Strople I honed my pipe riding skills at the Pipeline Skate Park in Upland, California. I was privileged to see the park when it was chalked out in the dirt. When they dug the hole for the fifteen footer, we originally thought that no one would be able to hit the top. I went to Arizona and skated the huge desert pipes and then came home to the Pipeline and started bouncing off the roof. Upland Pipeline skaters- Tay Hunt and Kevin The Worm Anderson, along with Waldo Autry were the most intense pipe riders... they ruled.

item.title: Chris Strople - Upland Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Back in the day the combi separated the men form the boysâ¦was in college at the time and Stan gave me a key to the park so I could skate between classes. Thank you STAN! CS

item.title: Micke Alba - Tailblock
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Micke Alba Pipeline. Upland, California.Â One of my favorite parts of the park was the famous twelve foot bowl hip. Â The bowl was twelve foot deep and this hip wall was about nine feet high. It had a nice rounded top lip, perfect for perfecting the art of the tail block.Â Â Growing up, there were always a few maneuvers that I wanted to learn and this was one of them. Chris Strople, Steve Alba, Steve Olson, Brad Bowman, Duane Peters, Ray Bones Rodriguez, to name a few, would do tail blocks really well. It was such a beautiful thing to watch, especially over real coping. The precariousness of the trick, on the very tip of the tail, made it difficult. The decks were thin and sometimes we would delaminate them doing this trick... I saw right away that the body position was exactly at the take off spot of Chris Strople's backside air. Â This is one of my early insights that made me study body and foot positions as a youngster. Sure it was thought easy to emulate tricks, but I thought it more important to break tricks apart, see their inner workings. Balance points, take off points, landing points, movements in the air, body contortions and everything. This was skateboarding for me. To sit and watch and then copy the photographs I had in my head.Â Â The tail block became one of my staple tricks in the end. I could simply tail tap and then I progressed to judo and anti-judo taps, air to tap, Saran Wrap, frontside tap and rocket tap. I never got the Salba 360 tap and I still don't know how he did that! Â It was a beautiful thing when he made it. I will love skateboarding forever.

item.title: Micke Alba - Upland Full Pipe
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Micke Alba The Upland Pipeline. Synonymous with the biggest and the best. One had to be gnarly to ride there. Fifteen foot deep bowl, five foot of pure vertical, deep twelve foot bowl, attached to a big, pure twenty foot pipe which was forty feet long. It had snake runs, qualifying bowl, beginners bowls, long wash... Â it was crazy and nothing like it had ever been built before. What if you were eleven years old and this was your backyard? What if almost everyday you saw the best skateboarders in the world? What if your brother was one of those skateboarders?Â Â What would you do?Â Â All I wanted to be was my brother Steve Alba.Â Â I looked up to him. I liked the way he carried himself. I liked the way he challenged himself. I liked the way he talked. I liked who he hung out with, even though they would always tell me "... scram kid, your bothering me." I would stick around, use their mannerisms, copy their gestures, imitate their tricks.Â Â My parents always told me that you are who you hang out with. Okay. I'm hanging with the best, therefore I should be one of the best. This is what my eleven year old mind told me. Â The pipe had various colored lines over the half way mark. Blue, black, yellow, red. I don't remember the order, but I think there were five altogether. I could get up to four, but never five. Salba had five on lock which was pretty damned high if you ask me ... The pipe is where legends were made. Kevin Anderson, Greg Ayres, Oriental Ben, Garrett, Salba, Doug Schneider, Rick Blackhart and Chris Strople ruled the pipe. The over-vert feeling was like a rollercoaster, full freefall. I also saw alot of slams in that pipe, many broken bones, knockouts and endless good times. Most people don't know it, but there were stairs at the far end of the pipe. A few skaters would haul ass down the pipe and carve out to the deck with the stairs underneath them. Very few ever made that line. Salba can testify to that!

item.title: Micke Alba - Invert
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Micke Alba Let me preface this by having my twelve year old son - Wheeler - saying, "Your thumb is not on the top." Right on Wheeler. Good eye. I won't tell you that this was in the beginning stages of my invert, on a fifteen foot wall, with five feet of vertical, we shall just overlook that bit of terrain reality. Really, after Bobby Valdez made the first invert at Lakewood, the next big contest was in Newark, North California. The invert was the trick of the contest, and everyone learned that each contest brought a new invention and skaters better learn it to keep up or fall behind. I started to learn the trick in the snake run at Lakewood. I did it okay but definitely didn't do it in a pool. Then the Milpitas contest was next. The contest bowl had a pinkish colored tri-bowl attached to it, with each bowl progressively larger and deeper. I learned the invert there, hand on top, no coping then, but I definitely turned heads as I probably did one hundred or so that day.Â Â Funny how when you are young, learn something new, and then want to get as much praise as possible, Â you do it over and over and over and over again. You do it just to get that acknowledgement of job well done. In those days, instead of high-fiving, they used to do this thing called, "come on up", a sort of flick-flick hand gesture that meant you did well. Rod Saunders and Greg Ayers used to do it all the time, along with Steve Olson. Back to the picture. Nice rainbow gloves and Nike shoes. There was a time when I rode for Nike but the shoes were very stiff and not flexible. How we did inverts and rock-n-rolls during this time I'll never know, but this is a good example of toe pressure to stay on the board. I was a little older in this photograph. I can tell from the wheels, Kryptonics finally figured out that conicals on each side of the wheel helped the skater go over coping and such. The pads were still antiquated and I can't believe we actually used those pads and thought all was okay on a fifteen foot wall. Â In those days, I donned the long hair. Wonder where my son Wheeler got it from?

item.title: An evening with Arto
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The freeway was cluttered with cars. Taillights and chrome. Brakes. Standstill. I saw frustration and lethargy on those faces closest to me. I watched people texting and jousting for position in their cars. I saw indifference. A young man rumbled past me in some sort of rocket-powered Porsche. The engine throbbed and it startled me. The driver was clearly agitated, weaving and switching lanes. He was a picture of impatience. I smiled. Within thirty minutes, he hadn't advanced more than three car lengths in front of me. "Never waste your money on a car that goes faster than the traffic will allow." Â I mumble. I drove past him on the right side, exiting. He looked like he was going to weep. Arto invited a few of us over to his house for an evening of good food, friends and bowl riding. I like Arto. I rather enjoy his company. He's artistic, well-read, interesting and he is one of the finest skateboarders on the planet. You add style, humor and generosity to those things and one can readily see why he is a top shelf type of guy. Good people. A film crew was at the house when Ray Zimmerman and I arrived. Arto and the film crew were leaving for a motorcycle trip to Alaska. Sunday was departure day and Arto was having one more little backyard bowl BBQ before he went away for a month. [caption id="attachment_15698" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Arto Saari[/caption] It was an incredibly heavy crew of skateboarders that descended on Arto's. Neal Mims, Anthony Van Engelen, Ben Nordberg, Rayce, Pedro Rob, Lance Mountain, Louie Lopez, Jake Brown, Joey Tershay, Guy Mariano, Ron Chapman and others were in attendance. [caption id="attachment_15700" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Louie[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15701" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Pedro Rob[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15702" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ben Nordberg[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15703" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rayce[/caption] Chris who ran the filming crew, threw down some hundred dollar bills for BBQ goodies, ice, drinks and stuff. I took grill duties and everyone else attended to the bowl. The snarl of traffic faded from my mind as skater after skater violated the coping back to the stone age. [caption id="attachment_15706" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jared[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15708" align="aligncenter" width="584"] THREE KINGS
Van Engelen, Mountain and Mariano[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15710" align="aligncenter" width="584"] King of his castle- Arto[/caption] The level of skateboarding was high, the food was tasty, the vibe was perfect and an evening with Arto is something that everyone should experience once in their lifetime. Thank you to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_15705" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Neal Mims[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15712" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Arto[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15709" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Louie[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Like it Ozzie. Gr8 fotos as always RayZ. Obrigado fellas.
sweet..arto is rad,nice post.
Almost like I can taste the bbq and hear the trucks on the coping...thanks, Ozzie
i like fire coping, ride on!
Ozzie you have the best connections and friends. What a bitchen time you have.

item.title: _DSC4619
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: THREE KINGS Van Engelen, Mountain and Mariano

item.title: Wally Inouye
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_14045" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wally Inouye at Marina[/caption] Tom Wally Inouye
If my memory serves me right, this shot was taken in late 1978, Â right after I left Sims for Caster. At the time, I was living in San Diego and would make the drive north to skate places like Marina, Lakewood, and Upland. In this shot I'm riding Chris Strople's model, with a flat deck, no concave and a wedge tail. It has Gullwing trucks and Wing wheels with TRW MRC 38ff bearings ($138.00 a set). The Marina Del Rey skatepark-- back keyhole --saw some amazing sessions.
Â For me it was about my equipment. Jumping ship from Sims to Caster was not motivated by money, but by performance. Â Bill Caster was a premier surfboard shaper for the Big Rock and Wind-n-Sea crew and truly believed in quality not quantity. He along with Ken Watson (Watson Laminates) brought this quality to skateboards.Â Casters boards were made from hard rock maple with epoxy resin and two layers of 6oz fiberglass. Not only were they strong but they had a life characteristic to them we called BOING.Â Gullwing Trucks came from the slalom side of things and Mike Williams first gave me a set to try. While still on Sims, I decided to join the Gullwing team along with Strople, Kubo, Kimbel, Martinez, Piercy and Williams. They developed Wings wheels, which were very fast for their time.
Brad Strandlund would always help me with my equipment by taking all my wheels and putting them on his lathe and making them perfectly round. He would sometime cut groves on the riding surface if I was going to ride plexiglass for added traction. He would lathe me special inside and outside lips or conicals. Brad also turned me on to the best bearing ever. It was the TRW MRC 38ff bearing. Â It was an aircraft bearing and you could turn your board upside down and spin your wheel and it would still be spinning for as long as ten minutes!
Other random shit. Rampage stickers. Rampage were the first halfpipe skate ramp plans done by Tom Stewart. SIO sticker by Barry Zaritsky. SIO were padded skate shorts. Town & Country. Everyone knows Town & Country.Â The Sharp brother's. I can't say enough about them. They took me to pools in the Valley with Valdez and Senatore. They were great photographers and easy to work with. Â Pool riding today blows my mind. What I see these kids doing in backyard pool is totally insane. They are taking it beyond known limits. Pool riding will continue forever. If you want to see it live and you have a pool in your backyard, then CONSERVE WATER - DRAIN YOUR POOL. Once it is empty... skaters will find it.- Wally Inouye
Inouye's Pool Service since 1976

item.title: George Orton / Big O / Invert
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_14363" align="aligncenter" width="584"] George Orton Big[/caption]

George Orton

Big O. Â My best memories of this place were the groms that hung around me. They were guys like Neil Blender, Freddie de Soto, Jim GrayÂ and a host of other locals. I loved being in a contest at Big O. The crowds were roaring, the atmosphere was intense and everyone was ripping. Â Then there wasÂ the sweet smell of concrete and the BBQ going off. Those were the days! New tricks were being made up every month, the skateboardÂ revolution was in full swing. Judges were taking payoffs, back door media deals were being made...it was a time of endless possibilities .My personal skating was at its peak with lots of tricks, some old, some just learned. My fondest memories were Tony Alva showing up with aquaÂ blue hair. He was ready to judge the big air contest. That was the weirdest hair color I'd ever seen in my lifetime Wow! The contest roared on and Bobby Valdez was doing his stalled hand plant inverts and wowing the crowd with that while I was doing face wall aerials. I was going fence high and gettingÂ ready for the show down. The judging was crooked as usual! Bobby and I went head to head. Â I kept blasting face walls while he keptÂ extending his arm higher and higher The crowd was going ballistic! Some people were complaining that Bobby's inverts were a connected trick and not an aerial at all.Â Anyway it didn't matter. Â Alva and the fans were loving it and that is what truly matters. Bobby ended up winning the high air contest with an invert, followed byÂ a lot of controversy. You know what? To this day, I wouldn't change a thing. - George Orton

item.title: Kent Senatore / Reseda
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Kent Senatore What I do recall from this Reseda Skater Cross photograph is from around opening day. The day before it opened, the Val Surf team had the chance to sample the park. We were skating and a crew of Dog Town riders arrived. Lou Peralta, the owner of Reseda, wouldn't let them in so they just stood outside the fence and heckled us. "Kooks! Valley goons!" On and on and on... Â Tony Alva was probably the worst. Those guys always messed with us. The thing is, we would ride their Los Angeles stuff and they would ride the Valley stuff so... It didn't really make much sense. Anyway, the next day when it opened, we were all there together. Snake session. They built a big wooden rollin ramp for speed and the session grew pretty heated. I saw TA fall and quickly just run up the front of the rollin ramp, drop back in and take another run. He was riding two runs to everyone else's one. I started dropping in behind him and following close on his heels. We actually hit boards on one pas and both of us stayed on. I think on that day, the Dog Town riders and the Valley guys sort of clicked. We were all ripping together and were at the same level in many ways. It was a rad time. This time can't be duplicated. The complete invention and discovery was at such an insane level. Everyday, every session, new possibilities were discovered and barriers destroyed.

item.title: Kent Senatore / Marina
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Kent Senatore Brad Bowman came to Marina Skate Park on this day. He had a brand new Sims/BB Superman prototype deck. It had the routed sides and everything. I remember being so stoked on that. He dropped in and did this long rock-n-roll boardslide. I was like "What was that?!" We were doing rock-n-rolls, but I had never seen a rock-n-roll slide. I thought that I could do them as well. So I did. I learned them immediately. That is what I recall from this day. Sunspots Wheels, Tracker Magnesiums, Mad Rats shorts and my KS Turningpoint stickers... Â good times. I never saw this photograph and forgot about this day until the image brought it all back. Amazing.

item.title: Teddi Bennett / Whittier
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Teddi Bennett These photos go way back. Probably back when Skate City in Whittier first opened. Â  Most likely one of their first contests. Â  Early on, I was sponsored by Tracker Trucks and not Independent, which was my main truck sponsor for most of my skateboarding career. Â I believe I wasn't even on the Powell and Peralta/Bones Brigade yet. Â I believe my main sponsor was Vans during the time these pictures were taken.Â What I really love about the one of me doing the invert is that I can see a lot of old friends watching me in the back ground. Â In that picture I see Neil Blender, Pat Ngoho, Steve Cathey, Freddy DeSoto, Jim Gray, and a very young Rodney Mullen. Â Super cool to see them all. Â Brings back some nice memories at a time when the sport was relatively healthy. Â The contests were well attended and there were parks all over the place.Â The picture of me doing the backside air is also at Skate City. Â Again, very early in my skateboarding life hence the goofy nose guard on my board. Â This keyhole was fun. Â It was pretty big compared to most pools at the time. Â You could carve around once and blast some pretty good airs off the first wall. These take me back to a better and more simple time. Â - Teddi Bennett

item.title: Jerry Valdez / B&W / Tailtap
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jerry Valdez This was from a row of houses that were being remodeled or demolished. I think it was in Laurel Canyon. Back then, most skaters bought skate gear from Val Surf Skate Shop.and they'd come into the shop and tell everyone about the good pools they were riding. We rode for Val Surf and were pretty well known from the magazines at that point, so they'd see if we wanted to ride with them. Networking. Pool skating was so new at the time. We shared pools. Very few guys actually skated them so.... It wasn't on anyone's radar. In this photograph, Marc Smith, Tony Altieri and Kent Senatore are in the background. That was a typical pool mission for us at the time. The construction workers had removed coping and we needed something to bounce off of, so we just set it up there. It worked. - Jer

item.title: Shreddi Repas / 39th St. Cage
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Shreddi Repas I started skating very early. I had a clay-wheeled board and rode school yard banks. I'd do catamarans with friends. One day a BMX rider I knew, told me about an empty pool nearby. I found out where it was and went there. There were older guys skating it and it was an eye opening experience. I kept trying and skating it often. I bought a twenty four inch Logan with Bennett trucks and Sims Bowl Riders. The better equipment helped me progress. One day, Wes Humpston, Bob Biniak and Jim Muir were there. The pool was super steep and tough to ride. They said it was "bunk" and the name 'Bunk Pit' was born. It became my second home in a way. Stacy Peralta came and rode as well. He was super positive. A great influence. He was a mentor. I met Lonnie Toft and Alan Scott there and they started taking me all around to places to ride. They first took me to 39th Street pool. It was known as 'The Cage' as well. It was sitting in this open lot in a bad area of town. We'd ride it pretty often. It had great transitions side to side. "- Shreddi Repas

item.title: Wes Humpston / Oxnard
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Wes Humpston Oxnard. The Oxnard park hadÂ really good bowls, a good vide and totally cool people. Kevin Keiser and I surfed up in that area often, so I always felt local and there were great donuts at the Donut Haus on Channel Island Blvd. I would travel up and down the coast to surf. Surfing is what inspired us all along. We were primarily surfers first. The skateboarding came second. If we were surfing somewhere, we'd try and ride local parks or hook up some pools along the way. Networking. Arthur Lake borrowed this board for a photo session and I am still waiting to get it back! ARTHUR! - Wes Bulldog Humpston

item.title: Wes Humpston / Frontside Dog Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Wes Humpston I remember being so stoked because I started getting front sides at the Dog Bowl. The more I did them, the more consistency I achieved. It was a big deal to me, because the guys I skated alongside, ripped frontside lines and many times when they saw me going for one, the next guy knew it was his turn! Â  I remember a guy sitting at the side of the pool telling me I was traveling across three to four blocks of coping on some of my frontside turns. He added that the other guys were just hitting the coping and going right back into the pool. I was just stoked that I was hitting it like that. 1977 was a good year. - Wes Bulldog Humpston

item.title: Dennis Martinez / Oxnard / G&S
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Dennis Martinez I was put on G&S in 1976 or early 1977. Doug Pineapple Saladino and I rode for Bahne together and he then got on G&S. We rode together often. I think Steve Cathey and Pineapple actually talked and I was then put on the G&S team. They had a great team back then. G&S had an A-Team and a B-Team. I was put on the B-Team first as was the norm. I felt like an outsider on G&S though. I was different from the other riders. At Oxnard, they had a really good bowl. No tiles or pool coping, but it was fun. We traveled around California quite often to hit the different parks. The scene was small back then. Everyone knew each other. I surfed and skated in San Diego, so the whole thing that we were doing was a natural progression. We had pools in San Diego. Soul Bowl was where I met Jay Adams and Tony Alva. Soul Bowl was a really great pool. When we designed Spring Valley skate park, we tried to design the pool after Soul Bowl. - Dennis Martinez

item.title: Dennis Martinez / G&S to Variflex
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Dennis Martinez I was on the G&S team, but I felt like an outcast. I just wasn't really like the other riders. Gil Losi of Variflex approached me and thought I'd make a good fit for the team. Variflex had a really good lineup. El Gato, Grisham, the Hirsch brothers, Orton, Seigfried, De Soto... Â I went to Variflex but it was all so short-lived. Drugs took their toll. I had been doing them for awhile and it all just got to be too much. In the end, my bad behaviors started becoming a priority in my life. Drugs and their use took skateboarding away from me and I let it happen. It was not a good time in my life. I watched all I love disappear like smoke from a pipe. - Dennis Martinez

item.title: Brad Bowman / Valley Pools
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Brad Bowman Our San Fernando Valley crew usually consisted of me, Mauro Montero, Arthur Viecco, Deano Mueller and occasionally others. We rode with Shreddi, Jay Smith, Jerry Valdez, Dave Ferry, Marc Smith and the Senatore's too. There were so many pools out in the valley. It was really hot all the time. Most of these were pools where we just hopped a fence, took some rides and left. We had a few really good pools going for awhile. Mondo's was great. Mondo's pool was really good. The transitions were big and the bowl was open. Willis was a square that Arthur had going in Panorama City. There were some amazing sessions at Willis. I skated with Jay, Shogo and Tony there. We had the Bunk Pit which was Shreddi's pool, Vanalden spit gutter square in Tarzana and others. In the beginning, I didn't drive, so I'd either take a long bus ride out to the pools or catch rides. The Sharp brothers would phone and tell me to get ready... they'd come by and pick me up. We'd go ride several pools a day. - Brad Bowman

item.title: Arthur Viecco/ Sunspots/Cactus
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Arthur Viecco I saw this huge cactus when we were stopped by the side of the road on the long hot drive across the Arizona desert. I started sticking the Sunspots Wheels onto the cactus spines. We added a bunch of them and thought it would make a cool advertisement or something. Later, when we pulled the wheels off, we found that the spines came out with them. Ouch! Â - Arthur Viecco

item.title: Dave Ferry / Oxnard
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Dave Ferry The other shot was at the opening of the Oxnard skatepark. I loved that side of the double bowl. Jerry Valdez designed and helped that place come about with a rich guy that made all kinds of multilevel parking structures all over L.A. - Â Edd Olson. He had a really hot daughter too! Sadly, the other side of that double bowl shifted when the cement was setting up. One side was a bank and the other side was a bit over vert. This side that I am riding was nice and even. If I recall correctly, most of the early magazine images from Oxnard Skate Park at this time, were from this side of the bowl as it was the spot where most skaters could really ride well.

item.title: Mike McGill - Big O Contest
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Mike McGill I recall Steve Olson coming into the contest late. He showed up, took a few runs and then promptly frontside aired the entire channel at Big O for the win. We were pretty amazed. Fellow Floridian, Alan Gelfand was a big inspiration for me. We had different styles and lived about four hours apart. Mark Lake, Kelly Lynn, Clyde Rogers, George McClellan were inspirational to me as well. George would give me rides to the skate park in his van. I was young. The layback air in this photograph was credited to me but Kelly Lynn originated it. - Mike McGill

item.title: Hester Series / Newark / Rick Blackhart
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_15790" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rick Blackhart - Newark[/caption] Rick Blackhart "Ah yes, Ride On Skatepark in Newark, California. It was the site of the third contest in the first Hester Series. The year was 1978 and skating was fucking hot! The Independent Truck had just come out and I was at the top of my game. I did the first frontside roll-in during this contest and should have won it but Bobby Valdez did a lame hand-plant and the judges couldnt decide who the winner was, me or him. They asked me if I wanted to tie for first place or let the judges pick a winner. I said "Fuck that! Pick a winner." So, they picked Bobby. Little did I know that if I had settled for a first place tie, I would have won the entire Hester Series. Yikes. Huge mistake on my part. As it ended up, I took third overall in the series.... Â Here are a few memories about the bowl at Newark. That thing was a monster. It was a twelve foot deep keyhole and all cement. It had a rough broomed surface that would tear you up. There was no tiles in the pool and it had huge four inch coping that felt like hitting a parking block when we rode up on it. It was a burly no-nonsense bowl for sure. I hear its still there, just burried in dirt waiting to be dug out.... Â grab your shovels!" - Dr. Rick Blackhart Thank you to Rick Blackhart for the memories and Glen E. Friedman for the image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Don't even try to say that that isn't one of the baddest ass f/s grind shots of all time . . and on THAT coping. Pure, original, hardcore full-on charging. That's the lead I followed.
wOW! Pricelesss inside scoop on our past. Packed into a tight concise paragraph - too cool. Thanks Ozzie & Rick.
Thanks alot Blue Tile, and thanks to all you other bro's for the cool comments. this day was EPIC! and one that will be forever etched in my mind. Thank you Glen Friedman..

Badass, and yes,a tough decision judging. Bobby did throw down a nice invert but the Dr. went balls to the walls fast, recklessly carving the hell out of the beast then rolled in Frontside for a full extension acid drop. Loved The hand plant and smooth run by Bobby but The Dr.got ripped that afternoon. Then got ripped that evening!
we're all fags compared to blackhart. he fuck rules. and was Indy team captain for A MINUTE!

Rick Blackhart...where do you start with this guy? The first time I skated with him was on Indian School Road in Arizona in a halfpipe.Edge to edge control. Flawless pump from wall to wall.His frontside roll-ins were literally like he was a ghost going thru the coping. It was almost a carve- in from the deck. For me..watching him skate was like going to class or a workshop. He took scary and put it within reach. Hands down for me..The Dr. literally ruled with his skate scalpel. Thanks Rick!

item.title: Aerial Agenda
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_15803" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Arianna, Luke, Kevin, Rylan, Randy, Me , Archer and Leo[/caption] Aerial. We have a good heart. Unclouded and pure. We love skateboarding and try our best to keep it positive. We make really quality wood. We test it. We ride it. We destroy what destroys us. We are like you. We collectively believe that to be better at anything, one has to trust the heart and push through all obstacles, ego's, strife and misdirection. The Aerial Agenda. To push through... [caption id="attachment_15805" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mancha at home.[/caption] The other day, we gathered together at Mancha's vert ramp. The team came together. Randy and Kevin Koch, Arianna Camona, Rylan Mancilla, Leo Ruiz, Luke McCabe, Archer Braun and myself. Eddie Chang and Jason ThurtleÂ could not make it but we kept the fires lit for them as a beacon... [caption id="attachment_15806" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rylan Mancilla[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15807" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Arianna Carmona[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15808" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Leo Ruiz[/caption] Mancha, Craig Whitehead, Augie, Bob Burnquist and Brian Patch joined in the session. Our team lit the proverbial fuse on this day. Little Rylan threw down in a big way. He did whatever he wanted for as long as he wanted. He was shining like a brand new penny. Arianna stepped up and put on her game face. Airs and rocks were hers... Owned. It seemed as though Leo Ruiz spent more time over our heads than the sky that day. Huge airs and 540's were on his menu and he ate heartily. [caption id="attachment_15811" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Archer Braun[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15812" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Luke McCabe[/caption] Archer Braun put style and flow into the session. Cool lines, tricks and power oozed from him. Luke McCabe spent his first vert session in a while, dropping in and finding his vert legs again. Once he did, airs and ollies were tossed around with further adieu. Good stuff. Â Randy Koch and Kevin bought some BBQ goodies and we had some snacks. MRZ took the photographs, Mancha- the local ramp lord and master- crushed the place like he owns it. Mancha has a great style and presence. He is a wonderful human being on top of it all... [caption id="attachment_15813" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Evandro Mancha Menezes[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15814" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bob Burnquist[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15815" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Craig Whitehead[/caption] [caption id="attachment_15816" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brian Patch[/caption] Bob Burnquist was Bob Burnquist. If you can think of something difficult to do on a skateboard, Bob has probably done it. Switch stance AND regular foot! Fini. Thank you to the Aerial crew, the parents, Â thank you Randy, thank you to Mancha & Courtney and the neighbors (sorry about the parking lot out front), thank you to MRZ and thank you SKATEBOARDING. Stay honest and pure. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: _DSC1059
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: Arianna, Luke, Kevin, Rylan, Randy, Me , Archer and Leo

item.title: Jay Adams / Caster/ BS Air/ Marina
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jay Adams This photograph was taken in the weeks leading up to the Gyro/Dogbowl contest at Marina. I was skating at my best. I was doing really high airs, about trash can height, and that was pretty big for back then. I was doing extended inverts and I had good lines in the Dogbowl. In the evening the pool became a bit slippery sometimes. On this night, I had a stupid lapper on my back truck and I had pulled a backside tailslide. I hung up anyway and went straight down to the bottom and hurt my back. It was painful, so I went to the doctor. He told me I fractured a vertebrae.
