item.title: Gold Cup II
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Eddie Elguera "This was at the Big O. The week leading up to the contest, I had been trying different things over the channel. Dale Smith was working with me at the time. He and I were trying to work out an invert over the channel but I just couldn't figure it out back then. I did lien airs over it and also pulled a footplant over as well. I'd do a backside air and then plant my foot on the opposite side of the channel... dropping back in. Duane Peters saw me do one and he then did one but went straight across and into the opposite transition. Progression. Coming into the Hester final, I knew that I just needed to qualify. I was the last to skate as I was in the lead. Everyone went and completed their compulsory runs. Duane went right before me. He skated well. I knew that I had to make the top eight and I could win the series. I remember that when it was my turn to go, Steve Alba, Duane and a bunch of their crew were yelling and spitting at me, trying to make me fall. Right before I went, Salba yelled, "You're going to fall Eddie!"Â He was right. I fell. I skated poorly." "I had one run left. I knew that I needed to stay on everything. I dropped in. Those guys were yelling at me. I made my line. The last trick was a sweeper from the round onto the peninsula and then I'd ride out of the shallow and end my run. Well, I went to do my sweeper. I missed my tail. I thought, "Oh my..." I simply threw it under me and put it on the line. I recall riding up into the shallow and all those guys that were yelling because they thought I'd blown it... Â they were like, "What just happened?" I felt good. I had stayed on it. I made the cut. We are all friends now. We skate together and it is really cool to have all of this history." - Eddie Elguera Tony Hawk "The Gold Cup, at the time, was the biggest event. It was overwhelming. There was a crowd of people entering. I recall that they'd cut the competitors to something like twenty riders. I couldn't even recall seeing that many guys ever skating. It was pretty heavy. I do remember something that really stood out to me. I recall Teddi Bennett talking to Stacy Peralta. Teddi asked Stacy if he should do a certain trick in his line for qualifiers. Stacy answered something like, "Well, you do what you think you can do. Stay on." Teddi then answered back, "I think I'll save that trick for finals." I was pretty blown away by that comment. Teddi Bennett was absolutely so sure of his skating and abilities, that he knew he would make the cut and be in the finals. I was totally surprised... That was the heaviest thing to me. There was no question in his mind. Amazing. I also recall the compulsory runs. It was a changing of the guard in a way. Some guys were on the way out. Some couldn't do inverts, which were part of compulsories. It was a strange and overwhelming time." - Tony Hawk Christian Hosoi "Gold Cup. I was twelve years old. It was all new to me. I think that I was going as high or higher than most of the guys out there. I mean, Neil Blender and Dave Andrecht were going pretty high at the time. They did the highest airs. It was a changing of the guard. A new era. The Gold Cup ushered in some serious amateur talent. Basically, Steve Caballero, Eddie Elguera and Duane Peters were already pro. So, the amateurs in Gold Cup were those guys that ended up as Pro's in the 1980's. The Gold Cup was my first taste of real competition. I had just started riding vert. I learned to skate vert in the back keyhole at Marina. I had to get used to the adrenalin, the crowd, the banners and the timed runs. Shogo Kubo, Jay Adams and TA basically helped raise me, so it wasn't so bad. It seemed pretty normal to me. Right place. Right time. I received my first photograph in Skateboarder Magazine that year as well. It was heavy. I was very young. Back then, it was pretty crazy. Gold Cup raised the bar. It was very trick-oriented skateboarding. There were compulsory runs as well. The Hester Series before it, was primarily style, lines, walls, wheelers and power. Some skaters couldn't keep up with the progression. They were left behind. I thought the compulsories of the Gold Cup were sort-of kooky, but I didn't mind. I just wanted to skate. We were the amateurs out there doing everything we could. We were trying to prove that we belonged. We always skated the best that we could." - Christian Hosoi Thank you to Eddie Elguera, Tony Hawk and Christian Hosoi for their time and memories. Thank you to Glen E. Friedman for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Great post - thanks for this, and thanks for all of your articles.
All the best.

Compulsory runs are so interestingly static & yet intriguing as a way to distinguish different styles to a given trick in a way that (may) make subjective judging easier / more fair. Maybe not strict compulsory but say a list of 20 tricks that you can pick 10 from? I've always felt judging subjectively, not perfect. Having 2 free runs and 2 compulsories might ease the burden of getting the results right? Thanks again Ozzie & contributors for letting us inside.
I agree Andy...the way the Santa Cruz crew treated Eddie was shameful.

I don't think that treatment of Eddie was a West Coast thing. At that point in time there were pretty strong lines drawn between Santa Cruz, Powell and Variflex along style and lifestyle lines even East of California. Each brand's vibe, board graphics, colors and of course the Magazine had a lot to do with it. Another great article. Seemed like Eddie was talking about Upland though, with the "round into peninsula" comment.

Really nice post! Great to here it from each of these guys. Very cool perspectives. Hard to imagine such bad sportsmanship as Eddie is talking about. That must have been a west coast vibe. I never saw and could never imagine such a situation on here on the east coast.

"1980s" and "pros" have no apostrophes. Tnose are for possessives and for contractions. I know that you care about your writing, so I hope that you can learn those rules. No criticism, I'm trying to help. I love your blog.
funny...

item.title: Chris Miller / Guest Post
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Chris Miller
"When I look at this, it stirs a feeling that is like a dream. Not really any hard memories from that day. Almost like it's somebody else, except I know it's me. I am reminded of the heat and smog of the Upland air, and the nervous energy of a skate contest. I remember the surface of that pool, rough in some spots and polished slick in others. The huge brown coping like a force of nature trying to send you to the flat bottom... More of a cornice than coping.Â I can tell by the angle of the board and my back foot what's happening here. I am at the edge of control, maybe past it, going twice as fast as I want to be and hanging on like my life depended on it. My board scooped, tail above me, the inside of my back foot all the way against the grip. Higher and faster than that board or bowl were meant to be ridden, on edge, playing with fire and trying not to explode.Â I am not sure what event this is... I think it was before I was pro and could be Rusty Harris or the Upland turkey shoot? I don't know, but I do see Frank Hawk on the deck and I am pretty sure that's Lester Kasai in the channel. My use of duct tape is pretty impressive... front coper only, a very flat looking board with almost no nose. Those were the times." - Chris Miller
Â Thank you to Glen E. Friedman for the image and thank you to Chris Miller for the memories. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Reblogged this on GÃ¸Î·Ñ ã Skaâ Ã®Î·g and commented: Chris Miller
Style.

Great insight of a classic pic. Only you, the subject could know or explain. I can relate to how gnarly the OG combi was & IE smog but the blasting air, scoop, foot placement & people on deck are things only you could know / relate. front coper only is interesting. - Thanks Chris.

Thank you Ozzie for chronicling all this skateboarding history. It brings back such great memories. When I reflect back on Upland, so many great skaters (locals and visitors) ripped the combi. From the early days of Craig Rowe, DP, ALBA brothers, Chris Robison, Eric Jeuden, and many others. And with all due respect to Steve and Mickey, Chris Miller in my opinion was the man at Upland. I was always so jealous/envious because he made it look so easy and with such style and grace. Im glad I got to skate with all these guys and witness up personal a great time in skateboarding history.
beautiful photo, beautiful words.

item.title: Billy Yeron / Marina
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Billy Yeron After Dino passed away and the Dogbowl was a thing of the past, Marina was looming quickly on the horizon. We actually helped with the park construction. We wanted the Marina Dogbowl to be pretty accurate, so once the equipment operators dug the main hole, TA, Jim Muir, Bob Biniak, Paul Constantineau and I actually shaped the walls with pickaxes. We formed the walls. The original Dogbowl had uneven sides and one was longer, so we worked to get Marina correct. It was a great time to be skating.

item.title: Introduction
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is a culmination of many years of thought and effort. Two ends of time are neatly tied. Then and now. In some cases, life and death. Some of our friends are gone now. William Sharp took these photographs between 1976 and 1980. Four years of skateboarding discovery and progression. Infancy and adolescence. The four years involved, were milestone years. Like NASA in the 1960's, these skateboarders were walking on the moon. No one had come before them. No map was readily available. Uncharted, concrete and painful. It was a path they readily traveled, middle fingers raised to the world. These riders pushed skateboarding into another dimension. Imagine, it is 1976 and you are standing in a sprawling backyard in the San Fernando Valley. The concrete and plaster of the empty pool glimmers in the hot summer sun. Friends watch in fascination. You poise on the copings edge. Your tail rests against the lip. You've already ridden over the light, up onto tiles and balanced on one wheel during the past days of pool skating. A question began to form in your head. Can you drop down that impossibly steep surface from the deep end deck? How will you drop down the vertical and will gravity allow you to catch up with your rolling wheels? Committed. You look over at the shallow stairs where your friends watch. Breathing in, you put your front foot on and spill down into your destiny. These scenes were played out often. Many times, the progression out paced the product and technology. Riders began doing airs in pools. Bearings --under immense stress-- buckled under the heat and strain. Trucks and axles broke. Bones followed. Progress and discovery spiked. Every new session brought new discovery and every contest found something new unveiled. Â The magazines of the time were a flag unfurled. A banner. "Follow us!" In a small dusty Pennsylvania town, I saw and heeded the call. What I saw and read in those magazines came to define my life. We had no video, very few photographic sequences... we only had the images burned into our hungry minds. I sat on my bed. Skateboard World Magazine perched on my lap. I thumbed through it. My mind a sponge. Jerry Valdez hung in the air above a blue pooI with red coping. Palm trees scraped the sky above. Skaters cluttered the shallow end, faces peering at the action in the deep end as Jerry raised the bar another notch. He often did. I studied the image like a scientist studies a lab manual. Every detail. Nothing lost. I put the magazine on a shelf and went outside. I began hurling myself out of the top of my small plywood ramp.Â

item.title: Shogo Kubo / Frontside Air
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Shogo Kubo
I thought this was at Lakewood but the T&C shorts is way early, so I guess I'm in Oxnard half pipe? Unsure.Â We didn't skate the half pipe much because of the bowl. I remember the snake run was fun...but again, we just skated the bowl.Â Frontside airs. The frontside air was first made by Tony Alva at the original Dogbowl back in 1977.
It all started by carving over the light at the Canyon pool, and just progressed to hitting the coping, grinding the coping...and eventually, TA was out of the pool. He figured out a way to come back in. It was amazing.Â I had to learn it and had it wired within a few weeks. I eventually learned to do one of the highest in that era.

item.title: Gregg Ayres / Blue Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Gregg Ayres The Blue Pool I donât remember if this pool had a name.Â  I think it was in Oxnard, Camarillo or maybe Ventura.Â  It had a ton of blue paint that seemed fairly fresh.Â  There was so much slick blue paint that the pool was very slippery, but it was a fun pool with good coping and smooth transitions.Â  At the time I lived in Redondo Beach and Oxnard seemed really far away, so I donât think I skated here more than a couple of times.Â  The Sharps liked this pool because of the unusually bright blue color and I am sure they could tell it was a good pool for the skaters to ride by the quality of our riding.Â  It was one of those pools that you could adjust to and tear up immediately.Â  And if you did fall, the slippery surface would usually keep you from getting hurt or even scraped up.Â  There was a picture of me riding this pool in Skateboard World in August 1977.

item.title: The Dead End Kings
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: He was young. Eighth grade. Nothing bad ever touched his world. Popularity shadowed him. Harmful words and schoolyard cruelty bounced past, like a yellow rubber ball to strike those less fortunate. The forgotten ones. His dad was proud of him. Baseball consumed him and his family. Games and practice. The smell of a leather glove. Bright lights glimmering down on Friday nights. A long drive to left field. He found himself backing up... eyes glued skyward. Lost in lights. Descent. This was it. "Don't take your eyes off the ball." He lifted his glove and... Arms hoisted him up. Victory. His father grinned knowingly at him in the rearview mirror that night. "Champ!" His voice murmured back towards him. At home, his friends around the neighborhood had begun to skateboard. The big new skateboard park down the street was overflowing with skaters. Gray concrete hills and moguls meandered over the property as he stood by the fence and peered inside. It looked like fun. "Hey man! Come on. Let's skate." His friends called out to him excitedly. He shrugged and trudged home. He had baseball practice. His father certainly would never approve of such a thing as skateboarding. Later that night, his father asked him what was bothering him. "You're not on your A game today..." Â Quiet reflection. Silence. His father downshifted the Datsun wagon as the headlights cut the darkness. He shrugged in the dashboard lights. "I don't know. I guess I miss my friends... Â they were all at the new skateboard park today." His father looked over at him. Stern voice. Commanding. "No son of mine will waste his time doing that! You have the talent to be something. Baseball is your gift. You are a rare find. Someday, coaches will be looking at you from different universities. I've invested too much time with you... Â get skateboarding off of your mind. It's a dead end. [caption id="attachment_16434" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kyle Kaitanjian[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16435" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Michael Serna Jr.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16436" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Micke Alba[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16437" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Duane Peters[/caption] Years flowed by like dirty water. Injuries and unfulfilled dreams. Baseball lost its lure. "All that glitters..." His father gave up long ago, on living a baseball career vicariously through him. His remaining high school years had blown past in a long exhalation of weed smoke and backseat liaisons. He had managed to avoid a few pregnancy scares. He held a job at a steel mill. Skateboarding was something he had, that made the unrealized dreams and the stress of life somehow tolerable. He hadn't heeded his father's advice. He had started skating and it was magical. [caption id="attachment_16438" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Steve Alba[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16439" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Greyson Fletcher[/caption] They rode empty pools together. They would have BBQ's and their band would set up poolside and play punk music. He and his friends found skateboarding a common bond. It was a cement that kept their world intact. It brought them together. United. When one of the crew had problems, the others were there. They followed a painful road to a dead end... and they were kings. [caption id="attachment_16442" align="aligncenter" width="584"] The Dead End Kings[/caption] Thank you to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That's my story. Amen!
Wow, the pic of Malba.... An amazing blast from my past - Thanks so much for what you do.
âbravo!â

Hell yeah! I didn't play ball, I worked after school. I had drunken parents and everything I did was "dumb & childish." Rolling on that board was the only freedom I had. It made me glad I was alive. If not for that freedom, the drugs would have won out. ....
Great story Ozzie
Reblogged this on GÃ¸Î·Ñ ã Skaâ Ã®Î·g and commented: Dead End Kings

item.title: George Orton / Reseda/ Roll In
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_14366" align="aligncenter" width="584"] George Orton Reseda[/caption]

George Orton

This is a shot at the newly built keyhole at Reseda's Skatercross. It was the first real skateparkÂ I ever went to and the home of Shreddi Repas. It was where the first Hester annual contest was held and where Bert Lamar entered his first big contest. I think he was about 3'10" tall. The vibe at this place was totally different from any other park. ThereÂ were rumors and grumblings about skaters switching teams and who wanted to kick who's ass! The tension was in the air and it was a beautiful thing. Rolling in was becoming very popular. Â The crowds were flamboyant being so close to Hollywood and the locals were veryÂ passionate about there own peeps... the bowl was quite tight, but yet workable. Bert kept trying to snake all the pros!Â during practice.. But I put a stop to that on one of his runs.. or his snaking agenda! Â I grabbed him on the backÂ of his neck on his way in.. with an abrupt departure between him and his board. Dangling in mid air, I told him toÂ cool his shit! He soon learned about respect. All kinds of lines were being explored as the day went onÂ I was currently working frontside roll ins which only a couple of guys would attempt to do.. that was the gnarlyÂ thing to do at that time and scored big points with the judges. It was a memorable contest all an all at the parkÂ and the motels, which is a whole other story in itself..Â

item.title: Tony Alva / Dog Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tony Alva The Dog Bowl story has been told. You've been there Ozzie. I took you there in 1999. It was before they bulldozed it. The place was massive. It was a really large pool so it isn't a wonder that the transitions were big, open and rideable. Dino's parents were cool. As he deteriorated in health, we finally began to stop going. It was in respect to Dino and his parents. Its time had come. Progression, tricks, style and lines were developed. Its time was soon gone. The pool is no more. Much like that era. Things happened so fast... it was hard to keep it all sorted and in focus. Strange and chaotic. Life.

item.title: Tony Alva / Desert Pipes
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tony Alva I rode the Arizona pipes several times. They were really something else. I mean, the surfaces were smooth as a glass window. Flawless. They were monstrous in size. It really was exciting to ride something this large and the ultimate speed that we developed and maintained was pretty incredible. We would sometimes transfer pipe to pipe when they were sitting in rows. You could ride up and frontside air the gap between the two. It was a long ride out to get to them. Plenty of time to party, act up and do nothing. We would drive up, ride for a few hours, take photographs, then drive back sometimes. They wouldn't last for long. Nothing good ever really does. This was a special place and will never happen again. Arizona desert pipes. Definitely one of the cooler things I've ever skated.

item.title: Rick Blackhart / One Wheeler
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Rick Blackhart This is a cool photo. It is too bad that no one ever got a photograph of me doing frontside airs. All these wheelers make me look lame. Of course, this shot is before airs, I believe. 1976 or 1977. I'm not sure. Â I'm wearing cool Vans... Â Tony Alva editions. I don't remember anything about this session. Is that Sierra Wave? It Iooks like Joe Fong in the background but its confusing because it also looks like one of those guys might be Jerry Valdez. I'm clueless on this one. I don't even recognize that board. Are those Indy's and Tunnel Rocks? Bennett's and Sims?

item.title: Mike Weed / Skatopia / Fruit Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Mike Weed This photo is from 1977. Spring time. I am at Skatopia Skatepark. I was doing tailtaps for the first time. I had heard that Tony Alva was doingÂ them the day before. No one had made a true aerial yet on vert. I think Wally landed the first backside air at Reseda skatepark not long after that. There were lots of photosÂ of unmade airs in magazines at this time, and then about month later maybe ten of us could do one. There were frontside or backside at first, no variations. Then a few monthsÂ later, everyone and their brother could do one. All kinds of different grabs and hand plants would be done in the near future. I have a broken arm in a cast in the photo. I Â broke it at the Fruit Bowl on the wood extension. Â I was trying to do the much dreamed about aerial off the side of the wood extension there. I never made it at the Fruit Bowl, but would make one soon. The Fruit Bowl was the firstÂ pool where we could do one wheelers back to back. That is what we called them at this time, later they would be called grinds. Also, we did the first two wheel carves over the stairs at this pool. The first frontsideÂ one wheelers were done at the Fruit Bowl. Â The first cess slide --or rock walk-- was done by Jay Adams at the Fruit Bowl. Â I did my first fakie 360, and fakie switch at the Fruit Bowl. Vert skateboarding took a big step forward at the Fruit Bowl, because it was a big open bowl with perfect transitions and the pool was going on for a long period of time. Skaters from Santa Cruz to San Diego ripped the Fruit Bowl. It was definitely one of the best pools of that era.

item.title: David Hackett / Upland Pipe
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is without question, one of my favorite photographs that Bill SharpÂ took of me skating. The year was 1977 and I was sixteen years old. I'm almost two feet overÂ vert with my inside wheel coming off the wall. I'm fully committed and riding onÂ Bennett Hi Jacker Trucks and OJ II wheels, mounted on a twenty nine inch G&S Stacy Peralta Warp Tail. Â Iâm not sureÂ how I rode that little deck back then. My back foot looks like itâsÂ three times the size of the tail! This wasnât opening day, becauseÂ I remember riding opening day with Jay Adams, Tony Alva andÂ Bob Biniak. That was the day where we all laid down the first over vert lines on theÂ still curing wet cement. That day, Jay shotÂ his Z-Flex deck so hard, that it did a full loop. Upon entering the pipeâsÂ upper quadrant, Jayâs board took out and destroyed the fluorescentÂ lighting fixture causing a rain of glass and white fluorescent dustÂ particles. You can see the aluminum metal guard rails in this photoÂ as a result of Jay Boy, so next time you see him, you can thank himÂ for that.

item.title: Dave Hackett / Reseda Tailtap
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was taken at ResedaÂ Skatercross skatepark in late 1977. It looks like Iâm aboutÂ to pull into a full tail tap in Resedaâs second bowl. I rememberÂ back then, I really wanted to ride for Sims but I didnât really knowÂ anyone that could make that happen for me, so I followedÂ Stacy Peralta and Paul Constantineau onto the G&S Team. TheyÂ treated me very good for a while, before I got kicked off the team.Â You can see my little G&S Competition Team yellow polo shirt that also had my name screened on the front. Man I thought that IÂ had arrived! That board is a thirty inch, solid oak Stacy Peralta Warp Tail with BennettÂ Hi Jackers and those old Emotion wheels. Emotion wheels were --by far--the worst and slowest wheels ever. The only reason we rode them, wasÂ we got paid three hundred dollars each, to appear in their advertisement. It was me, my brother PaulÂ (RIP), Bob Biniak, Tony Alva, and Woody Woodward. Back then, we would do anything to make a dollar skateboarding. It was all in the name of being a âProfessional Skateboarderâ

item.title: Dave Hackett / Marina / FS Grind
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I love this shot as it really captures the era. Tube socks, Alva Pig board, Copers, a Clyde Slide, 1/2â riser pads under my Tracker Extracks and dig the wooden tail tap device! This was shot in theÂ Marina Dogbowl around 1978. This was a special time in my life, as I was riding for Alva Skates and hanging with TA most of the time. I had just come back from Florida and I had won a contest. It was on this trip that TA and I had cutÂ out this deck and the Florida guysÂ turned me onto the Clyde Slide, mounted up to the back truck. TheÂ blue, yellow, and red on the bottom of this deck are mini Alva stickerÂ sheets we used as our graphic. I wish I still had that Jay AdamsÂ Fly Away Helmet. It looks like Iâm riding doubles here with another goofy footer. It is probably Polar Bear or Marty Grimes. I was tight withÂ both those dudes and we sessioned Marina for sometimes eight hoursÂ a day, in between gnarly Chorb sessions in the parking lot. I still have that deck over thirty five years later.

item.title: Dave Hackett / AZ / Desert Pipe
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Iâll never forget this Arizona desert pipe trip. I think it was late 1976 orÂ early 1977, as Iâm all decked out in G&S gear. This was right before I startedÂ riding for Alva Skates. If I remember right, it was me, TA, KentÂ Senatore, Jerry Valdez, Bob Biniak, Shogo, and Stan and Bill Sharp.Â Stan (RIP) and Bill drove all of us out there in Stanâs van and weÂ were all little assholes to them. We gave Stan a real hard time. The poor dude didnâtÂ deserve most of the crap we gave him. If it wasnât for him and BillÂ and Skateboard World Magazine, many of us would not have received some of the rad coverage and sick shots they took. We all owe themÂ an amends... I think this place was called Biscuit Flats. It wasÂ this huge open empty space where a company called Ameron wouldÂ manufacture and place these huge pipe sections out in the middle of theÂ desert to cure. When we heard about these, we wasted no time in drivingÂ out to ride them. In this picture, Stan is taking a photo of me as TA and Kent Senatore look on. That trip was awesome!

item.title: Dave Hackett / Suspender
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Back in 1977 and 1978, there were quite a few people attempting to blast airs out of verticalÂ surfaces, such as bowls, pools and ramps. Some of the first guys IÂ ever saw attempting and completing airs were Jay Adams, TonyÂ Alva, Steven Picciolo and Tom Inouye. My brother Paul (RIP) and IÂ were on the Malibu Skateboard Team and one of our closest friendsÂ was a guy named Gary Strauss. He lived on the beach in Malibu, justÂ south from the pier where he owned the Malibu Surf Apartments. That wasÂ where we often would hang out. He was also a World Class Trans PacificÂ Nacra Cat Sailor and an inventor. It was Gary Strauss who developed theÂ Velcro Foot Strap Harness called âSuspendersâ. We tried them and my brother and I would blast serious air out of pools, ramps and here in the second bowl at Reseda. It was a crazy product and very dangerous because it was hard to bailÂ out of. Â I did manage to do some of the very first airs over the four and five foot mark. This was a low one. JustÂ look at the seriousness and the concentration on my face andÂ you know how gnarly a slam on the death straps could be.

item.title: Dave Hackett / Reseda Wheeler
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This photo was taken at one of the hot and radical night sessions at Reseda Skatepark right after itÂ opened. It was late 1977 or early 1978. I'm not sure, but this was an important timeÂ in my skate career, as I was sponsored by G&S at the time, butÂ hanging out and riding pools and Parks with Tony Alva, Jay, PC,Â Muir, Shogo, and Steve Picciolo. This is a one -wheeler off the second bowl at Reseda. I'm riding a deck that was ridden and tested as one ofÂ the first Alva Skates boards. Tony was originally going to come out with twoÂ models- The Model âAâ and The Model âTâ. This is a Model âTâ. TA gave it to me. That is why thereâs a swastika on it andÂ a Dog Town cross. Â I wasnât acting like I was some hardcore DTÂ local, because I wasnât. I was always proud to be one of the only professional skaters from Malibu. It just turned out that Jay, Tony and a few otherÂ DT guys used to come surf Malibu and the Colony and some of the crew would date my sisterÂ and some of her friends as well. Shortly after this time period, I wasÂ always considered by the media as a Dog Town guy. I wasÂ proud of that too. I ended up selling this deck to a collector a fewÂ years ago for some good money.

item.title: Duane Peters / Big O Layback air
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Duane Peters This is from the Big O Capsule. Layback air next to the channel. I was fresh on Dogtown. You can see my board with the self-stick on letters, because I had just signed my contract. I was super stoked and practicing for my subsequent win at the Whittier contest in Hester Series II. Â By the time that contest was over, I was already looking elsewhere, for some company to put out my routed board. The board I'm riding in this photograph, is the template board for my later striped Santa Cruz deck. I was experimenting with colors. Check out the Kanoa helmet. Â DP - MOD - Â  Â X X

item.title: Jim Muir / Gonzales
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jim Red Dog Muir The Gonzales Pool was tighter than the Dogbowl but we took what we learned from the other pools we rode before and applied it. Every new pool offered up possibilities. Each was a learning experience. Gonzales was a great pool. It was a deeper pool with obstacles and a great hip to ride. We had it to ourselves for quite a long time after the Dogbowl was gone.

item.title: Jim Muir / Marina
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jim Red Dog Muir Once the Marina Skate Park started being built, I spent a good bit of time over there helping. Myself, Billy Yeron and the others would help with the design and construction. We'd ride either Oxnard or Pipeline in between working on the Marina park. We would drive out to Pipeline and ride Mt. Baldy pipe as well. We liked stuff that was surf-oriented. We would ride Pipeline pipe at night. We just loved that weightlessness. It was strange because people stopped looking for pools as much. There were more places to ride. Parks and things began to be built all over the place. There were all kinds of things going on at this time. The Turningpoint and Pepsi ramps. I didn't really care for much of it. Pools just felt so much better to ride than man made stuff. I passed on a few good opportunities I guess. I had pretty bad injuries by this time as well. Skating was taking its toll. I slammed and hurt myself at Oxnard. I was off for awhile and when I came back, people were doing ollies and inverts. It was a big change.

item.title: Alan Gelfand / Fs ollie Del Mar
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Alan Ollie Gelfand This photograph reminds me of the most memorable time in my skateboarding life. It was right before I quit completely. I had won here at Del Mar Skate Ranch. I won Big O and Marina. Then, I simply stopped. There were compulsory runs and I couldn't stand the thought of that. You mean, someone is now going to tell me how to skate and what to do? I always went in the opposite direction if such things occurred. I didn't want to learn and do inverts. In the Del Mar contest, I won the highest air contest with a four foot frontside air. I wanted to skate, how I wanted to skate and that was that. I always tried to do a different trick on each wall and I didn't like falling. I felt it was unprofessional. In the end, I went back to Florida. The parks closed and our vert ramp became thrashed quickly in the Florida heat and humidity. That was the end.

item.title: Confusion / Alarm Pools
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_16516" align="aligncenter" width="584"] What we all must do sometimes.[/caption] My friend Jonathan Hay at Confusion sent this little nugget of joy and I post it up for your edification. Please click below and have a read. - Ozzie ALARM POOLS

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks Ozzie and Jonathan!

item.title: alarmpools3-600x600
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: What we all must do sometimes.

item.title: Rise and Fall of the Roman
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Like phantoms into the ages lost has the CimbrianÂ nation passed; destiny shifts like summer clouds on Grecian hilltops massed. Untold centuries glide away, Marius long is dust; even eternal Rome has passed in days of decay and rust. But memories live in the ghosts of dreams and they still come to me, and I still see the gleam of her golden hair and eyes like the deep gray sea. - Robert E. Howard The Roman The Roman. It came into our lives and burned bright as the sun while it remained. Like all great things, it wouldnât last. The story of its discovery is lost in the mists of time. Rumor has it as being found by Riverside Ed. Who knows? Who can tell? My initial query was met with silenceâ¦. Â and so it goes. Subsequently, I heard Riverside Ed, Mike Lopez, Ripperside Kevin, Brandon & KB all drained and cleaned it for the first time. It was- ââ¦. filled with solid sludge. Someone had changed their oil and dumped it into the pool. There were metal rods, trash and a bowling ball in there. We recovered a family of frogs from the pool and relocated them as well.â
Riverside Ed and Mike Lopez- day one
KB - first ollie transfer
That is all I have learned and I am left to tell you this tale. I heard faint rumblings last summer when I was recovering from my fractured collarbone. âThe Roman-end is insane!â âThe lines are incredible and the transitions are perfect.â Salba told me that he could ride it like a half pipe and that the trannies were super-fun though the pools surface was a bit slippery. âIt needs an acid bath or somethingâ¦â Salba added. Within a few weeks, I found myself pulling up beside the house. I was with Riverside Ed, Salba, Lance Mountain & Brian Fick. It was August and the sun was a scorcher! The pool sat on an old sprawling property in the middle of nowhere. A huge palm tree shaded the shallow end and a horse barn lay at the other end of the yard. Everything was in a state of neglect and disrepair. It was quiet. Heat simmered off the pools blue painted surface. I walked into the pool and looked it over. The paint was so slick that I slid on the pools waterfall just walking down into the deep end. Salba brought out some orange soda and Lance and I began to spread & mop it around on the surface. It dried quickly and we could feel the surface becoming grippier immediately. Sweat was running into my eyes so Lance cut off some T-shirt sleeves and made us what he and Blender called- âSleeviesâ for our heads. It worked and I still have mine.
Salba, Lance and me - orange aid
Lance and Salba - cleanup
The pool was strange. It had meatloaf coping on the facewall Roman cup but had 4-finger gnar Anthony coping on the rest of the pool. It looked like a damn ledge up there! I peered over at the deathbox and wondered how I was going to get over it. Salba saw me looking and smiled. He had done it both ways on a previous visit and I could see that the deathbox was heavily hammered already. I mumbled- âWellâ¦. Â if thatâs the way it gotta goâ¦â Walking out of the pool, I saw that the Roman deep end cup was higher than the side walls. It gave the pool a step-down edge for transfers. âThat could be interesting.â- I thought. Â Salba pushed in and drew the high line. When I say that he ruled the Roman, you better take my word for it.
Salba - tail tap over an icy descent
Lance - FS Air transfer
He slipped into the speed and pulled tailtaps, BS airs from high to low and did the box both ways in one line. Lance immediately launched FS air transfers from deep end cup to side wall, did the deathbox Â and pulled super floaty BS ollie transfers onto the side wall. It was an amazing session. Riverside Ed hit the facewall hardâ flowing everywhereâ and I finally made the deathbox and ended it all with a BS air over the same. That 4-finger Anthony coping can sure bonk you around!
me - BS Air deathbox
The pool became slippery again so Riverside Ed and I came back the next Saturday and painted it with supplies donated by Ripperside Shawn. The paint helped so much and the subsequent sessions were amazing. We rode it as often as possible through the hot summer months. Dust and heat. Sweat. Gallons of water.
Riverside Ed- the shadow tells the story
Salba - FS deathbox on a 4-finger jut
The property fell into the hands of a new owner. It was cleaned up a bit, fenced off and large angry dogs occupy the backyard. The pool sits empty and the horse stable and barn are filled with flies and moldy straw. A small rundown bath house sits next to the pool. The paint is blistered and the plumbing virtually gone. A door sags on its hinges and creaks in the breeze. It reminds me of the fleeting nature of all things. The pool, the house, friends, families, countries, empiresâ¦. life.
end of the line?
that horse doesn't look too happy with a cowboy behind it...
"When in Rome...."
Thank you to Riverside Ed for finding the Roman. Thank you to the crew for draining it. Thank you to Ripperside Shawn for the paint. Thank you to MRZ, Brandon Wong and Brian Fick for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Gem - story of the roman end is long over due. Couldn't be a better cast either.
What a great looking hole in the ground. Bitchen find. Transitions are amazing. The coping is like your having to slap a sharp curb.
Awesome. I imagine US Bombs "Skater Dater" playing in the background as I sit and watch in awe. Thank you for writing these so us east coasters can feel the stoke Ozzie

item.title: Hold On To What You've Got
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
They gathered on the horizon like a black plague. Leprous. The end of all good in this world. The buildings had turned to dust. The stars burned out. I shivered. I lit a small fire and checked the shotgun. I had five shells in and nine extra. If they came again, I'd have to be careful. This would probably be it. The last attack had been brutal. They fell back and watched as I hacked one to pieces with a shovel, lit his head on fire and stuck it on a stick as a warning. I shrieked at the godless sky in primitive fury. I don't think they liked that too much but I didn't really care what they thought. Â They pushed and now I was pushing back. I pitied them. Outside the house, Â I could hear them gathering... Â grunting, shouts, screams of the dying. Those that have escaped told stories of mind-bending horror. "They were peeling the skin off..." Â I stopped such thoughts and prepared myself. I took my long Gerber Mark II knife and slit my forearm lengthwise. Rivulets of blood ran onto the floor. I was surprised at the color. In the dim light it was black. "Well, one of my past lovers had called me a black-hearted bastard... I guess she was right." I mumbled to myself and chuckled. Taking two fingers, I smeared blood across my cheeks and face. I put on my war paint as it was time to take a stand. Picking up the shotgun, I heard the rush of approaching feet as the door burst inward in a shower of wood and violence...
Grant caressing some lady finger under the glare of a San Burn wilderness
I woke up with a start... Â my phone was buzzing. A truck rumbled through the intersection outside. Clawing at my phone, silence soon reigned again at Ridiculous. I peered at the time. 5:53 am. I pulled myself from the bed and made coffee. I shook my head to clear away the remnants of a nightmare world. What dreams I sometimes have! I mumbled and stretched as I looked at the pool in the backyard. Pool pals were coming to visit. Devin Scott, Theo Van Bruggen, Grant, Jen, Josh Nelson, Brandon, MRZ, Chelsea and Al would be over at around nine am. Ridiculous resident and all around ruler- Â Bunk- was getting up and ready as well. I drank coffee and listened to Massive Attack - Angel... Â memories of apocalyptic battle faded with the growing dawn.
Josh Nelson- rock-n-roll
Bunk- light box
Chelsea Castro- first grinds in a backyard!
Al Brunelle- punishing zombies and killing it!
The crew arrived and everyone was really stoked to be going out and skating. We wanted to get an early start as the temperature was already in the nineties. By noon it was going to be a brain burner. We loaded up and headed out. First pool. Fire pool. Everyone jumped in and swept and cleaned. The girls surprised everyone and quickly put lines down. Chelsea pulled her first grinds in a backyard pool. Devin, Theo and Grant threw down light box and Al hammered disasters and other insanity. Josh Nelson pulled rock-n-rolls and Bunk crushed light box. MRZ took some amazing photographs but the heat was already beginning to take its toll.
Devin Scott mauled the Triple Bubble...
Brandon Wong- deathbox... all day long.
Theo giving up some High Fivage
We headed out and stopped for refreshments. Cool beverages. Life. The next pool was going to be the Triple Bubble. Theo had been wanting to get into the Bubble since he saw us drain it last summer on the BTO. It was his turn and after a sweep and a quick cleaning, he didn't disappoint. Side cup grinds, deathbox lappers and all around ripping were put in under the heat. The Triple Bubble has a big tree that provides welcome shade and we were all posted up trying to take advantage of this fact. Brandon Wong decided that he wasn't going to stay on his BS deathbox attempt. The promise of a "High Five Parade" from everyone changed his mind. Minutes later, that ghost was slaughtered. Good stuff! Regardless, the heat was intense and after everyone had a good session, we headed out again... Â San Burn Gnar Dino. It lived up to its name.
Theo punched the shallow end silly... FS 5-0
Josh Nelson wasn't playing around at all... BS Ollie
Jen dropped her brew just long enough to put the drop on this BS Gnarler
Big Al with a big Heelamonster- Yikes!
friends- hold on to what you've got... it could be much worse.
I had to leave and deal with some things but Bunk took the crew over to a nearby pool for a ten minute quickie but by then, the heat had really become unbearable. The entire day made me think of a few things. My dream had been fresh in my mind. It was of a bleak world. A world of no happiness, no love, no friends... only despair and violence. I have been around the world. I have seen things. People live in a violent world right now! War. Conflict. Catastrophe. It made me think that we might want to hold on to what we have. What we have is far better than what is brooding on the horizon. Fini. Thanks to the crew and to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Awesome pictures! Wild dream. Immaculate post. Really REALLY enjoy your writing ...
Josh kills it. Fast. Fun to watch skate. Good pictures and another good write up.

item.title: Stacy Peralta / Concrete Wave
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Stacy Peralta This photo of me is at the Concrete Wave skateboard park Â - one of the first skateparks built in the greater LA area, certainly the closest to Santa Monica at the time. Â It was primarily a banked wall park as they hadnât yet designed pools for skateparks yet. Can you believe that? Â Pools came a bit later. Â In fact this park eventually did build a pool that many of us had high hopes for but it turned out to be completely un-ride-able.

item.title: Stacy Peralta / Pomona Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Stacy Peralta I believe this photo is from the Pomona pool which was on the side of an apartment parking complex. Â It was a very tight egg shaped pool. Â You can see from my left arm how much projection was required and how tight that pool was to get to the top and roll the coping. Â It was essentially a one-pump pool which so many pools were like back then. Â You had one-pump to get up up the other side of the pool wall and so many skaters were unable to do that as it required a lot of strength and exact timing. Â If youâre timing was off you made it only halfway up.

item.title: Stacy Peralta / Corral Pool Wood Block
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Stacy Peralta I believe this photo of me is from the Valley pool that we got introduced to by Jerry Valdez. The Corral Pool. In fact that is how we met Jerry. Â It was either in the back of a condemned home or in someoneâs backyard who didnât mind us skating there, I canât remember. We were always trying to get higher in the pools we rode so building wood extensions back then became very popular for a while.

item.title: Stacy Valley Pool Wide Below B_W
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz

item.title: X
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: They didn't have a name for what he was. He wasn't the sum of his parts. His last visit to the hospital hadn't been a very good one, but they usually never were. His stay on a 5150 hold, seemed to last longer than seventy two hours. The police had picked him up in Pomona. He tried explaining that he was only walking past the elementary school. "The children approached me... " Â he protested to the arresting officers. He was listed as a Danger To Others. Psychiatrists tried their little tricks. He was adept at turning them around. Glib. He knew what to say... He buckled his pants and put his t-shirt back on. Stepping over the body, he took one last look around the place. Details. The red blood had dried and darkened. Brownish clumps clotted on the baseboards. Moving back to the bathroom, he grabbed a towel and ran it hastily over the doorjambs, furniture and things. Turning the air conditioner to 60 degrees, he took the towel and trash with him as he left. San Bernardino baked under the hot August sun. A bus had carried him past the 215 freeway and up an offramp. He rose at the next stop and stepped into the afternoon. He was drowsy from his activities all night. His latest 'art project' hadn't gone quite the way he planned. It didn't tell him that it loved him. He painted with it until the gurgling ceased. Death is death. He was it. He chuckled as he recalled a stupid film: 21 Grams. "MacDougall needs to have his head examined." he snorted, referring to Dr. Duncan MacDougall's futile attempt to prove the immortality of the human soul by weighing people before and after death. MacDougall observed that there was a twenty one gram difference after death. "Fucking scientists..." With his mind a cauldron, he plodded on. The sun seeped into him and he headed north, walking up the main street. He had to find some shelter and sleep. Thugs and workers thronged the 7-11 market on the corner. Some sold vice and others bought it. In the end, he didn't think it really mattered... Â Misery was the norm. He sipped a Slurpee and stepped back onto the street. A few blocks over, he saw a small house that sat back in the trees. Old newspapers littered the dry lawn and it looked empty. The street was still. It slumped under the sun. He moved past the side of the house. Broken furniture and scattered clothing lay inside. Spiderwebs covered the porch railings. He forced a window up and crawled inside. No electric. No water. It had sat for months. Old mail lay in a pile by the mail slot in the door. He moved upstairs to the top floor and slept in a corner that was shaded by a huge tree. A noise woke him up. He had been dreaming of razor blades and he -Â absently -Â felt himself with his hand. He had a hard on... The noise was coming from a house adjacent to where he was. He moved to the window as he heard it again. "What the...?" Â Then he saw. Through the tree branches, he saw that the neighboring house had a swimming pool. It was empty though and there were kids riding scooters and stuff in it... "Jesus! That's all I need. Cops will come and be all over the place." He peered at them through the dirty window. [caption id="attachment_16560" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Nolan Munroe[/caption] They laughed and seemed pretty unconcerned. They acted like they belonged there. It was weird. He watched one of them fly up in the air on a skateboard and roll back down through the swimming pools deep end. It was pretty impressive but he needed to leave. [caption id="attachment_16561" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Paul Luc Ronchetti[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16562" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Sam Beckett[/caption] Gathering his things, he slipped outside. As he was walking up the street, he saw one of the skateboarders watching him from the wall. Their eyes met. The skater didn't look away... He moved up the street as quickly as he could. He needed to sleep and gather his strength. His artistic Masterpiece was waiting out there for him.... somewhere. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That was the beginning of a great movie...your writing is mesmerizing...love it...even the dark stuff.
Wow, that's a pretty dark post contrasted on a bright IE story and knowing how cheerful Nolan is. Fun read nonetheless.

item.title: Jay Smith / Hester Series
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_16567" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay Smith Hester Series Whittier[/caption] Jay Smith "To be quite honest, I never really liked contests, but the Whittier Hester contest was one of them where I did pretty well. I don't really know why. I didn't like the compulsory runs. They killed me. Compulsory runs just seemed to take away the freedom of skating to me. The only thing I did enjoy about contests, were the sessions in the days leading up to the event. The best skating always happened on the practice days. Heavy sessions. Everyone was pushing each other hard. On contest day, it was organized. We had to go in order and the waiting just took it out of me. The contest was structured and boring... we waited and waited and then had to take our turn. By then, our pads were dry, our muscles no longer ready, we were stiff, especially if we had slammed practicing... It just wasn't for me. The fun was always present in the days before an event. The sessions, parties and everything. Compulsories killed that for me. I'm a pool skater, not a robot. I simply couldn't do some of those tricks and I didn't want to. I'm never going to learn a trick that I don't want to do. The skateboarding of a contest just seemed to lack pizzazz." - Jay Smith Thank you to Jay Smith for his memories and Glen E. Friedman for the image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hey Ozzie Just Checking in to see your OBSESSION. Thanks for keeping your heart in soul on 4 wheels! JAMI

Now what is really great about this photo is...Jay looks like he is relaxed in a hammock in Fiji waitin' for a mojito as he is chillaxin!... waiter please....a little more lapover mix in my drink. This guy just ruled on these. Jayboy is somethin' else. We knew and we saw.

Jay is the best ever at laybacks-but thanks Shogo! I really appreciate his skating the most because Jay always comes in hot! Burning up whatever he skates with manic, almost cartoonish speed! Ask anyone who's skated with him in the 2000's and they'll tell ya...he's super fast! That's why he didn't like all the back and forth compulsory type runs full of tricks and treats to blow his speed!!! Hail Jay "The Layback Master" Smith
:v
Yeah brother, yeah !
Jay Smith. Nobody throws down a cooler layback. Nobody.

Such a epic photo! Look at all the classic goods in this photo - Powell Beamer, indy coper, Powell tailbone pad, Sims Gloves and Mad Rats. Plus, the trick itself is so insane -- every photo of Jay Smith is a pleasure to see.
If the layback had been a compulsory, you woulda taken it all Jay. Thanks for the 1st person feeling of being a participant in skating history. You the true layback maestro.

item.title: Wes Humpston remembers Bob Biniak
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Bobby Biniak. I knew Bob for over forty years. He was the bestÂ and he was a good friend. Bob was always fun to hang or skate with. He was always funny, laughing & truly a bigger than life character... Â  He ripped from the very early days of banks, parks & pool riding with a surf style and a wicked frontside snap. He could hang it out on a hip or take it into the shallow ends of pools where not many could at that time...
R.I.P. Brother...

item.title: Wes Humpston remembers Baby Paul Cullen
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Baby Paul's folks and mine knew each other from the 1960's in an Irish soccer club. Fast forward to the mid 1970's and this little raggedy ass blond kid would be ripping the banks on some piece of shit board and was just skating circles around older kids with the newest setups! Ha! Â Many times at pools, he would borrow someone's skate and show them how to ride it. Good luck getting it back. He did it to me many times. Â I remember Paul was always up to something and messing with someone. He was always starting all kinds of shit and Kent Sherwood once told me that the most dangerous two kids to ever put together were Baby Paul & Jayboy!
R.I.P. Little Brother

item.title: Billy Yeron remembers Dennis Polar Bear Agnew
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: He was ten years old when we met and I was thirteen. We both had just started surfing. Â I looked over and saw him there. Short, chubby, ruddy with no wetsuit, and there he stood burning paper in a trash can to keep warm. Dennis Polar Bear Agnew grew up to dominate the next generation of Z~Boyz. He joined the Z~Flex team at a young age, and he dominatedÂ  surfing and then went on to be one of the best tattoo artist in Venice, California. Polar Bear lived a short but sweet life and that's how I remember Bear.

item.title: Sammy Durick- Kona Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Sammy Durick Gunnar Haugo took me out to the Kona Bowl. He said that it was "Top Secret and no one could know." It was out by Hale avenue and Harmony Grove road in Escondido. We'd show up at the pool and everyone would get out and watch. The sessions were usually, Gunnar, myself, Lee Jesperson, Steve Archer, Jim Sigurdson, Jon Warneke and Jeff Tatum. The house had burned and was gone if I recall. We could pull the car right up to the pool, turn up the stereo and smoke weed and skate for hours. It went on for a few years I think. Steve Archer lit the coping on fire once... We also had Coleman kerosene lanterns that we'd set around the deep end so we could skate at night. I also remember that I did something back then which really stands out in my mind. I went surfing in the morning, skated Kona Bowl in the early afternoon and then drove up to Big Bear Mountain to go snow skiing at night. I did all three in one day. That was pretty special. I recall showing up at Kona Bowl and we felt like kings... There was a mutual respect felt by all of us.

item.title: Smolder
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The fire started in a dry riverbed just east of San Diego. Smoke blackened the sky and when one looked up, it seemed for certain that the end had come. The death of dreams. Finality. The fireman arrived as residents were leaving. The lonely battle. The uncommon dark. Helicopters. The crackle and hissing... Smolder. Afterwards, the media pointed its fingers. Who? How? Does there have to be a reason? Sometimes the world simply breaks. It gives us things to do... Houses were gutted and the dead black earth slept. A man on a nearby hillside looked over the remnants of his property. Ash colored his world. He kicked at a charred photograph album and decided then and there to build again. Spinning on his heels, he walked towards his truck. He passed by the huge Blue Haven cement swimming pool and noted that it was the only thing left virtually unscathed. Fast forward forty years. A small ranch house now stood on the lot. The long rolling hills and sun-split boulders stretched away unimpeded into the distance. Neighbors were still a rarity and the area remained desolate. Remote. The dusty road leading to the house was festooned with rusting barbed wire fences. It stated clearly: No Trespassing. The old man had rebuilt after the fires, his kids had moved on and started families themselves. He grew old and eventually passed away. Â The property changed hands. The house became a renter.Â It fell into disrepair and occupants cared little for the home. They squandered long nights with their crime in their veins. Vice. They had long ago given up on doing any real good in this world. They moved through life in a vacuum. Â Rent was spent on escape. The owners saw no way out. The property suffered. The house soon became a bank foreclosure. Seven months later, Billy Green sat by the side of a country road and looked at the list in his hand. He shook his head in annoyance. Turning the truck around, he soon pulled in at the start of a long meandering dirt road. It arced up and out of sight. "I guess this must be it..." He drove slowly. Billy cleaned up foreclosure properties. It was his job. He skated pools and did the best he could do. Don't we all? He saw the house as he pulled to the top of the hill and looked over the recent foreclosure that had come his way. He slowly walked the property. It was a mess. Seeing a long dark wooden fence, Billy spotted pool tiles! Â He rushed forward. "All the way out here!?" Â He looked at the pool as it spread out on the back of the property. He couldn't believe it. The pool was actually bigger than the house. Strange. The Blue Haven was deep in black water. Frogs were in the water and it reeked from a few feet away. The transitions looked massive. Billy made some phone calls. He would need help.
Billy Green - crail
John Torchia - method
Tyler Martin - lien melon
Kyle Berrard- gets in on a secret session and gets a one-up on the jacuzzi lip
Billy called in some friends and the cleanup began in earnest. Brian Fick, Ripperside Shawn, John Torchia and Mike Lopez all joined Billy in the draining mission. The pool was a mess. To all appearances, it hadn't been used for its intended purpose in a long time. Decades. The crew laughed as the water and muck were pumped away and the pool's secrets were revealed. It was stellar. They kept it to themselves and rode it for a few months. The area is virtually uninhabited. They were left alone. Eventually, it needed paint and the crew gave her a fresh new skin. The pool was a secret. It was kept that way. The big Blue Haven sat so far out in the wilderness that it was a journey just to get there. The crew rode it for a few more months then it sat again. Neglected. Wasps and frogs moved back in. The house squatted there... the years moved by.
filthy lady
Ripperside Shawn and I crawled through the mist in my truck. It was winter and the mountains were cold this early in the morning. The Blue Haven lady waited. We drove up the long dirt lane. Shawn was going to check the pool for the first time in a few years. I had never been there. As we approached the house, we saw a car in the driveway and a trailer parked nearby. Surprise. Defeat. "Damn!" I frowned into the morning... Â Shawn said little but his disappointment was evident. "Well, lets go... its gone." I told Shawn to wait a minute. I wanted to --at least-- look at this pool that I had heard so much about. Â I got out of the truck and as I approached the house, I saw a man walking towards me. I smiled and waved. As it turned out, this man had bought the property. We told him the story. Pools. Skating. He seemed intrigued. He let us drain it then and there. He shared in our stoke. The pool was thrashed. Elements and neglect had taken a heavy toll. Shawn and I spent several weekends draining, sanding and painting the pool. We rode it and kept the crew tight.
Ripperside Shawn- putting in the work.
Ripperside Shawn, John Torchia and Pepper... painting.
Ripperside Shawn- feeding the bird
the original crew reuntited
We decided to get some pals together after we painted it and have a fun little session. We got the original crew together and had Billy Green, Brian Fick and the others all in for some fun. Sometimes... Â you can go back and do it all over again! Â One day the owner said that he knew nothing about skateboarding but he knew who Tony Hawk was. Surprise? Since this man had shown us so much kindness, I made a phone call. Tony Hawk, Josh Stafford, Brian Fick, Lance Mountain and Kevin Staab all rolled out together. The owner was so happy. He couldn't believe it.
Tony and Lance
Josh Stafford - hanging one high
Tony- front rock
The session was fun. Everyone fought to keep their speed on the big transitions and there was quite a bit of laughter to be found. Tony Hawk didn't play around. Rock-n-rolls, backside airs, tailblocks and ollies were thrown down in quick order. Lance rode like a champ. Inverts and loveseat frontside airs went into the books. Stafford killed it all day... We rode for a few hours and it was inspiring to see Staab, Stafford, Hawk and Mountain all rolling around in a backyard pool. I must admit that I was very pleased to have had a small part in making such a thing happen. In the end, good things went down. The sun dropped over the hillside and the wind picked up. Everyone left in good spirits. In the past, there was a bit of bad juju associated with the property. Fire. Loss. Drug use and neglect. Skateboarders flipped it all on its head. After sessions like these, we can make things right. Karma debt is paid. Peace falls once again over a quiet San Diego hillside. The birds are free and they run these grounds....
Lance- invert on a tall wall
Kevin Staab - crail
Tony Hawk- tailblock
Thank you to the original crew. Thank you to Chuck for allowing this to happen. Thank you to everyone involved and special thanks to Brian Fick for the images. Skate- Ozzie

so cool!

Reblogged this on GÃ¸Î·Ñ ã Skaâ Ã®Î·g and commented: Smolder
totally cool...that is how it should be!!!Good Job!
Billy is an incredible pool finder, worker, skater & human in general. Glad you got in on that 1 Ozzie & brought the property some amazing juju. Gr8 read & as always gr8 eye candy Fick.

item.title: Tom Wally Inouye / Corral Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tom Wally Inouye I think this was the first time shooting with the Sharp brothers. We had been riding Reseda skatepark a bunch and that is where I met Jerry Valdez, Kent Sentatore and David Ferry. Jerry and Kent invited me to come skate the Corral Pool with them and the Sharp brothers. At this time I was just starting to skate for Sims and Tracker. All I remember is that the Coral Pool was unreal and both Jerry and Kent were ripping. Jerry would do these insane tailblocks...

item.title: Tom Wally Inouye / Oasis
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tom Wally Inouye This photograph is from the halfpipe at Oasis Skate Park under the 805 freeway in San Diego. It looks to be around 1979, when I was skating for Caster and Gyro wheels.Â We would troop down and skate Oasis from where we were riding at the Del Mar Skate Ranch. It was the park where Doug Pineapple Saladino, Dave Andrecht, and a bunch of the G&S boys would skate. I mostly remember skating the halfpipe and the egg shaped pool.

item.title: Tom Wally Inouye / Marina
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tom Wally Inouye The back keyhole of Marina Del Rey. What a great park this was, as it offered so much different terrain. When the Dogbowl was being heavily sessioned, we would venture up to the back keyhole and skate with all the upcoming groms like Christian Hosoi.

item.title: Tom Wally Inouye / Pipeline Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tom Wally Inouye Pipeline Combi Pool. What else is there to say? Â If you weren't there, you really missed out. Some amazing sessions occurred with amazing skaters.Â Progression was being pushed everyday, hands down. I met life long friends there. The Hoffman's ruled it and they ran IPS out of Upland.

item.title: William Sharp Book Project / Update
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_16620" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brad Bowman over the deathbox at the Fishbowl. AKA- Pink Motel. 1979[/caption] "Don't let dreams always be dreams." - Delmar Collins William Sharp Book Project. We've come a very long way in the past year. First, we had to buy a high-end scanner for color slides and B&W negatives and then we had to sort and separate thousands of images. William spent a few months over the winter, scanning and putting photographs in order. I started doing the questions and collecting stories. We have completed the preliminary image selections for all of the major sections in the book. I'm finishing up the writing this week through next and then we only have to trim down and complete the publication image selections from those we've not already eliminated. I've finished editing stories and anecdotes from some of the greatest names in skateboarding. The list includes: Tony Alva, Steve Olson, Brad Bowman, Jay Smith, Jerry Valdez, Kent Senatore, Scott Foss, Eddie Elguera, Pineapple Saladino, Dennis Martinez, Arthur Viecco, Dave Ferry, Jay Adams, Duane Peters, Steve Caballero, the Alba brothers, Kevin Anderson, David Hackett, Stacy Peralta, Wes Humpston, Jim Muir, Tom Wally Inouye, Shreddi Repas, Gunnar Haugo and the Kona Boys, the Dogtown crew, Rick Blackhart and Teddi Bennett, among others. Its almost ready. Â Labor of love. This is a dream coming true for me... Â I love skateboarding. Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: No Lonnie Toft???
Rad, really looking forward to it. You do a killer job with Blue Tile Obsession so it's a great combo. Whos' doing the layout???

item.title: The Grid
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
there is no elevator. one must take the stairs.
The day before had been a hot one. San Burn Gnar. It lives up to its name. I stretched out and ran. My lower back hurt and I felt old. After my workout, I figured I would do some grid work. Concrete miles. Foreclosures. "Are you down with OPP?" Â Yeah, Â  Other People's Properties. You know me... I drove a few streets and squinted into the sun. The problem with getting up at 4:30 am... Â is that by noon, I've already done everything that I need to do. It makes the evening feel almost out of reach.
sliding in
I drove and drank water. Katatonia growled from the speakers. "The Dead End King is here..." It seemed fitting. An old lady sat on a porch and stared idly into the morning sun. She had an oxygen tank beside her and the thing was sending oxygen to her nose through a clear plastic tube. In her hand was a smoldering cigarette. Dangerous. She was one of the doomed. A shadow passed across her face. She looked up startled and caught my eye as I drove slowly past. I felt for her. Her house was old and paint-blistered. An old car sat dusty and rusting in the driveway. She looked rumpled. Her life had passed her by and I was reminded of something I had read. "It's hard to answer the question "What's wrong?" when nothing is right."
life and its obstacles
gone...
I continued on. I found a few good pools. The yards were a mess. Most of the people had pulled out and left. Most of what was left remaining was junk and trash. Detritus. The Obama administration doesn't seem to ever see such sights. I step around children's clothing, family photographs, mattresses and plants wilting in the hot sun. Maybe our government should take care of us instead of themselves for a change. I drove on into the sun. It was time to think happier thoughts.
Count Lurkenberry
The streets were surprisingly empty. Weekend. Early. I thought of my friends... Â my real friends. People that love me for the person I am. I thought of Angelo and his pool. I laughed to myself as I remembered something Lance Mountain had said. I took phone calls from TA, Jim Howell, Jerry Valdez and Jonathan Spooner. I reflected on life and all that is good in it.
hope
In the end, I made it home. I found some new things and spent the morning in an Â introspective way. Perhaps by seeing the bad in the world, I am reminded to stay positive and send good vibes out on a constant basis. I will not be one of those that get stuck in the stagnant pool. Complacent. I don't own a television yet I still would refuse to believe its lies and nonsense. "While there's life, there's hope." - Cicero Skate and stay positive- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Tom Fain taught how to find Empty Pools...Google Earth. It's amazing how many are right in our own neighborhoods.....Satellite view !!! Then you can zoom down to the street view and you are set.

item.title: Buena Vista Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Buena Vista- in happier times? I beg to differ... the pool is much happier now.
Words. No one reads them. We only look at the pictures, give them a thumbs up and forget them. Yet, I won't believe it is all for nothing. I cannot. I won't. Stories are important. It gives things meaning. I've said it before and happily repeat it here. "Sometimes it isn't important that all of the facts of a particular tale are true. It is only important that we continue to tell it."
Buena Vista
The great stories. I've been hearing a good number of these as I interview the 1970's and early 1980's riders for the William Sharp book project. It makes me believe. I know that what we are doing matters. It must. We were in San Jose last week. Do you want to talk about a story? I heard that the old Buena Vista pool was going again. The locals dug it up and maintain it. This pool has longevity. Virtually everyone knows about Buena Vista. Many have ridden it. Video parts have been made there and legends have cruised its long shadowed walls. MRZ and I woke up early one day and over breakfast decided we had better put some miles in and go check it out. Local Bill Ackerman was one of the first to ever ride Buena Vista pool. He swam in the pool as a kid as his parents were associated with it. Once the place burned in 1960, it soon found itself abandoned. In 1976, Bill and his pals rode skateboards in it. The pool began its glorious history then and there. We all owe a debt of gratitude to Bill Ackerman. He has been a mainstay throughout the pools life.
Buena Vista morning- Ray Zimmerman and I.
We drove over through the passes. Huge pine trees scraped the sky and the woods were thick and dark. Shadows and streaming sunlight made it seem surreal. We twisted and turned on the mountain road. Eventually, we pulled to a stop by a metal gate. I peered at my text message and directions again. "Metal gate. Park. Follow the waffle soles in the dirt." Ray and I did as we were told. We found her. She sat. Colorful. History. I stood in wonder. We wasted no time. We both were stoked and rode for an hour together.
MRZ can take great photographs... and he can skate!
it was odd riding a pool with no coping
After a time, some pals of mine called and said they would be joining us. Grant Nobel and Brian Armstrong were coming to ride. It was going to be fun. Once they arrived, we really got busy. Grant rolled in and out of the pool like he had been there before. His lien to tail slides were amazing. Brian pulled super quick lines throughout the pool and made shallow corner grinds as well.
Grant Nobel- lien to tail slide
Brian Armstrong- frontside shallow corner magic
Phone calls. A water break... Â it was growing hot. Grant and Brian wanted to go ride another pool and some other riders had just stopped by Buena Vista. We talked and then split off to go meet some friends at another permission... Â but that is a whole other story. Thanks to Bill Ackerman for the pool and its history and the session. Buena Vista has a good story. Thanks to Grant and Brian and MRZ. Stoked! Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: just hit that buena pool last week was great .

item.title: 'An early education' with Jeff Grosso.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4846" align="aligncenter" width="450"]
Jeff Grosso- Vans Combi 1998[/caption]
Brad Bowman- Upland Combi pool.
We were kids, days felt like years, there was plenty of time for everything, and everything was brand new. What do i remember? I was never very excited to go toÂ  Upland. It felt like more of a punishment than a reward, to my young mind. There was the brutal heat, smog, and harsh transitions... shit, not to mention the sand- paper surface. We'd beg for 'Skate City', but receive an all day pass to the 'Pipeline'. However, like i said... we were young and hyped! We'd spend our days battling heat stroke, drinking too much 'Mountain Dew', and following the younger locals around the park like lost puppy dogs! Chris Miller, Eric Jueden, Chris Robison, and Don Pollard became fast friends. While not scarfing down pizza grinders, we rolled in an endless train around the 15 foot bowl , jumping the hip, only to start all over again! We played tag in the snake runs, learned lip slides in the 8 foot bowl, and received an education on 'Combi' etiquette. Round shallow! These were times of innocence, and the progression flowed from us, as did the blood! I still have the scars. It was great! It sucked. It was an early education in the 'Badlands', and I learned from some of the best...GROSSO Thanks to Jeff Grosso for the memories & Jim Goodrich & MRZ for the images. 2010-Vans/Protec is coming. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: amissae rei
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Something lost. We've all experienced it. You long for something, fantasize and think, daydream and wonder... Â only to finally move to action and have the opportunity lost. We find pools often. We search and that is why. One has to drive systematically. One has to look for the signs. Â Eyes open for anything that can get you past a homeowners reluctance and fear. I use honeyed words and a glib tongue. I am an expert at reading human beings. Manipulation. A master. I am he. One has to watch for threats. Dogs. Drug dealers and users. Thugs... everyone's looking to make a name. I don't want to be the corpse over which someone stepped to get theirs.Â Caution. Sometimes, a pool is far from my home. I weigh it all out. This pool was found by a friend in December of 2010. He told me after he stopped and took photographs. Recon. Lay of the land. "It's sitting at the end of a cul-de-sac in a pretty high end neighborhood. The pool rests on a really big property and unfortunately sits in the very back left corner." I digested this bit of Intel and looked over the images. There was at least three feet of water in it. Also, it looked like someone had pushed one of the surrounding brick walls into the deep end. I ran an experienced eye over the rest of the photographs. There were cancer holes visible in the plaster of the waterfall directly below the hip. If these were present, I assumed there was other such damage beneath the brick piles and rain water. As good as the pool looked, it would take a great deal of work and money just to get it rideable. I put it off for awhile. A month became a few and a few became another year. As all things go... Â time climbed by. I would come upon the pool images from time to time, but never was in the area to invest what it would take to see the project through. I just figured that my window of opportunity was past. I drove over today. Wrought iron fence posts on red brick walls, wrapped the property. My eyes scanned the area, searching for the house that should've been there... Â but wasn't. I swore to myself. Dirt and thistles covered what was an opportunity, now lost. Life. Amissae rei. Â Thank you to Brandon Wong for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I would have GLADLY donated a weeks time and effort of cleaning just for the opportunity to take one RUN in a pool like that! Where I come from, pools are VERY few and far between, and those that do exist are almost always in a functioning home or motel or worse, vinyl.

We'd beg for Skate City Whittier, but receive an all day pass to the Pipeline. However, like I said... we were young and hyped! Chris Miller, Eric Jueden, Chris Robison, and Don Pollard became fast friends. While not scarfing down pizza grinders, we rolled in an endless train around the 15 foot bowl , jumping the hip, only to start all over again! We played tag in the snake runs, learned lip slides in the 8 foot bowl, and received an education on Combi etiquette. Round shallow! These were times of innocence and the progression flowed from us, as did the blood! I still have the scars. It was great! It sucked.
