item.title: Hobie Weaver Woody / Pepsi / Mike Weed
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Gregg Weaver- 'Massage pool'- 1977
I lived in a small place in Pennsylvania and in the summer of 1977, the Pepsi skateboard team came through. They set up a clear plastic U-Shaped half pipe, in the parking lot of the local JC Penney store. It was hot and sweltering, as only the northeast can become in June. Pennants and colorful Pepsi banners hung slack in the stifling heat. People milled about the large plexiglass ramp which was roped off and empty. A PA system was set up to one side and a technician fiddled with wires, duct taping them flat onto the ground.

The asphalt lot was hot and people grew restless. I skated around the periphery, trying to see anyone I might notice from Skateboarder magazine. So far, zilch. I noticed some greasy looking guy selling snow cones from a box truck. He was doing a brisk business. The way he eyed up the kids, made me uncomfortable, so I kept my two dollars tucked deep in my corduroy OP shorts. There were a bunch of fat people sweating it out and from the looks of things, should've found themselves a spot inside the glass-fronted JC Penney store. At least they would be cooler in there and wouldn't sweat and stink so badly. Damn! Â Even the store mannequins seemed to droop in the shoulders.

I skated around behind the ramp and that's when I saw them. Roy Jamison and Mike Weed were getting their boards out of a small van. I caught my breath. Mike Weed looked at me and nodded. If Roy Jamison did as well, I didn't notice. Mike Weed just nodded at me! Mike Weed! I couldn't believe it. Go ahead and call me a moron, but I hadn't seen a skateboard pro in my entire life. All I saw were magazine photographs of a life and culture far, far away. I stood there slack-jawed, I am sure. They slipped under a rope and crossed the bottom of the ramp out of my view.

I heard the PA system spark to life and the announcer began introductions. They began riding to music. I believe it was Foghat or some frizzy-headed, bell-bottom band similar to them. Â To be honest, I remember one -wheelers, forevers, Roy Jamison having such a rad style, and almost passing out when Mike Weed gave me a sticker. I recall little else. I know that I didn't sleep that night... not much anyway. The next day, I talked my mom into going to the JC Penney store with me. They sold the only skateboards in town.

They had a Hobie Weaver Woody for sale. It was $49.99. I rubbed my fingers across the smooth wood and smelled the red, urethane Power Paw wheels. The ACS 430 trucks mocked me... I only had $11.00. I must tell you, that I worked an entire summer in my fathers upholstery shop, to save up the rest of the money to buy that Weaver Woody. It came without grip tape, so I cut up strips of floor sand paper and glued them onto it. I rode that board into the ground until it was unrecognizable.

Gregg Weaver wasn't at that JC Penney demo, not that I can remember. His spirit was though. There are a few things that don't make sense to me now. Over thirty years has passed. I don't know why other Pepsi team riders weren't there and I only really recall Mike and Roy skating. I can't remember what I did with the sticker Mike Weed gave me. In my mind, it matters not one bit. He gave me a sticker....that is all that matters. When you are thirteen years old, and a poor skateboard kid from PA, that stuff stays with you forever. It is in my blood. Â I heard that Mike Weed passed away from cancer and it saddens me... Â R.I.P. Mike and thank you bro. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the Weaver image and Marlon Whitfield for the Woody images. Skate - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Awesome Ozzie - selective memory is better than none. They came to my elementary school twice as a kid and I have no specific recollections but I know they had a such impact on me wanting to sk8 for others to enjoy. Share the sport with kids. Is there anywhere to see who was on the Pepsi Team, years and / or demo listings?

Such a good read. I saw the Pepsi team (probably in 77 or 78?) when they performed at Knott's Berry Farm in the big theater there. It was so cool to see the wood and plexiglass ramp. After that I ordered a Pepsi helmet just like the one's the team wore. I have pics somewhere that I shot with my pocket 110 camera and I still have the Helmet in my collection.
-Aaron
That post brought a tear to my eye. Sweet memories!

item.title: diehard
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: He looked down. Black. Burnished. There was a gun in his hand. It wasn't the first time and he now understood how his bad side could burn. A smoldering soul. Looking through the front windows of the 7-11 store, he cursed at the police lined up in the street. This was no mercy show. Squad cars were row on row... standoff. End game scenario. His road to ruin. SWAT were on the roof across the street and he periodically saw them changing position. Silhouetted. "They should know better..." he mumbled, reaching for a beer from the six pack cooler behind him. His nerves were close to snapping like a dried up rubber band and thoughts scurried through his mind like ants. He couldn't think straight. "Damn!" The phone rang. He moved deeper into the shadows... "Yeah?" Stern voice. Police. Negotiations. The negotiator asked him if he was alone and once assured that he was, told him that he alone held the power. A safe outcome could only occur if he walked out now. "It is the right thing to do." he added. He let the line go dead after asking for some time. They said that they would get in touch with him in an hour or so. He didn't think the police would storm the building. They knew he was armed and obviously dangerous. The first police officer through the door behind him found out. He turned and shot him through the leg. Broken glass splintered across the room with his next two shots and fellow officers quickly dragged the wounded officer clear of the building and out to safety. Sweating and in a full-blown panic, he squatted behind an ice cream freezer, awaiting a furious assault that never came. His ears were humming. "Shit! Shit! Shit!" He cursed himself with fury. His heart hammered and his eyes darted frantically around the edge of the freezer. Watching. Waiting. After a time... loudspeakers. The police broke it down for him into easily digestible pieces. Surrounded. Doom. He knew that it was over for him. That had been three hours ago and they still tried talking him into leaving the building. Capitulation. He smirked under the glare of the nearby revolving police lights outside. "Surrender myself to what!? A cage for the next fifty years?" He didn't find such a prospect very appealing. Well, he had an hour left to figure things out. Things would be what they would be. Sitting on the floor, he couldn't quite comprehend how he had ended up here. He had a son... Well, his ex-girlfriend had a son. He had a restraining order against him, preventing his contact with the child and the mother. Once, they had been a happy couple. They had named the boy Charlie... he liked that name. Yet, a few short years of his being gone, not paying support and remaining, "A loser..." as she frequently referred to him, had shown them both that what little remained between them wasn't worth saving. A few days ago, he found out through her family that she had desperately needed money. Charlie's asthma was pretty bad lately, his health problems worsened and bills were piling up. He sat up all night and in the morning had found himself standing in front of the Comerica Bank. The bank opened, he walked in and slipped the teller a note. Things went fine. He barely spoke and simply showed her the pistol under his jacket. Compliance. A small cloth bag was slid across the counter and he stepped into the morning light outside. He made a straight line for his truck. The line quickly unravelled... Police. Running. People pointing and frantic. 7-11 loomed in front of him and in he went... Â they followed. In his mind, he had taken it to the end, where it begins. Munching on cashews, he set the pistol on the floor. He reached over and picked up a skateboard magazine off the shelf. He once skated. He missed it. Life had been so much better when his friends would get together and ride the bowls at the park. He paged through it as he tried to settle his nerves... He needed to stop thinking for a few minutes and calm down... "Whoa! This dude is pretty good." A photograph showed a skater named Brad McClain in a backyard pool. Youth. What had happened to his? He didn't know. He looked up from the magazine and thought of his friends and skating. Things sure were simpler back then. He shook his head at the thought. A chasm had opened up between what he was and what he had now become. It was probably better not to think on these things, as somewhere along the way, venom had taken up residence inside his heart. He had flipped the page. It was a full page photograph of McClain doing a huge hip transfer. Unreal.Â He set the magazine down and took a look outside. The police were still there, caught up in what they deemed to be right. Right? Them. Wrong? The rest of us. Well, they sure were stoic. Â "The waiting awaits them..." Â  He grabbed another beer and sat back down. He was feeling a bit less stressed. It would all be undone soon enough... The great end. He felt a strange calmness. He took a sip of his Corona and picked up the pistol again. He wiped it off and checked the magazine. Four rounds... "One for me and three for all of them." he murmured. Disturbed by such thoughts, he set the pistol on the floor between his feet. Â Looking at the clock, he rubbed his eyes and he tried not to sink... it was hard not to sink. He felt like he'd been sinking his whole life. Titanic. Not enough life boats... "How the fuck did it come to this?" Mumbling. Pacing. The store lights flickered and the isolation he felt was staggering. All he wanted to do was go back in time. He wondered if he should just run outside shooting. At least they'd kill him. It sure beat fifty ears in prison. It was hard to die. He was startled as the phone rang. It jolted him. "Yeah...." Negotiator. "Last chance kid. Make the right decision. You've made far too many wrong ones this day. Let's end this thing and set it right." He hung up. Silence fell and all he ever hoped to be would never come to pass. He knew it and it overwhelmed him. He started walking toward the door. He saw revolving lights. They momentarily lit his face in crimson. He wondered briefly of Charlie. His boy. Legacy. He hoped Charlie didn't see him being arrested on the evening news. His skin felt hot. Flushed. The pistol in his hand hung forgotten at his side. He saw movement as he approached the glass doors. Muzzles. Guns. He reached out with one hand. "It is hard to die..." He pushed the door open and stepped into his destiny. Thanks to MRZ and Deville Nunes for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Really intense story ...they shot him on sight. Right? If it was around here they did!

I love your writing style, intense is a great word for it.
Stories like this appealed to me back in my drinking and drugging days because I felt hopeless, misery loves company I guess. Now that I have been sober and have some hope and peace, they appeal to me because they remind me I don't ever want to go back

item.title: A Reason For Living.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Tyco- stoking himself and everyone else
James- the man in the three piece suit, couldn't believe what he was hearing. He stuffed a finger under his collar & loosened the top button. It had suddenly become hot & stifling. The man sitting across from him wasÂ  Steven Marsden. Steven Marsden was his boss at the accounting firm where he worked. Well, at least he had been his boss. Steven Marsden had just given him the bad news. He had been 'let go.'Â  He fumbled for words."Isn't there any other way?! I could work less hours... something?" Steven Mardsen fidgeted with a pen on his desk & looked away & out the window. The city spread out beneath them some 12 stories below. Buses looked small from this height & yellow taxis flitted & flew between them. He turned his gaze back to the man sitting across from him. This was a part of the job that really turned his stomach. Letting people go & laying them off was almost as uncomfortable for him as it was for them. Almost. He brushed a hand across his well-fed belly & had a momentary pang of ease. At least he was going to continue eating well. Uncomfortable silence. Averted gazes. Perspiration. Steven Marsden rearranged a few files on his desk & mustered up his courage. " No James. The board asked us to downsize & make certain cuts in administration & personnel. You've been here for the shortest length of time."Â  James couldn't believe what he was hearing. "Sir, I've worked for this company almost ten years! Ten years!" Steven Marsden was adamant. He wished James well. There was nothing he could do. He dismissed him & added that James would have to clear out his desk by days end. He walked slowly back into his office, mind reeling. "Jesus! It's a good thing Julie left with the kids!" His ex-wife had remarried & he spent a great deal of time looking at the silver framed photographs of his family. It was as though his life had stopped. He was in some obscene 'holding pattern'. His living room felt like a tomb. Old memories. Dusty shelves. Scrapbooks of images... reflecting broken pieces of himself. He fell back into his big black leather chair in his office & tried to form a plan. Nothing. He needed a drink...Â  but-- then again-- he always needed a drink. It made the long nights possible. It made the clock & its hours forget him. As far as he was concerned, Steven Marsden didn't know how he felt. He didn't care. "Damn!"Â  His job was all he had. He threw a few things into a boxÂ  and --avoiding the eyes of his co-workers--sidled out of the office & into the elevator. Later that night, he drank deeply. He awoke in a cloud. His head throbbed & he bumped around the house. He realized he didn't have coffee or anything to take away his headache. Looking over at a side table, he saw a half litre bottle of Dewars. He grabbed his jacket & left the house. Walking towards a store, he saw children playing with their parents nearby. He looked away. He heard the clickity-clack of wheels behind him & turned, just as a few skateboarders approached. They were dressed in torn up jeans & colorful tennis shoes. He stepped aside, they nodded & flew past him. He walked on as they disappeared around a corner. The sun was bright & he wanted some coffee. He idly wondered about his own children. He hadn't seen them in a week & missed them. Funny thing. He missed the noise, radios & bickering. He missed his boy, leaving hisÂ  toys on the driveway. He missed his daughters books laying everywhere. After they moved out, these had been the things he was glad they had taken with them. Yet the longer they were gone, the more he missed these small things. These are the things that made them who they were. He walked on & purchased some coffee & Tylenol from a 7-11. Slowly making his way home, he heard a strange swooshing sound coming from behind an ornate block wall. He stopped & heard voices & laughter. He peered through an opening in the blocks at the top. The skateboarders that had passed him earlier, were inside the yard. He recognized them & they were standing & rolling around inside an empty swimming pool! He walked back around to the front of the property & quickly saw that it was a home that was on the market. The 'For Sale' sign hung over the dry grass lawn. He walked back. The skateboarders seemed oblivious & they hadn't seen him. He coughed politely & they turned in panic. He waved & smiled. "May I watch?" he asked, taking a seat on a small brick ledge. The skateboarders seemed alarmed but nodded. "You the owner or something?" The tallest one of them asked, looking over at him & grinning.Â  "No. Not me. I just heard you & peeked in. I saw you & couldn't believe it." He took a sip of coffee & watched as one of them pushed in & rolled right up to the top & over the chrome light fixture. He found himself grinning...Â  He watched the skateboarders for a long while. They seemed so happy. One of them said that he was "Stoked!" He asked them what it meant. The tall skater explained that skating gave them a feeling that they couldn't get anyplace else. He turned to take a run inside the pool & stated, "Stoke is what makes life worth living." James wandered home after awhile. He thought about what he had seen that day. He thought about his children, his situation, his drinking. He had things that he loved to do, but he hadn't done them in a long time. He walked into the kitchen & automatically reached for a glass & some ice. The bottle of Dewars mocked him. He turned on his heel. Maybe it was time. He had been living in the past & it had consumed him. Maybe, by losing his job, he could start a whole new chapter...Â  He went to sleep sober that night . He thought of the skaters & the message he had heard. Stoke. He couldn't ride a skateboard, but he would find those things he loved to do & start doing them again. Before sleep took him, he knew that life would be better. He thought it funny, the things one can learn from a bunch of kids riding around on toys. Thanks to Rhino for the image of Tyco. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Stoke is back in my life. Its the best therapy. Its nice to wake up and be able to surf and skate without feeling like hell. Thanks.
Beautiful and inspiring. GOT STOKE? I'm stoked.

item.title: then
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I became inhuman. I would see children playing in the park. I don't rememberÂ being so naive. My cold blue eyes regarded them with a bit more toleranceÂ than I reserved for most of my species. The people that I saw in day to day life sickened me.Â But imagine, just imagine, if I truly had a mind to let myself off the leash! Heaven help thee. Â I knew deep inside that what I saw in them was the same weakness I saw in myself. I told my stories. Once they dried up there was still Â emptiness in residence... Â like a dark vulture wheeling above my life. The evening was red, as if someone had brandished a cruel blade and skinned the sky.Â Life became more like a dream than reality. IÂ walked in the woods to shake the mood. The branches were black andÂ bare... more dead than they should be. It seems that most of what I did was for naught. How do I explain my years lived in twilight to people that live inÂ daytime and hide away from the darkness? - Ozzie Thank you to Lucia Griggi and Brooks Sterling for the images. Skate- Ozzie Â

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I can relate to that..
No need to explain that to me! I am still there....beautiful....

item.title: Fishbowl / Memorial Photo & Art Show
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_16721" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Duane Peters[/caption]

FISHBOWL R.I.P.

Mark Zamudio put together a little trivia/memorial event at the Vicinity Skate Shop in Orange this past Saturday evening. The event had photographs from many different Fishbowl sessions over the years. It had really cool paintings and art by Nicole Dodson and others, photographs by MRZ, Brandon Wong and other great photographers. Mark Zamudio had gone by the Fishbowl when he found out that it was being destroyed and managed to collect broken pieces of our dream. He had them on display. Stellar.

[caption id="attachment_16723" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mark Zamudio[/caption]

[caption id="attachment_16724" align="aligncenter" width="584"] MRZ[/caption][caption id="attachment_16725" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Nicole Dodson[/caption][caption id="attachment_16726" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Skreech[/caption]

In 2010, Ben Butler and Jon Tucker managed to talk the owner Jeff, into letting us have a few more sessions. I was lucky enough to ride there with Ben, Duane, Arab, Chicken and others. Privilege. I asked Duane Peters and Arab about their personal memories from the Fishbowl over the years. I figure that it would be better to simply reprint their responses here.

[caption id="attachment_16727" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Fishbowl 1988[/caption]

Arab

âWe first started skating the pool back around 1976-77.Â  In those early years, the old lady that lived there would charge us fifty cents to skate.Â  Duane reminded me that it was fifty cents per hour and then I remembered she had an old cooking timer she would set for one hour and leave it in the kitchen window. When our time was up,Â  it was either pay another fifty cents or splitâ¦..Â Â Â In the early days you would get free tap water in a little Dixie cup,Â  but then when she realized she could make money on the water she would charge us ten cents for iced tap water in an eight ounce Dixie cup.â

âThe first time that I went to the Fishbowl, there was an old wooden fence surrounding the yard and I had jumped up to look over at the pool. As I pulled myself up, I pulled the fence right over onto myself! Â  It was fucking hilarious!!Â  We propped the fence back up and went around to the front and asked if we could skateâ¦â

âI donât know who originally found the pool. It could have been Arnie Hogue and his brothers, as they lived in the area. Arnie and his familyÂ moved away to Utah or something, before the whole pool contest thing started.Â  You ask anybody that knew him thoughâ¦Â  Olson,Â  DP or the Carrasco brothers and they will Â tell you, Arnie was one of the best pool skaters ever back then. Had he stuck around, he wouldÂ have probablyÂ won the Hester Series the first couple years. He was like Gerry Lopez on a skateboard;Â  so much style and so much power,Â  he owned the Concrete Wave pool and every other pool around Orange County in the 1970â²s.â

âBack toÂ Fishbowl. The pool saw some great sessions back then and it was a tough little pool to skate, because it was so tight. Later on, in the midÂ  to late 1980â²s, there was another resurgence of the Fishbowl.Â  By then, the brick wall that surrounds the pool was built and some of the littleÂ fishÂ that protruded from the plaster walls had been chipped off.â

[caption id="attachment_16730" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Chicken[/caption][caption id="attachment_16731" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ricky Barnes[/caption][caption id="attachment_16732" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chuck Hults[/caption]

âIn the early 1990's,Â  the house was sold and the guy that lives there now had moved in. He would not let anyone skate. I tried about every five years, knocking on the door and asking if I could skate.Â  One of his daughters would always tell me that their dad would âkill themâ if they would let anybody skate the poolâ¦â

âI stopped about a year ago and there were a bunch of potted plants in theÂ bowl and no answer at the door.Â  I didnât feel like barging by myself without a lookout, so I just chalked it up to another failed attempt. A couple months ago Ben Butler had told me about the guy that lived next door. Jon Tucker. He had a kinky square pool thing that they were skating and the owner of the Fishbowl was letting them skate his pool now. I was able to ride it thirty-five years later after my first session there. How awesome is that?" - ARAB

[caption id="attachment_16735" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jon Tuckers- Porkchop & neighboring Fishbowl[/caption][caption id="attachment_16740" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ben Butler proves himself handy at getting one over on the MOD[/caption]

Duane Peters

âThere was a really heavy local scene, back in the 1970s.â Every pool crew had their own spots and you didnât just cruise up on someone's pools. When we did try to go someplace else, we had to be careful. One guy would peek over the wallâ¦uh-oh! Heavy session going. We could hear the skating. One of us would hop over and feel out the scene. IfÂ  you got the ânodâ, you had to get in there and get someâ¦try and go all out! We always had a few pools in our pockets, that way we could trade with the locals. At Fishbowl there were a couple of Mexican guys that were rad. This one guy was doing ârock walksâ beside the deathboxâ¦later at Concrete Wave, there was quite a bit of argument regarding the rock walk or the cess slide. It all went back to the Fishbowl. Â Some of the earliest tailblocks were done there. The old lady living there, did have a kitchen timerâ¦she also had a little hourglass timer, if I remember clearly. That was a heavy localized scene though. Arnie Hogue was a rad guyâ¦really good. He did one of the first taildrops ever done on vertical. The Fishbowl was going before the Concrete Wave opened, I know that. That pool has been going for a long time. It was great to go back there.â - Duane Peters

[caption id="attachment_16741" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cam Dowse by Brandon Wong[/caption][caption id="attachment_16742" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cholo with the cookie Jar. It was filled with plaster pieces from the Fishbowl.[/caption][caption id="attachment_16743" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Nicole Dodson[/caption][caption id="attachment_16744" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Josh Borden[/caption]

FISHBOWL R.I.P.

Thank you to Jeff for letting us skate the Fishbowl. Thank you to the original pool rippers that discovered it and kept it going. Thank you to Jon Tucker & Ben Butler for this go around. Thank you to MRZ and ARAB for the images. Thank you to Arab and Duane Peters for the memories and for Mark Zamudio and Vicinity Skate Shop for doing things right. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Reblogged this on Skateboarding is Not a Crime.
Epic history..makes me want to skate it badly : ( ....great photos and legends galore.
If Duane Peters Says it's the shit than it is MOD approved. Wish I could have enjoyed it too.
Reblogged this on GÃ¸Î·Ñ ã Skaâ Ã®Î·g and commented: Memories Of The Fish Bowl

I grew up in Anaheim and spent many a quarter here in the mid seventies. I used to pick up Steve and Mike Hirsch in my '66 VW and try and grind that tight ass bitch. Wasn't there a patio cover between the fence and the shallow end back in the day? I remember a wood picnic table with the "water for sale" sitting on it? I'm getting old... Great story Ozzie

item.title: drive
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I drive. A ribbon of black asphalt stretches out like my thoughts. I'm reminded of my father when I was a small child. He sat reclining in our living room. The television was on and he smoked cigarettes and watched the Vietnam war news. His hands were calm. No tension. Legs stretched out in black trousers. A blue blur of smoke hung above him like a question mark. I stood to one side holding his leg with a tiny hand. Unknowing. Here I am years later. I drive. I think of skateboarding and those I know and love. I seek. Like any other person, I long for something... other than this. Why? Why am I so torn at times? I smirk at myself in the mirror and change the thread of my thoughts. Gripping the wheel, I turn into an old neighborhood. Poverty can no longer hide the hardness of her ravaging years. The economy has been poor for far too long. People are in despair. The whole world is crying. I see broken windows and trash. I pull to the curb. My experienced eyes run across the property. Walking the perimeter of the house, I assess for threats. Squatters. Dogs. Neighbors. I pull myself onto a side wall. Crumbling. I lay on top briefly. Pool. Black water. I make note of the transitions. There are signs that someone is living here. Back room. Rumpled blankets. Refuse. Empty bottles are everywhere. I laugh under my breath as I see a magazine near the makeshift bed. 'Juicy Booty'. I have a look... Â interesting. "Different strokes I guess..." I mumble to myself and soon find myself driving again. The world opens up to me. Mysterious. I wander and think. Isn't is odd how so few win and so many lose? The more I know, the less I need. Simplicity. I think back to my father all those long years ago. Stoic. He lived a Spartan life. His world was work and his children. We defined him. I down shift the truck and exit the freeway. A dirty sun drops on the horizon. It dips behind the trees and they stand silhouetted. Stark and gloomy. I drive. We rode the pool. In a confusing and sometimes dismal world, we try and set things right. The pool was lost to us just as fast as it was found. New tenants. New paint. An unfulfilled dream. I stopped and spoke with the new owners. It had been three years. An offer and an outstretched palm. Deal. We returned with friends. Happiness rose up like smoke. Stories were told. Laughter. [caption id="attachment_16753" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ripperside Shawn[/caption]
PLG, Chet, me, Sam and Al
Al Brunelle
Sam Beckett
Later that afternoon, I said goodbye to Pierre Luc Gagnon, Chet Thomas, Sam Beckett, Brian Fick and Al Brunelle. Climbing into my truck, I threw up my hand in farewell. It was a great day. The neighborhood looked brighter. The slumped shoulders of despair seemed lifted. Perhaps it is our individual mindset that makes things the way they are. We decide our reality. Â Thanks to MRZ and Brian Fick for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It is totally our mind set that shapes the world we see. Albeit what is going on around us can effect is, but our mindset will prevail. Great writing

item.title: Jon Warneke / Hilltop Roman
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jon Warneke Being part of the vertical movement was an incredible experience. Â We were constantly seeking new challenges. Â We had the Kona Bowl which was our local daily fix for shredding and pushing each other beyond the limits. Â But finding new terrain that was bigger, deeper, higher became our obsession. Â I would fly my fellow Kona Boys out of Palomar Airport in Carlsbad performing aerial sorties in search of empty pools, reservoirs, pipes, gutters, anything with vertical. Â The Kona Boys had a dual aerial assault during the vertical movement, one in the pool, the other in an airplane high above north San Diego county. Â We were building an unforgettable era while living in a vertical fantasy land.Â  Â

item.title: Jon Warneke / Date Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Jon Warneke

The Date Bowl was surreal. Â The Kona Boys would load up our cars for the road trip from the coast. Over the mountains and into the desert was an adventure in itself. Â We were living life to the limit, in a dreamland of limitless vertical, pumping each other up for the huge pool built and abandoned in the desert floor. Â The anticipation of shredding, experimenting with new moves that hadnât been developed, pushing the vertical movement beyond anything we could comprehend at the time was an awesome thing. The Date Bowl was an arena for the best vertical skaters in the universe from the Los Angeles area and San Diego. Â It was an adrenaline rush to jump into the shallow end of the Date Bowl as it would be full of the best skaters ever. It required huge confidence. You had to nail your first run or you would be shunned out of the Date Bowl, as there were no second chances! Â We shredded the place, set the pace and the standards for years to come.

item.title: Jon Warneke / Kona Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jon Warneke The Kona Bowl was a small, extremely vertical, tight pool that created and built the Kona vertical movement. Â The Kona Boys owned that pool. Â When we showed up, whoever was skating, would leave the pool and watch in awe. Â It was common to have large crowds show up when we would begin a shred session. Â More than once, the best skaters in SoCal would show up to see what the Kona Bowl was about, many of them leaving and discrediting the pool because it was too radical and difficult to skate.

item.title: Jim Sigurdson / Date Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jim Sigurdson We were skating at the Del Mar Skate Ranch right after it opened. Some guys showed up from the Palm Springs area and said that they knew of a huge pool out in the middle of nowhere that they'd skated. It was near Indio past Palm Springs. They drew us a map and we quickly loaded up the van and we drove out. That was how we did it back then. I recall the long drive. The heat. The winding roads. Laughter. We pulled up this dirt road after following the directions for a few hours and came to a stop. We all just stared. The pool was massive with huge Date Palm trees all over. It was a burned down resort and the pool also had a big jacuzzi pool next to it. Everyone swept it out and tore into it. It really was a big pool. Easy to develop speed. It was the pool where I started gaining height in my airs. We could fly in that pool.

item.title: The Valley
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: San Fernando Valley. The night hides a million horrors and ill deeds. People secure themselves behind barbed wire, brass locks and brandy. The world is held at bay. Lights shimmer from the hillsides. Every shadow hides a heartbeat. How long will the pattern of another broken life define us? How far will our voices reach as the machinery of government rides over our liberties? The valley held so much hope. Los Angeles sprawled and spilled up and over the hills... The further it grew, the higher the heat climbed and the freeways split things into parceled concrete and neon pieces. Huge palm trees and family homes climbed the hills and ran away across the valley as far as the eye could see. Shimmering water. Swimming pools. Dreams were built on the backs and sweat of the hard-working immigrants and residents. Years blew by. Goodness. It once was and it no longer was what it could've been. Unravelling. Some areas remain unchanged. Some are in decline. Some are lost. It is the way of things. Restoring order. Life will do it for us sometimes. In the 1970's, there was drought and heat. The San Fernando Valley cooked under the relentless sun. Skateboarders moved through the area. Cars were loaded with boards and the occupants were loaded in turn. Fun and mischief. It is what they did. Jerry Valdez, Kent Senatore, Marc Smith, Dave Ferry. Arthur Viecco, Brad Bowman, Shreddi Repas, Jay Smith and a crew of others, were constantly on the search. Unknowingly, they created a path for us to follow. Did you ever notice how day by day we do the same routines and nothing seems to change? Then, we eventually look back and nothing is the same. Everything is different. In this case, the world evolves into a continuing shit show. The lonely parade marches down the street followed by a band that plays no music... Â Rome burns. Skateboarders roam through the detritus of life and create where they can. What life leaves as scraps, we form into a useable canvas for expression. Urethane is our paint. Eddie Mighty Moreno, Oscar Navarro, Al Brunelle and Robbie Russo took MRZ and I to the San Fernando Valley the other weekend. They follow closely in the footsteps of their predecessors, yet they expand on an original idea. Progression. Things would cease to be interesting if those that come later, simply duplicate what is already here. These guys are our future. [caption id="attachment_16765" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Eddie Mighty Moreno[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16766" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16767" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Oscar Navarro[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16768" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Robbie Russo[/caption] We drove a concrete ribbon of oil and grease. Trash and smog were a constant reminder that there are far too many of us in the world. Condoms should come as standard equipment on all new models in production. The world is going half the speed of what it takes. We pushed through. Alleys. Cinder block walls. Foreclosures. Driving into a waning sun, we slipped into a quiet neighborhood. We pulled to the curb. Looking to the right, we all saw it. Neglect. Abandonment. The house sat in silence. Leaves and blistered paint marred its face. A broken white fence sagged on its hinges. "This is the one. It is basically a ten minute get in and handle your business type of pool." We nodded. Eyes ran over the nearby houses. I saw a neighbor standing shirtless on the sidewalk nearby. He already laser-beamed us. I wanted to walk up and tell him that I found his nose... in our business. I didn't. I smiled and said "Hello." I approached. I told him we wanted to skate the pool and take a few photographs. He turned his head to the side and spat on the ground. "You can do what you want. I aint no rat." With that, he turned on his heel and walked back into his garage. We slipped into the yard. It had huge trees and the pool was carpeted with debris. Everyone silently went to work. Within fifteen minutes, it was cleaned, ridden and vacated. Abandonment and neglect were conquered. The pool was left behind as a perfect memory of how a San Fernando Valley afternoon could be. We took a lost dream and infused with with new blood... if only for a brief moment. [caption id="attachment_16779" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Eddie Mighty Moreno[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16781" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Oscar Navarro[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16780" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Robbie Russo[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16782" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle[/caption] Thanks to MRZ for the images. Thanks to the crew. 1970's B&W image courtesy Fineman Archive. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Great read. Struck close to home having grown up in the Valley in the 70s and 80s. There were pools all over the place back then. First pool I ever skated we found by accident and by joking on the way home from "getting" wood for a ramp from a local in progress housing tract. I'm not sure which of the group said it, but we joked that it would be funny if there was a pool up on the hill across the street from the police station. We hiked up the dirt hill and our jaws dropped when among a bunch of scattered remains of a house a perfect kidney pool with just a couple feet of water in it sat before us. Needless to say it was drained and we were the first to skate it! sessions went on for some time until it's demise. There is a housing tract on that hill now without even a small hint of the magic that was once there.
-Aaron
Eddie M. Is sick. So contorted.
So rad.
3 of the 4 riders on this Valley posting are ACE PILOTS. MIGHTY, AL & Oscar...Yes they also won the Vans U.S. Open together as a team for VAL SURF. ACE the future? sorry indy, the time has come.

item.title: Allen Losi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Allen Losi One of my favorite Marina memories was the Dos Equis commercial. I was too young to drive and lived hours away, so every time I could go skate at Marina, it was a big day! The night of the Dos Equis shoot, I was going to stay the night there while they made a commercial. I skated all day long. After they closed for the night, the production crew set up a table of food and went to work up at the Turningpoint ramp which was at Marina at the time. I think I was with Lance Mountain. Â I remember eating until I felt sick and then I laid down on the balcony and a rat ran over me. I got up and I went to check the video shoot and saw either Duke Rennie or Fred Blood roller skating in a gold unitard. I remember thinking there's no way the commercial was worth that! The coastal fog came in and everything was too wet to skate, so everyone ended up in the pro shop all night. By the time I made it home the next day, I was more than spent! However, I was so content I remember it to this day.Â Another thing I have to say is, the Gyro Dog Bowl event, seriously opened up my skating mind. Jimmy Plummer, Dennis Polar Bear Agnew, Shreddi Repas... Â it was my favorite event of all time. I need to thank Eric Grisham for all the rides when I was just a grom.

item.title: Jim Sigurdson / Hilltop Roman
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jim Sigurdson Hilltop pool was found by Gunnar Haugo. It was off Buena Creek road. I guess that a greenhouse supplier friend knew we skated and had seen the pool empty. He told us about it. We knocked and they let us skate it whenever they were home. We just swept it out, kept it drained and cleaned the area up. It was a typically steep Roman pool. Mostly, we did facewall grinds and tailtaps. We rode the Hilltop if we had skated the Kona too often. It gave us a bit of variety... Â we rode pools and the VC reservoir. Good times.

item.title: Gold Cup Series
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Scott Foss / Gold Cup Marina The 1980's dawned bright and sunny. Pool riding contests were the measuring stick of the time. Compulsory runs were added to the Gold Cup regimen. The previous Hester Series I and Hester Series II, had no such thing. Compulsory runs changed the dynamic of the contest immensely. Trick-oriented skateboarding became the fuel that raced the contest series' engine. Skate parks had been sprouting up all over the country and there were many young riders that had learned quickly in such environments. Riders no longer had to find pools, trespass on school yards or risk arrest. They no longer needed to buy expensive lumber and build ramps. Skate parks were nearby and the skaters learned exponentially. It has been said that many of the Hester Series contest riders, quit the contest scene because of the compulsory runs. The compulsories went like this. The rider had to do a frontside carve, frontside air, invert, two backside carves, backside air, slide to fakie, then a fakie and a rock-n-roll and then a rock walk. If a rider didn't complete the compulsory, he was out. The invert wasn't learned by everyone and a few Hester Series riders were dismayed to find themselves shelved by the maneuver. Trick-oriented contest riding was born. The Gold Cup Series was held in 1980. Contest one was June 21-22 at Oasis Skate Park in San Diego, California. The rest of the contests were held over the next several months at Big O Skate Park in Orange, California, Colton Skate Ranch in Colton, California, Marina del Rey Skate Park in Marina del Rey, California and the series final at Pipeline Skate Park in Upland, California. A new hall of heroes and legends were made and would grace the pages of skateboard magazines at the time. Eddie Elguera, Steve Caballero, Duane Peters, Micke Alba and Dave Andrecht were among the highest placing in the series. Amateur divisions were held in the Gold Cup as well. Some of contemporary skateboardings biggest names, had their start in the Gold Cup. Billy Ruff, John Tex Gibson, Neil Blender, Lance Mountain,Â Christian Hosoi and Tony Hawk were quickly becoming a heavy threat on the amateur scene. They were the children of the skate park era. They were unique, inventive and consistent. They went high and they could rip. The Gold Cup Series brought a new level of invention, progression and creativity that had not been present before.

item.title: Curt Cortum / AZ Pipes
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Curt Cortum We had ridden the Mt. Baldy pipe and Pipeline skatepark's full pipe. We had heard rumors of the Arizona pipes. Everyone kept it quiet. When we got out there in the middle on nowhere and saw them, we couldn't believe it. They were huge. Perfect. There were tons of them. Sections were sitting around in no particular order. They spun them on site. Some had seams and others were seamed differently. It made no sense. I recall the Sharp brothers directing us towards certain pipe sections that they wanted us to ride. I guess the sun and light were better at different times. Once, Ameron Pipe Company workers came by and sat inside one of the nearby pipe sections. They sat in the only shade available, since there were no trees around and ate their lunches. They were hooting it up for us. I was lucky and I knew it. I was aware of how special this was... even at the time. Everyone in skateboarding was talking among themselves about these pipes. I think Gregg Ayres, Rodd Saunders and possibly Doug Schneider had gone out first. Â It was all pretty hush-hush. I ended up out there in Arizona quite a few times. Ameron put the pipes in the ground and we climbed down in and rode a downhill section as well. It was awesome. It seemed like we were surfing a giant wave. The Arizona pipes were different than anything we had ridden. Mt. Baldy was much smaller. The first time I went to Mt. Baldy, we were at the top of the spillway. We could see the pipe, but we couldn't get in. I went back to the nearby neighborhood and stole a garden hose. I tied it to the fence post and jumped over. That hose stretched so far.... We ended up riding but I was scared while there. It had been rumored that there were many people who were arrested skating the Mt. Baldy pipe. I got out of there unscathed.

item.title: Kent Senatore / Elephant Country
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Kent Senatore We were driving near my house one day. I lived up in the hills and we spotted a blue pool hose hanging down out of a yard. It was draining water into a hillside of ivy. We pulled over and ran up the hill. Â This was on the San Fernando Valley side. Near Laurel Canyon. It was off of Laurel Terrace actually. We peered over the hedges and saw tiles and coping. It was a huge left-handed kidney pool, almost completely empty. We came back pretty directly. It was usually, me, Dave Ferry, Marc Smith, Jerry Valdez and sometimes the Altieri brothers. The Elephant Country pool transitions were so good, I recall it being one of the first shallow ends where we would actually carve and keep our speed. We hadn't really done shallow riding up to that time. I think that we only rode it just a few times. The owners were out of town and were having the pool refurbished. Workers would be there sometimes and we couldn't get in there. It was called Elephant Country because inside the huge picture windows, there were two huge elephant tusks. They formed an arch. You can see them in the photographs... Â The house was situated on the top of a bluff and the valley was spread out below. Very scenic. High end neighborhood. I do vaguely recall being chased out of there. We split over the hedges and slipped and slid down the ivy hillside...

item.title: Jerry Valdez / Forward
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
âSkateboarding is the best education into oneself. Itâs not about having others make it for you; itâs about you making it happenâ. Jerry Valdez
Who would have thought that the late 1960âs and early 1970âs would have set the stage for what we call skateboarding today.Â Â Americaâs kids were looking for a physical outlet outside the existing sports.Â Â Born out of the concrete and asphalt jungles of the inner city, curing boredom and dissatisfaction, the skateboard delivered a solid solution to this need.Â Concrete drainage ditches, catch basins and empty swimming pools, were the playgrounds for a sport not yet accepted. Those few that had imagination, ambition and the mental âgo for itâ attitude,Â looked for more than the typical sidewalk ride and skateboarding became a way of life.
Challenge, a high level of confidence and visual art form, these were some of the virtues that created the icons of the 1970âs and set the standard moves that remain the staple of todayâs skating. For without the highest focus and commitment, pain and injury will follow. Only a handful of photographers were around to capture the history-making trendsetters who blazed a new trail for skateboarding.Â Â This book is a tribute to the pioneering skaters and BillÂ Sharp, whose photographic skills captured the state of the art at its ground breaking historical inception. BillÂ Sharpâs photography is a window into that time. For without his lens, most would not have pushed it to the max.Â I am proud to call myself a skater and thus be associated with the group of individuals that make up the brotherhood of skateboarders now and in this book. Enjoy the blood sweat and mega pain it took to produce these images.
The Jer
Â

item.title: Jerry Valdez / Skyline / Vipers
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jerry Valdez Skyline Bowl and Toilet Bowl were very close to each other. They were about a mile apart off Mulholland Drive near Beverly Hills. Skyline Bowl was a reservoir right below Benjamin 'Bugsy' Siegel's mansion. Madonna would eventually live there in the1990's. The neighborhoods near these reservoirs were high end and the homes spacious. People had money and with it came paranoia. The neighbors would see a bunch of kids scrambling out of cars with skateboards, making noise, hanging out... they didn't want anything to do with any of that. The spots were a pretty big bust. We'd ride Skyline. I'd carve and do handstands. Vipers Bowl was another one that we rode often. There were snakes at that spot but I recall this one guy that we rode with, being a great artist. He'd paint these dragons and serpents on the bottom of the bowl. They were like thirty or forty feet in size. We called it Vipers Bowl. We ruled there. They eventually filled it with asphalt and nature took its course. The area is now unrideable.

item.title: In Memoriam
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_16860" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Paul Hackett R.I.P.[/caption] All fled, all done, now lift me on the pyre.Â The feast is over and the lamps expired. - Robert E. Howard In Memoriam Life can come calling. Ups and downs. A narrow path. Life also stalks along with its pale ever-present shadow: death. Death is almost always unexpected and truly unwelcome. The dark night. The great end that is sweeping in. We live our oftentimes mundane lives and periodically things are kicked sideways around us. Some people lead their lives and some folks are led around by their own. Who's to say what is right? What is good and correct for one person, can be a downfall for another. Skateboarding has lost a few of its pioneers and friends. Demise. Poor choices facilitated some and others fell to a mysterious end that awaits us all. Story. Glory. Our Hall Of Heroes is a new one. We are building it. Skateboarding is a fresh face. A blonde-haired waif staring into the sun. We haven't been around too long. We are already losing the lifeblood that pulses through our collective consciousness. Our legacy is a broken board. Splintered men and fractured pieces. We have lost so much, too soon. This is our tribute to them. Thank you for making us what we are. Respect.

item.title: Gunnar Haugo / Hilltop Roman
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Gunnar Haugo I was working at a local nursery nearby in the Vista area and one of the guys that I worked with, knew that I skated pools. He had been to a house up on a hill close by and made a delivery of plants. He noticed a huge empty swimming pool in the yard and told me about it. I drove up after work. Approaching the house, I could see the red-colored coping and blue tiles in the backyard. I knocked. A really pretty hippy-looking chick answered and after I explained that I skated and all that, she said that we could ride. We had to keep it empty and the yard clean. It was a huge old Roman end pool. The face wall was perfect and the side walls were a bit steep. The coping was really big but it was great for edgers. We rode at the Hilltop Roman almost every other day. Other skaters found out and soon started driving up the driveway and just going back and skating. It freaked her out a bit and the owner shut it down. We rode pools all over Escondido, Fallbrook and Vista. John Warneke had a pilots license and put it to good use. We found a bunch of our pools from the airplane and then we'd just drive around and ask. If you never try, you'll never know.

item.title: Jerry Valdez / Elephant Country
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jerry Valdez The area where the Elephant Country pool was located were all high end homes. The neighborhood was lush and the property looked out over Studio City. That was Kent Senatore's backyard basically. The Val Surf kids lived all over those neighborhoods and up in the hillsides. Laurel Canyon. Studio City. Those neighborhoods were full of big homes and huge pools. I think that we rode Elephant Country about eight times. Probably less. The owners were gone and things were being repaired on the property. I think the pool was being worked on as well. It had nice flow, big transitions and great coping. It was sweet. The elephant tusks were just inside the big glass walls behind the pool so we named it Elephant Country. Fitting. Mr. Bennett and the owner of Val Surf -Mark Richards were at the pool when I shot a Bennett advertisement there. The pool and property were really picturesque.

item.title: Jerry Valdez / Corral Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jerry Valdez Corral Pool. It was my local spot. Craig Stecyk did an article "Things Are Hot In The Valley" and it featured the Corral Pool. There were horse corrals, avocado and citrus trees.Â The place had worm beds. Two foot high wooden boxes all over the place. It was a big property. That pool was our bread and butter. We were skating there quite a bit. If I remember correctly, I think that the owners of the house knew Arthur Viecco. That pool was one of our daily stops. It had a deathbox, loveseats, pebble coping... We spent many hot summer afternoons at the Corral. Great memories.

item.title: Jerry Valdez / Mondo's
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Jerry Valdez

We always looked around for pools. Our whole crew would stay on the lookout. We rode pools in Los Angeles, Beverly Hills, Studio City, Holmby Hills, Brentwood... We'd skate all over. Once we started riding for Val Surf, kids would stop in the shop and talk about pools that they had going in their neighborhoods. We'd be in the magazines and stuff and they'd invite us to ride their pools. That is how we'd ride so many. Mondo's was one of these. We found out about it through some kids. We'd skate six to eight new pools a week. Some we'd hit and never go back. Others were too good. Mondo's was one of our regular pools we wanted to ride. It was deep in the San Fernando Valley though. Super hot. Dirty. It was a really great pool. We could do hip tailtaps, deathbox grinds, airs...It was perfect.

item.title: Arthur Viecco / Corral Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_16885" align="aligncenter" width="584"] KENT CORRAL[/caption] Arthur Viecco The Corral Pool was only a few minutes from my house. I didn't discover it, but I became friends with the family that lived there. Â I was always pretty nice to them. A local kid. A bunch of skaters started really going there and the family finally said that people could only skate if they came with me.Â The pool was off Tobias Avenue in Panorama City. There were a bunch of pools in that area. It was my neighborhood. Old ranch houses. Citrus trees. The Willis pool was a few blocks away as well. Most of those pools are long gone as is Corral. Apartments sit on the Willis pool lot. Times change. The Corral Pool was great. Stacy Peralta loved it. He taught me fakies in that pool.

item.title: Jerry Valdez / L-Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Jerry Valdez The L-Pool was a huge swim club pool in Upland somewhere. It was definitely a Badlands pool. Those guys rode it hard and had talent. It was at a defunct swimming club and the pool had varied transitions throughout. It was a spit gutter top as well. On the deep end face wall, the locals had put wood inside the spit gutter--filling it in-- so a skater could ride over it and get to the top edge of the pool. I went there with the Sharp brothers. They had heard about it. I remember that I was riding a very narrow Z-Flex board and really large Road Rider wheels. I pulled edgers on that thing. I think Lee Gahimer was there and a bunch of local kids. It was big, nice and very open.

item.title: Skateparks
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: In March of 1976, Carlsbad Skatepark opened. It was designed and built by Jack Graham and John O'Malley. The two would go on to consult and design a dozen skatepark projects, including Concrete Wave in Anaheim and Shady Acres in Long Beach. They publish a skatepark builderâs guide, "Skatepark Development." This is the beginning of skateparkÂ constructionÂ all over California and eventually worldwide. Skateparks begin to appear all over the United States. Most are completed by contractors who learned their craft pouring foundations of buildings and such. The skatepark designs are fairly poor and little is done to ascertain the skaters needs. Skateboard professionals began seeing the need to become involved. They took what they had learned riding swimming pools, catch basins, reservoirs and pipes and applied that knowledge when giving advice to skatepark builders. Skateparks began to improve dramatically. Pools and concrete finishes were made smoother. Flaws were minimized. Walls were even and flow was maintained. Modern skateboarding aficionados had a better place to learn and develop. The next generation would learn, evolve and invent at an alarming rate. The skate park boom ensured it.

item.title: William Sharp Book Project / Oxnard
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I spent an entire year questioning the early pioneers of skateboarding. I emailed, phoned and then wrote down anecdotes and memories. William Sharp scanned negatives and slides for days on end. He told me, "One rainy February morning, Â I made coffee, came into my study and started scanning. The next thing I knew, my wife was phoning and asking what I wanted for dinner. It was already after 6:00 pm." He confided that there were several days spent in such a manner. I have spoken to most of the main skaters that William Sharp photographed all those long summers ago. I've been frustrated, elated, humored, humbled and appalled. Most were gracious and accommodating. Most were surprised that anyone was interested in listening to them. Many really delved deep, trying to give me what I needed. Some used me for their own ends. Â In retrospect, it was a learning experience. I found out the stories behind the story. I learned. I am presenting these riders in their own words. When these photographs were taken, I lived in Pennsylvania. Although I started skating in 1973, I wasn't here. I was there. Outsider. I've never been a pro. I've never been sponsored. I've never been anything other than a collector of words. A manipulator of sorts. I claim nothing else. I spent the entire weekend going over everything page by page. A few of the riders are still holding out. Whether it is ambivalence, distrust, sloth or they simply don't care is of no consequence at this point. I'll put them in the book regardless. Respect for what they've done. I'm in Oxnard this morning already. William and I are doing an image count and then we are moving forward. I'll keep you informed. Thank you for the support. - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Oh hell yes Ozzie! Much respect to you and Bill for putting forth the effort and investing the time to bring these images and pages to life. I know of this process all too well. Let me know if there is anything that i can do for you guys to help.
All the best!

F*** yeah Ozzie ! It's the few like you that all the rest of us end up being thankful for in the end. Thank you.

Looking forward to more more more! Thanks a ton for keeping such a great body of work (skating and your blog) so fresh! Cheers!

Awesome project. Keep up the great work. Let me know if you need help with the layout or publishing.
-Aaron

item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Beverly Hills. There are spacious yards and properties so vast and sprawling, you think that you are passing by a college campus. I recall one day a few years ago. Tony Alva and I were driving somewhere up in Beverly Hills. He pointed casually to his right and said, "Tom Cruise has a house right there." I looked over. I saw huge trees, a high wall and beyond that, what looked like a hotel somewhere in Europe. I replied, "Really? He actually lives in that!? That's where he lives?" We were driving about forty miles per hour, talking and we were still driving past his house... yeah, his property seemed that big. How much does one person need? Yesterday, I drove over to Los Angeles to see TA. We wanted to touch base, go over the William Sharp book material, skate and hang out. I hadn't seen TA since our surf adventure to Scorpion Bay in Mexico back in May. He was busy. I was busy. Life on life's terms. He wouldn't be home until 3:30 pm. I drove over to Bel Air and into Studio City early in the day and prowled the hillsides looking for pools. I had to be careful. People gate everything and most homes are on video surveillance. If I got popped lurking in those neighborhoods, Â they would take me to the wall. [caption id="attachment_16904" align="aligncenter" width="584"] You better bring backup.[/caption] I drove up onto Mulholland Drive. Buildings towered downtown as Los Angeles floated like a million dreams in the distance. I pulled to the side of an overlook and checked my phone. Satellite. I saw Skyline and couldn't believe it. "Damn. After all these years!?" I recalled photographs of TA, Kent Senatore, Jerry Valdez, the Altieri brothers and a few other guys just tearing it up in the early skateboard magazines. I negotiated a few turns. The sun glimmered. I pulled over as I saw the rusting chain link fence looming to my left. My heart thumped. It looked just like the photographs from my youth. Ivy and brush grew thick and lush against the fences. I approached the edge. I half expected to see Jerry Valdez or TA standing on the lip and pushing an old Logan Earth Ski or Z-Flex board, dropping down that steep face. Quiet met me at the gate. Nothing stirred. It was just me and my childish heart... I slipped over and walked around. It was so abrupt and steep at the bottom, I wondered how they didn't tear their trucks off. The corners were rounded. I imagined them carving... Amazing. I sat on the wall. I breathed it in. I don't care if anyone thinks I'm a dork. It was moving to be there. Â I remembered the photographs. I remember the snow in Pennsylvania piling up outside. I heard the snowplow rattle up the road in front of the house. I looked back down at the magazine again. Skyline... and here I was thirty-five years later.Â Full circle. It took me awhile to leave. Driving into Coldwater Canyon, I saw construction fences. I saw work crews. I ran my eyes over the homes. Nothing escaped me. Detail. Recon. I spotted something to my left. Next street-a quick turn around. Pulling into a small narrow lane, I stopped. Shade trees. Ivy covered walls. A dog barks. I stood in silence a few moments and then I peered over a crumbling wall. The pool was a Paddock square. The shallow end was pushed in. Construction debris lay everywhere. I took a peek inside a window. Old chandeliers, furniture, dishes and rugs were piled against the walls. A bygone era. A better time. Fini. The pool sat neglected. Demolition time was on its horizon. I slipped out and headed to TA's house. We had to return together. At his house, we went over some photographs from the William Sharp book and we completed an interview. We sipped espresso and caught up on things. TA told me about his band GFP and his musical interests. He showed me his new Alva signature acoustic bass that Fender is making. It sounded so good as his fingers deftly moved up and down, playing GFP tunes. The sun was waning as I told TA about the nearby pool. He grabbed his stuff, we threw a broom into the truck and left. "We definitely have to check it out." Driving down, we parked and went inside. We swept the pool and quickly found ourselves carving, turning and riding over the light in the faltering afternoon sun. We were laughing. It was tiny and fairly tight. We didn't care. TA smiled and pushed in. He said, "In the 1970's, we'd ride anything." TA found a little whippy, side-bounce line that sent him over the light. He hit a quick grind and frontside snapped the shallow side wall. We slipped out as we had slipped in. We took nothing but the fun. Wheel marks on old faded plaster were the only thing that spoke of our passing... Thanks Tony. Epic. - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Keep up the interesting life. Get out in the surf more and wash off that pool dust.
loved it!

Nice fotos on the Skyline Pit. The infamous Toilet Bowl is just down the hill on Wrightwood Lane. The Viper Bowl is right above the Hollywood Reservoir. The Mini Bowl is below Skyline. Some surveillance shots of those places would be epic.

item.title: Chris Miller- Tell Us About It.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Chris Miller "Bucky's pool is a masterpiece for sure. Absolutely perfect concrete work, beautiful coping, and angles that work really well. It's wide open, but you never really lose speed in it. In fact, if you're riding it right and tapping into the lines, there's an abundance of speed. Almost too much. The shallow end is something like nine foot deep and it doesn't have any flat, so when you drop and get a solid pump off the waterfall, you have a scary amount of speed. It's this super intense acceleration that doesn't really happen at other spots. Of course, you need the speed to get up those giant walls, but the way you feel the speed is very unique and kind of startling the first few times you skate it. This particular shot was from some of our first sessions there. The deck hadn't been poured yet which was sort of scary-weird and made everything feel another foot or so higher. The line I take to get into this tail grab is a slingshot carve through the giant shallow pocket (that feels amazing all by itself) and sets me up with speed for a massive air. it usually takes me a few tries to make one of these because there's just so much speed and G's, it's easy to go too high and have it get away from me. That said, if I can control the launch and control take off, the landing can be somewhat forgiving. That big corner is like a massive catchers mitt just waiting. There's so much transition and curve that I can kind-of land anywhere. The other thing is that it spits me back out down the long way on the flat, so I can relax once I put it down. It's pool skating with snowboard scale." - Chris Miller Thank you to Chris Miller for taking the time to tell us about it. Thank you to MRZ for always being there and providing the skateboard world with stellar images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: NHS History Museum & 40TH Anniversary
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_16936" align="aligncenter" width="584"] FORTY YEARS[/caption]
The titans of it all were there in force. Salba, Duane Peters, Steve Olson, Lance Mountain, Rick Blackhart, Steve Caballero, Christian Hosoi, John Lucero, Jeff Grosso, Brad Bowman, Darren Navarette, Peter Hewitt... the list could fill this piece. The new industry standard for skate history museums was being unveiled at the VIP event which coincided with the 40th anniversary of N.H.S. Many of the key players were assembled to see for it themselves. They would not be disappointed.
[caption id="attachment_16937" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jeff Grosso, Christian Hosoi and Lance Mountain[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16938" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Duane Peters[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16939" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rob Roskopp & Steve Olson[/caption]
The museum is much more than a display of skate history. ItÂ isÂ skate history, right down to the very "walls" that some of the displays hang on. Upended skated ramps, complete with wheel and board marks form some of the actual pathways that you travel to view the displays... it is pure skateboarding and it is completely fucking proper.
While the museum highlights the history of the specific brands that N.H.S. has developed, we all came not so much to celebrate this or any other particular piece of history, as much as we came to revel in the fact that skatingÂ hasÂ a history that we're all part of. Even those of us that were there in the beginningÂ tend to get stuck on the immediate, the impending and forget the significance to our lives of what has already been. This museum has been erected to remind us of whence we came, lest we forget our roots.Â Moreover, an unfortunate affliction of youth is the inability to see the significance in the moments you live and even more, the ones that have come before. This place will be here to show them that their personal journey in skating actually began long before they put their prints on it.
[caption id="attachment_16941" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Scott Foss[/caption]
I was picked up by Santa Cruz in early 1978 and got sponsored by Independent trucks shortly thereafter. I was among the first group to have that honor, so this was almost surreal on a personal level. It spoke to me through some of the most significant moments in our history, moments I was privileged to witness first hand on many occasions. I was there at Winchester skatepark when the first production Independent trucks were unveiled to the public at large by the Buck brothers, Peter Gifford and company. I sat next to Jay Shuirman at the Newark contest and watched Bobby Valdez pull off the first hand plant in competition. I was no more than ten feet away. I witnessed Rick Blackhart skating at the same event, power grinding his way into the first Indy ad. Here it all is, the boards, trucks, photos and most importantly the people. This place is almost beyond words and description for me. It is a tactile connection to the past and the feeling and energy that was the beginning of what is now. It is an awesome collection of the artifacts of our lineage.
[caption id="attachment_16942" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bob Denike[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16943" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Roderick[/caption] [caption id="attachment_16944" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Richard Novak (center)[/caption]
My old friend and skate partner Bob Denike is the "Man' at N.H.S. as many of you may know. What most may not realize is that while many have worked tirelessly to put this epic museum together, Bob has also been as busy as anyone down in the trenches. He didn't just pontificate and delegate but personally went out in search of the fragmented pieces of our history, dealing with various "unique" individuals, hassles and frustrations all while also running a major corporation. We are all extremely fortunate to have a man like him at the helm of one of our industry giants. His character is beyond reproach and he sweats out and engineers every detail purely out of his love and dedication to our craft. This museum is a testament to that. What was is inseparable from what is. May the future be worthy of the glorious past that created it. Peace. - Scott Foss
Thank you to Lorrie Palmos for the images and Scott Foss for taking us along for the evening. Skate- Ozzie

The items from the 70's & 80's are incredible. Not only does the museum show the history of NHS since 1973, it shows the history and design history of Indy Trucks!

item.title: Dogbowl / Wayne Babcock
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Wayne Babcock was one of the original crew that drained the Dogbowl. Here is a rare bit of footage from the summer and fall of 1977. Skate - Ozzie
